PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Brownhill (from 115 citizens) and O'Chee (from 24 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitions request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Durack (from 93 citizens) and Powell (from 1,123 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned showeth that:

In the light of public concern at the operations and decisions of the Family Court, we the undersigned support a full and open enquiry into all aspects of the Family Law Act and Practises as proposed by Senator David Brownhill, NSW.
This enquiry should also cover related issues such as legal representation and the child Support Agency.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Health Act
PETITION.PARA: The draft Charter of Residents' Rights and Responsibilities and the draft Agreement to be entered into between the Proprietors of Nursing Homes and their Residents which have been tabled in the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia by the Honourable Peter Staples, Minister for Housing and Aged Care on 18 September 1990.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the above draft Charter and Agreement are designed to require Proprietors of Nursing Homes to act in a manner contrary to proper moral standards and to incur obligations that are likely to lead to unnecessary expense and litigation.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament amend the said Draft Charter and Agreement in such ways as are necessary:
1. To preserve the Proprietor's rights to ensure that providers of Health Care Services to Residents comply with the Philosophy of the Proprietor in relation to such services.

2. To ensure that the Agreement can be offered to Residents of Nursing Homes without offending the conscience of Proprietors and Staff who have moral objections to the grant to any person of a right to indulge in extramarital sexual intercourse in their Nursing Homes.
3. To eliminate vague and uncertain language.

4. To remove from the Draft Agreement the provisions which impose on Proprietors and Staff onerous responsibilities that will increase demands on the human and material resources of the Nursing Homes without securing any essential benefit to the Residents.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy: Family Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That the Government is planning to introduce an assets test on Family Allowance at a level of $300,000. It will also reduce the threshold for the Austudy and Family Allowance Supplement (FAS) assets tests from $322,759 to $200,000.

Your petitioners ask that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Australian Government to exempt the family farm of registered primary producers who are living and working on their own farm from inclusion in the assets tests for Austudy, Family Allowance and Family Allowance Supplement.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Spindler) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Financial Corporations Act 1974 and related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Spindler) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, I have the honour tonight of introducing legislation to finally establish a proper national framework for the regulation of the non-bank financial system in Australia. Following a series of crashes in the non-bank sector, the Bill is designed to restore investors' confidence in the Australian financial system by providing them with investment avenues which are supervised and secure.

Non-bank financial institutions (NBFI's) provide an important alternative to the dominant deposit taking institutions-the banks. Even though bank deposits are guaranteed by the Reserve Bank, market niches are filled by NBFI's. This arises from regional, social or even structural factors. Indeed there is an innovative proposal for a Building Society for women currently before the Victorian Government. Special conditions will apply to loans during pregnancy and maternity leave. Certainly the Australian Democrats support the choice and diversity which NBFI's provide.

However the non-bank deposit taking sector has lost market share since bank deregulation. The number of building societies has halved in the last four years. Many have converted to banks and many have been acquired by banks. Others have failed, losing hundreds of millions of investors' funds. The Farrow Group is a spectacular example of the result of inadequate supervision. Several Credit Unions and Friendly Societies have also run into trouble. Clearly strong supervision is necessary to protect investors' interests.

To many people it is absurd that Australia remains a collection of States as opposed to a Nation. Unfortunately some people still seek to divide our great country on the basis of some arbitrary lines ruled onto a (still incomplete) map of Australia in London during the l9th century.

Happily the heads of Australia's various Governments have finally sat down and commenced a process of efficiency, rationalisation and reconciliation and hopefully will embark on the setting of national priorities and national goals and actually achieving them.

However, in this area the result of the Premiers' Conference has been disappointing. The proposal emerging from the Conference seeks to set up a cumbersome bureaucratic structure with Boards in each State in turn reporting to yet another National Commission.

There are no clear lines of accountability, no national scheme and no guarantee by the Reserve Bank. Yet the Reserve Bank in its charter has been given responsibility over the Australian financial system.

We should take a lesson from the long and weary process to achieve uniform companies legislation and put the ultimate responsibility for our financial system where it should rest: with the Reserve Bank and the Commonwealth Government.
To date Australia as a whole has been the loser because of the archaic division of responsibilities which were necessary to achieve the compromise of which the Australian Constitution is the result.

However, with respect to non-bank financial institutions the lack of efficient supervision and the consequent problems experienced by some sectors of industry cannot be blamed on the Constitution. There is specific power granted to this Parliament to make laws with respect to financial corporations. This Parliament has exercised that power.

The blame lies with successive Federal Governments who have failed to proclaim Part IV of the Financial Corporation Act. Presumably this inaction has been based on the notion of States' rights. This is a nebulous concept usually reserved for justifying reactionary positions by those seeking to maintain their particular sphere of influence.

The usual outcry which follows any attempt to introduce some reason into our society has been muted lately. No small credit for this should go to the increasingly statesmanlike actions of the New South Wales Premier. Whilst vehemently disagreeing with many of the policies of his Government I pay tribute to his efforts to bring conservative politics into the modern era. I hope his Federal colleagues support this Bill.

Incredibly Mr Keating and Mr Fraser have rebuffed attempts by the States to transfer the responsibility for the regulation of NBFI's to the Commonwealth via the Reserve Bank. This is an amazing and ironic role reversal in inter-governmental relations!

Surely there is no greater national economic responsibility than the health of the financial system itself. If the financial system collapses so does our economy. Along with it goes personal and community prosperity. Eventually our society would disintegrate.

Indeed the Reserve Bank has a responsibility for the stability of the financial system as a whole. How can it fulfil such a responsibility adequately when it only has an indirect role in the management of the nonbank financial sector?

Mr President, this Bill seeks to complete the national prudential supervision role of the Reserve Bank. In fact, in the case of Building Societies and to a lesser extent Credit Unions, the Reserve Bank does in fact indirectly support these institutions by supporting the banks who from time to time need to provide liquidity or other assistance.

This existing structure is obviously deficient because ultimately a bank (which operates in competition with NBFI's) will need to support an ailing NBFI. Commercial considerations will be at odds with the protection of the NBFI. Clearly such a system is untenable. This potentially severe problem will be remedied by this Bill and consequently an improved financial system will result.
I now turn to the specific provisions of the Bill.

This Bill proposes to transfer to the Reserve Bank the responsibility for the prudential supervision of financial corporations. Currently the provisions contained in Part IV of the Financial Corporations Act 1974 have not commenced operation because the proclamation necessary under the legislation has never been made. While using the structure of that legislation the content has been expanded and brought up to date.

Clause 3 of the Bill proposes to amend the Principal Act to ensure that the currently dormant Part IV will commence when this Bill commences, which Clause 2 of the Bill determines will occur at the time of Royal Assent.

From that time onwards the Reserve Bank will have supervisory power with respect to the asset ratios, lending policies, interest rates and other matters concerning NBFI's as well as the powers over banks.

Prudential controls will be enacted by a proposed new Part IVA which will treat the deposit taking institutions that is building societies and credit unions in a similar manner to banks. Minimum risk weighted capital adequacy ratios will be imposed on all these institutions. Initially Building Societies and Credit Unions will be subjected to a minimum ratio of 8%, which is the rate that currently applies to banks. There is separate power in the Bill to vary the ratio for the different categories of NBFI's. This initial level is also the level chosen by the Victorian Government in a Bill which is currently before that Parliament concerning proposed prudential supervision measures for Building Societies.

These ratios will replace the various liquidity ratios which currently apply under State legislation. There is also a power to vary the capital adequacy requirements where it is expedient to do so in the interests of members or depositors of the institution.
In addition a prime assets ratio will be imposed on both building societies and credit unions at the initial rate or 10 per cent.

Further measures are also proposed to ensure the liquidity and the solvency of these deposit taking institutions and societies. A specific national liquidity and solvency fund for both building societies and credit unions. These funds will not be pooled between the different entities. Consequently the distinct industry structure of the various NBFI's will be maintained. These funds will commence six months after Royal Assent to allow time to arrange the matters with the States and to transfer existing funds.

There is a further set of provisions which ensure the Reserve Bank may intervene in respect of significant asset acquisitions by building societies and credit unions. This power would only be exercised in extreme cases to safeguard the interest of depositors. One recent example of an NBFI putting too many eggs in one basket is the Dreamworld investment made by the OST Friendly Society. The investors have no say in the actual portfolio decisions made by trustees or fund managers and hence some broad prudential controls in this area are needed in some extreme circumstances.
No action is proposed by this Bill in respect of merchant banks, finance companies, trustee companies or non-deposit taking societies including terminating building societies.
This does not mean no reform is necessary in respect of these entities. On the contrary the Australian Democrats see an urgent need for extending appropriate measures to these institutions.

For example we support a consolidation of the various Trustee Acts to simplify and streamline trust, and especially estate, administration. The Companies and Securities Industry Legislation also needs reform in this area.

Further, there is also an urgent need to obtain uniform consumer credit laws in this country. The States are considering the issue, however nothing substantial has yet been achieved. Hopefully the recent Premiers Conference will provide some momentum to this process.

Next we need to turn our attention to the national regulation of Friendly Societies. It is understood that the question of the supervision of Friendly Societies is being considered as part of the review of the Life Insurance industry being conducted by the Office of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. That office may well be a more appropriate regulatory body than the Reserve Bank. Nevertheless this Bill brings Friendly Societies under the registration and statistics provisions of the Financial Corporations Act for the first time.

The Bill also proposes to delete the now redundant reference to Papua New Guinea in the Principal Act. The reference arose because of PNG's status (as an external territory) at the time of passage of the original legislation. All the penalty provisions of the Principal Act have been increased by 500% to restore their real value.

Mr President this Bill represents merely the first stage of the Australian Democrats vision for the financial system in Australia. Uniform national prudential supervision will help to restore the confidence which is currently lacking in the NBFI sector.

The next stage would be a transition to a genuine national administration system. Such a system would embrace all financial corporations and investment vehicles such as unit trusts. Obviously extensive consultation and agreement with the States would be necessary to facilitate such a system.

Finally, we envisage a situation where after a sufficient period of active prudential supervision some or all of the various categories of deposit taking NBFI's will qualify for the deposit guarantee which is currently enjoyed by depositors in banks.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BUREAU OF STATISTICS (PARLIAMENTARY SUPERVISION OF PROPOSALS) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Walters) agreed to:

That the following Bill be introduced: A bill for an Act to amend the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act 1975 to provide for parliamentary supervision of the collection of information for statistical purposes.
Motion (by Senator Walters) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Following the question on my Bill for an Act to provide for voluntary answers to statistical surveys for all surveys save the census itself passing in the negative on a tied vote in the Senate, I now present a new Bill for an Act to amend the ABS Act 1975 to provide for parliamentary supervision of the collection of information for statistical purposes.
The purpose of this Bill is to allow for parliamentary scrutiny and, if necessary, rejection of statistical proposals within five sitting days of its tabling in both Houses of the Parliament.

Under present arrangements if the Government Statistician wishes to make a compulsory survey then he is required to table his proposals in both Houses of Parliament. There is currently no provision to reject or vary the proposals. This fact makes me wonder why the Statistician did not table the present household expenditure survey which is a compulsory one and thus differs in a most significant way from previous surveys which were voluntary.
I can only surmise that the reason was to keep the increased size, inquisitiveness and expansion of the survey from the view of the Parliament.
The current household expenditure survey has caused great contention, concern and harassment in the community despite denials by the Statistician.

The Statistician is asking people to disclose intimate details of their household income and expenditure of a most personal nature. Information that could not possibly be of value for determining the CPI, average weekly earnings and pension increases. Information such as the size and nature of bank loans, the collateral offered for them, access to people's bank managers, and other such information up to and including production of their income tax returns.
So much for having a privacy Bill to protect your tax file in one area when in another area the Statistician can ask you for your tax return.

The Government Statistician has become far too aggressive and assertive and has savaged the parliamentary process and the Clerk of the Senate. For his own reasons and against competent advice from his officers he decided not to table the proposals for the household expenditure survey and yet wanted to compel answers from people on the grounds that the survey was no different from previous ones. This is patently ridiculous and has been admitted by officers of the Bureau in the Estimates committees because other surveys were voluntary and if this one is compulsory that is a significant difference.
This Bill will allow for parliamentary scrutiny of survey proposals and their acceptance or rejection. Acceptance will give proposals the authority of parliamentary scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I understand that agreement has been reached between all parties that the Bill now proceed through all stages forthwith. I seek leave to make a brief explanation on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will recall that my former colleague Senator Sheil secured passage in this place of an Australian Bureau of Statistics (Amendment) Bill in 1989. The credit for this Bill, as the Senate will be aware, goes to former Senator Sheil for his work in endeavouring to make the data collection activities of the Australian Bureau of Statistics more accountable to Parliament and to the Australian people. I therefore consider it appropriate that Senator Sheil's original second reading speech, which launched the Bill in its successful passage through this place in 1989, be again placed on record. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This Bill, like the End of War List Bill, has been passed previously by the Senate. We therefore concur to its going through its final reading today, without necessarily saying that it will go through with or without our support. But it does reflect the will of the Senate previously. I agree with Senate Walters's procedure in that it will save a lot of time.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

COMMONWEALTH AND STATE HOUSING AGREEMENT (SERVICE PERSONNEL) BILL 1990

The Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement (Service Personnel) Bill gives effect to the renegotiation with the States of existing agreements on the provision of housing for members of the Defence Force.

Under a series of agreements made between 1945 and 1979 the Commonwealth advanced funds to the States to construct houses to be used by Defence Force personnel. The Commonwealth was required to lease the dwellings at a rent which covered all State costs including the principal and interest payments on the Commonwealth loans, repairs and maintenance, insurance and administration. Ownership of the houses remained with the States, with a State acquiring possession once a house was no longer required for Defence purposes.
As at June 1987 some 14,000 Defence houses had been provided under these agreements.

The agreements were unsatisfactory in many respects. With ownership remaining with the States, the Commonwealth was unable to trade in the houses with a view to improving the quality of the Defence housing stock. Additionally, the arrangements with the States could not provide the greater flexibility in Defence housing that became necessary as operational requirements led to changes in the location of Defence personnel. As far as the States were concerned, as the houses could not be returned until they were no longer required for Defence purposes, they had no certainty that a house would become available for public housing.

The Government established the Defence housing authority in 1988 as the single agency responsible for meeting Defence housing needs. With the commencement of the authority, it was opportune to approach the States to renegotiate these agreements, with the aim of having the authority assume control of all Defence housing.

Under the renegotiation terms offered to the States the Commonwealth assumes ownership of 50% (by value) of the agreed stock of Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (Service Personnel) houses, with the other half handed back to the States. This handback is to be achieved over five years, with 60% of handbacks to occur within the first two years. The renegotiation agreement deems the handback period for most States to have commenced on 1 July 1989. The outstanding debt on the houses is to be shared equally between the Commonwealth and the States.
All States, with the exception of South Australia, have agreed to the renegotiation.
The Bill enables the Commonwealth to enter into the necessary agreements, obtain title to houses, and to forego half of the outstanding debt owed to it by each State.
Financial impact statement.

Agreement with the States will result in the transfer of housing assets valued in excess of $600 million from the States to the Commonwealth. It is planned that up to 4400 houses from the stock transferred from the States will be sold.
Houses of equivalent value will be returned to the States. Some 4200 houses will be handed back to the States over the first two years of the agreement, and around 7000 over the full five years.
Liability for debt totalling approximately $110 million will be transferred from the States to the Defence Housing Authority.

The 7000 houses to be returned to the States will require replacement. The bulk of these will be funded from the existing Defence housing program. However, approval has been given for the Defence Housing Authority to borrow an additional $250 million for housing acquisitions. A further 2000 dwellings will be leased.

The improved quality of the 7000 replacement dwellings will result in the Department of Defence paying increased market rentals to the Defence Housing Authority. In the current financial year the part year effect is expected to be approximately $2.5 million. By the end of the handback program in 1995-96, rent payments will have increased by approximately $24 million per year.

The renegotiation will provide the Defence Housing Authority with title to a significant housing asset. Once it obtains title, the authority will be able to trade in those houses. Over the five year period of the agreement, 7000 houses will be made available to the States for public housing.
In all, this is a most satisfactory result.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
DEFENCE FORCE (HOME LOANS ASSISTANCE) BILL 1990

The Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Bill gives effect to the Government's undertakings to establish a new form of housing assistance for members of the Defence Force who enlisted on or after 15 May 1985, and puts in place arrangements for the sale of the franchise to provide loans under the new scheme to the National Australia Bank.

It has been the Government's desire to establish a form of housing assistance which would encourage home ownership for members of the Australian Defence Force and which would provide an incentive for individuals to remain in the Defence Force.
The Government also recognises the need to ensure that Defence Force personnel do not suffer any detriment in relation to home ownership as a result of the nature of their employment.
The new form of housing assistance provided in this Bill is designed to meet these objectives.

The new scheme is available to all members of the Defence Force who enlisted on or after 15 May 1985. In general, those who enlisted prior to that date remain eligible for assistance under the Defence Service Homes Loan Scheme, although those in this category who are still serving and have not exercised a Defence Service Homes Loan entitlement may elect for assistance under the new scheme. Personnel in this position will be advised of the provisions of the new scheme and will be required to make their election by 30 June 1991.

Defence Force personnel will generally need to have served for at least 6 years in order to become eligible for the new scheme. There are, however, special circumstances where this requirement will not apply, such as where an individual is involved in operational service in the Persian Gulf or is discharged as the result of a compensable medical condition.

The new scheme provides eligible personnel with a subsidised housing loan of up to $40,000. Interest on the loan is subsidised to the extent of 40% of the average interest that would ordinarily be payable over the term of the loan; the individual will be required to meet the remaining 60%.

With a view to retaining personnel in the Defence Force, the Government wished to ensure that the extent of assistance was linked to continuing service in the Defence Force. Thus, the subsidy will be available for the period of completed years which the individual continues to serve beyond the initial six year qualifying period. For example, a member of the Defence Force who has completed 14 years service is able to receive the subsidy for a period of 8 years.

The loan may be taken out either during service with the Defence Force or at any time up until two years after the individual has left the Defence Force. The subsidy is available for a maximum period of 20 years. In order to become eligible for the subsidy, the individual will be required to reside in the house for which the loan has been provided. The loan may be transferred from one house to another while the individual serves in the Defence Force, and once during the first two years after the individual leaves the Defence Force.

On 17 August 1990 the Government announced that the franchise to provide loans under the new scheme had been sold to the National Australia Bank. The bank will pay the Commonwealth $42 million for the franchise, plus an additional annual commission, the amount of which will be dependant on the number of loans taken out in the year. The commission will commence at $975 per loan, increasing to $2700 per loan by the year 2002.

Outlays on the new scheme will be dependant on the extent of take-up of subsidised loans. Assuming a take up rate of 8%, outlays in the 1990-91 financial year would amount to $135,000 rising to $1.779 million in 1991-92, $4.187 million in 1992-93 and $7.712 million in 1993-94. These figures do not take account of those personnel who elect to relinquish their entitlement to a Defence Service Homes Loan to take up assistance under the new scheme, a figure which cannot be reliably estimated at this time.
This legislation will provide the framework for a worthwhile and effective scheme of housing assistance for Defence Force personnel.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
CORPORATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

There is, I think, no doubt that the closing years of this decade will be remembered as one of the bleakest chapters in Australia corporate history. It is a period which has witnessed the collapse of a number of major players on the Australian corporate stage.

Tragically, these collapses have brought with them some appalling losses of shareholders' and investors' funds. They have also brought to light evidence of outrageous irresponsibility and excesses on the part of the directors and management of some major corporations.
The damaging effects of this behaviour on Australia's reputation in the international marketplace has been all too obvious.

These events, Mr President, have indelibly underscored the Government's long held belief that corporate regulation and investor protection in this country has been inadequately served by the co-operative companies and securities scheme which had its genesis in a 1978 agreement between the then Commonwealth Government and the States.

A major flaw of the co-operative scheme has been the lack of a single, clearly defined line of Ministerial responsibility to a single Parliament for the operation of the scheme. No single Minister or Government has been able to be held properly accountable for the regulation of companies and securities in this country.
The outcome has been fragmented administration, ineffective use of resources and the lack of consistent, co-ordinated and coherent direction in regulation and enforcement.

As Honourable Senators will recall, Mr President, the Government sought to redress the shortcomings of the cooperative scheme by the introduction in 1988 of an historic package of legislation designed to bring the administration of companies and securities law for the first time under a single and truly national regulatory regime.

The centrepiece of that legislation was the Corporations Act enacted by this Parliament in 1989 with strong business and investor support. That legislation brought together into a single legislative instrument the law regulating company law, company takeovers and the regulation of the securities and futures industries. In so doing it established a single line of ministerial and parliamentary responsibility for companies and securities regulation consistent with the fundamental principles of parliamentary democracy on which our society is founded.

Sole responsibility for the administration of those laws was conferred on a new national regulatory authority, the Australian Securities Commission, under the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989.

It is now a matter of history that the validity of the corporations legislation was challenged in the High Court by some States and that the High Court earlier this year decided, on the basis of a strict interpretation of section 51 (xx) of the Constitution, that the Commonwealth could not legislate with respect to the act of incorporation of trading and financial corporations.

That decision did not, however, reflect upon the capacity of the Commonwealth Parliament to exercise its plenary legislative power with respect to the governance and activities of such bodies after the formal act of incorporation.

The decision of the High Court did nothing, Mr President, to diminish the resolve of the Government to proceed on a national basis with the much needed reforms enshrined in the Corporations Act and the Australian Securities Commission Act. Events that had unfolded in corporate Australia between the introduction of that legislation in 1988 and the handing down of the High Court decision had provided further dramatic emphasis to the urgent need for the Government's proposed national regulatory regime.

The Government accordingly sought urgent negotiations with the States and the Northern Territory with a view to gaining Australia-wide agreement for a scheme of national regulation which, while based on the Corporations Act 1989, would give due recognition to the constitutional role of the States in relation to the incorporation of trading and financial corporations.

Negotiations in the months following the March general elections led to the conclusion at Alice Springs on 29 June 1990 of Heads of Agreement between Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Ministers on future corporate regulation in Australia.
The matters agreed in those Heads of Agreement are translated into the scheme to which the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill gives effect.

At the heart of the agreement between Governments lies, on the one hand, a recognition by the States and the Northern Territory of the need for a national Corporations Law, administered by a single regulator responsible to a single Minister, Government and Parliament and, on the other hand, a recognition by the Commonwealth of the constitutional power of the States in relation to incorporation, and the interests of the States and the Northern Territory in the formulation of company law and the maintenance of satisfactory levels of regional service.
The Heads of Agreement and the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill strike a balance between those various interests in the following ways.

The need to take account of the decision of the High Court in the Corporations Case, and to avoid any possible future constitutional uncertainties in relation to the new national legislation, are taken account of by resort to an application of laws regime broadly similar to that underpinning the current co-operative scheme legislation.

Under that framework, the Bill converts the Corporations Act 1989 into a law under section 122 of the Constitution for the Government of the Australian Capital Territory to be known as the Corporations Law of the Capital Territory.

The Corporations Law will then be applied by State and Northern Territory Application of Laws Acts as the Corporations Law of each of those jurisdictions. In this way a single national Corporations Law will be enacted throughout Australia.

Under the Heads of Agreement, Governments are to seek the passage of the necessary legislation through their respective Parliaments in time to enable the new national scheme to commence on 1 January 1991.

While the application of laws regime will ensure that the new scheme, like its predecessor, is based on State and Territory law, the way in which that regime addresses issues of regulation, investigation and enforcement is fundamentally different.

In the first place the separate roles of the State and Territory Corporate Affairs Commissions as delegates of a central coordinating agency, currently the National Companies and Securities Commission, will be replaced by the conferment of sole administrative and regulatory authority on the Australian Securities Commission. The Commission in turn will be responsible to a Commonwealth Minister and the Commonwealth Parliament. This is to be achieved by amendments of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 and the conferment of corresponding powers, functions and responsibilities on the Australian Securities Commission under State and Northern Territory law by the various State and Northern Territory Application of Laws Acts.

The legislative regime will also greatly streamline and simplify the investigation and enforcement of offences under the Corporations Law as in force in each jurisdiction. This will be achieved by the adoption of a novel legislative device whose effect will, in summary, be to `federalise' such offences.

The federalising technique will involve each State and the Northern Territory providing in its Application of Laws legislation for the application to the investigation, prosecution and enforcement of offences under its Corporations Law of the provisions of relevant Commonwealth laws to the exclusion of State and Territory laws. One effect will be to confer investigatory, prosecutorial and other associated powers on the relevant Commonwealth authorities and officers to the exclusion of the corresponding State authorities and officers. Provision will be made for such powers to continue to be exercised by State authorities and officers in circumstances where arrangements are put in place between the Commonwealth and the relevant State or Territory government to enable the most efficient and effective use to be made of resources.
Thus, for all practical purposes, offences under the Corporations Law of each jurisdiction will be treated as if they were offences under Commonwealth law.

The same `federalising' technique will also be adopted by State and Northern Territory Application of Laws Acts to ensure that Commonwealth laws relating to freedom of information and judicial and administrative review of decisions of regulatory authorities under the Corporations Law apply to decisions under the Corporations Law to the exclusion of State administrative law regimes. Commonwealth judicial and other authorities and officers will exercise their powers under those laws to the exclusion of any corresponding powers conferred on State authorities and officers.

The exercise of jurisdiction by the courts of the States, the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory and the Federal Court will similarly be the subject of a special legislative regime to give effect to the intention of Governments that the new scheme have, so far as is practicable, the characteristics of a single national law.

Parallel civil jurisdiction under the Corporations Law will be conferred on the Supreme Courts of each State, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, and the Federal Court of Australia.
This important outcome of the Agreement between Governments will ensure freedom of choice to litigants between a local Supreme Court and the Federal Court.

The national character of the jurisdictional arrangements will be achieved by the cross-vesting of civil jurisdiction between the several State and Territory Supreme Courts and the Federal Court. In this way, the relevant State or Territory Supreme Court, or the Federal Court, Will be able to be seized of all litigation relating to a particular matter irrespective of the particular State or Territory jurisdictions in which the various associated causes of action arose. As part of the crossvesting mechanism, courts will have the discretion to transfer matters to other courts where it is in the interests of justice to do so.

Consistently with the `federalising' of the investigation and prosecution of offences under the Corporations Laws, criminal law jurisdiction will be exercisable exclusively by the relevant State, Australian Capital Territory and Northern Territory courts in much the same way as offences under Commonwealth laws are, under the Judiciary Act, tried by State and Territory courts.

This will be achieved by the cross-vesting of the relevant State and Territory courts with jurisdiction to deal with offences under the Corporations Law of each other jurisdiction. No territorial limit will be placed on the jurisdiction of those courts to deal with indictable offences where those offences are alleged to have been committed either outside Australia or under the Corporations Law of the relevant State or Territory.

To avoid the legal and practical difficulties that would be involved in providing for the transfer between jurisdictions of criminal proceedings in relation to indictable offences in other circumstances, the legislation will place some territorial limits on the matters that may be dealt with by the criminal courts of each jurisdiction. Under these provisions the courts of each jurisdiction will be limited in such cases to dealing with indictable offences that are alleged to have been committed, begun or completed within that jurisdiction.

These provisions will, notwithstanding those necessary limitations, nevertheless provide considerable scope and convenience for a court in one jurisdiction to deal with associated offences that involve one or more other jurisdictions in addition to that jurisdiction.

The courts of all States and the two mainland Territories will have full cross-vested criminal jurisdiction without limitation as to locality in respect of summary offences under the Corporations Law of each jurisdiction in the same way as those courts may exercise summary jurisdiction under the Judiciary Act in respect of summary offences under Commonwealth law wherever committed.

Decisions of State and Territory courts exercising civil and criminal jurisdiction, and the Federal Court exercising civil jurisdiction, under a Corporations Law will be subject to the same hierarchy of appeals as with other matters ordinarily dealt with by those courts.

There are a number of other respects in which the Bill will introduce legislative mechanisms and requirements to ensure that the Corporations Laws of all jurisdictions together form a single national regime.

For example, the Bill and the State and Territory Application of Laws Acts will establish a regime for the citation of the Corporations Laws of each jurisdiction that will enable a simple reference in any instrument to the `Corporations Law', without more, to suffice, as a matter of law, as a reference to the Corporations Law of the relevant jurisdiction, or to two or more such laws, as the case requires. This will add simplicity and legal certainty to such things as documents filed with or issued by the Australian Securities Commission and indictments, pleadings and orders filed in or issued by courts exercising cross-vested jurisdiction under the national scheme.

Of special importance is the way in which the new regime will deal with the matter of incorporation. As a consequence of the decision of the High Court in the Corporations Case the incorporation of companies will continue, as a matter of constitutional necessity, to be rooted in the Corporations Law of a particular jurisdiction. That apart, the Corporations Law of each jurisdiction will, for most purposes of companies and securities regulation, treat companies incorporated in other Australian jurisdictions in the same way as companies incorporated in that jurisdiction.

At the practical level, incorporators will be able to seek incorporation under the Corporations Law of a nominated jurisdiction by filing the necessary documentation at any ASC office in Australia. Moreover, the legislation will enable filing and other obligations of an Australian incorporated company under any one or more Corporations Laws to be fully discharged under all of those laws by complying with the obligation in any one Australian jurisdiction.

There will, however, be one area of regulation in which existing differences from jurisdiction to jurisdiction will be preserved for the time being. This is the area that can be broadly termed `fund- raising' by the Crown in right of a State or Territory, by State and Territory public authorities, by other local statutory bodies and by special classes of corporations such as building societies, cooperatives, credit unions and friendly societies.

Although there has been no suggestion amongst Governments that the incorporation or governance of such bodies should come within the new national scheme, there is a significant body of opinion, with which the Commonwealth is in agreement, that a single national fundraising regime should apply to most such bodies when they seek to raise funds outside their own jurisdictions of establishment or incorporation.

Generally, the State and Northern Territory Governments also recognise the need for reforms in that direction. The limited time available for the negotiation of the Heads of Agreement has not, however, enabled the implications of any reform in this area to be fully worked through by the State and Northern Territory Governments.

It has accordingly been agreed, and this is reflected in the legislation, that the status quo of the provisions of the cooperative scheme legislation should be continued on in the Corporations Law in relation to such bodies. This agreement has been reached on the understanding that the extent to which the new law should apply to those bodies will be reviewed by Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Ministers as a matter of priority following the commencement of the new national scheme.

The respective roles of the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory in the future reform of companies and securities laws is a matter which has formed an important part in the negotiations between Governments leading to the introduction of the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill. Governments have agreed that the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities established under the Formal Agreement relating to the cooperative scheme should continue in operation under the new national scheme, but with a redefined role and under the Chairmanship of the Commonwealth Minister.

To that end a new Formal Agreement for signature by Heads of Government is currently under preparation. When that Agreement has been signed, the Government will seek to have it annexed to the corporations legislation.

In relation to the future reform process, it has been agreed that the Ministerial Council will have a consultative role in respect of all legislative proposals and a deliberative role in relation to the reform of what can be broadly described as company law matters. Takeovers, securities, public fundraising and futures will be pre-eminently matters for the Commonwealth, subject to the general consultative role of the Ministerial Council. The Commonwealth will have four votes and a casting vote in the Ministerial Council; each State and the Northern Territory will have one vote.
Importantly, the concurrence of the Commonwealth will be required for the introduction of any company law reform proposal.

I have already mentioned the importance to the States and Northern Territory of the maintenance by the Australian Securities Commission of regional levels of service. To this end, a number of commitments undertaken by the Commonwealth in the Heads of Agreement will be inscribed also in the new Formal Agreement. For its part, the Government believes that levels of service in each jurisdiction will be significantly enhanced, especially having regard to the establishment by the Australian Securities Commission of a national data base for companies and a state of the art document imaging system.

The Commonwealth has also agreed that Regional Commissioners of the ASC should be appointed by contract outside the framework of the Commonwealth Public Service Act and that the State and Northern Territory Ministers should be consulted in respect of such appointments. The Bill amends the Australian Securities Commission Act to provide for such appointments by contract. The Commonwealth's obligation to consult with the State and Northern Territory Ministers on these appointments will be amongst the provisions of the new Formal Agreement.

One of the matters of considerable importance to State and Northern Territory Governments in agreeing to the new national scheme has been their desire to preserve their capacity to levy stamp duty on share transactions and charges.

To meet these concerns the Commonwealth has agreed to the inclusion in each Corporations Law of provisions that will ensure, in combination with local stamp duty laws, that State and Territory stamp duties are leviable on off-market transactions in the securities of companies incorporated in their respective jurisdictions and that charges wherever registered have been stamped in all jurisdictions in which property secured by them is located.

As a result of the agreement between Governments for the new national scheme, State and Northern Territory Governments will forego revenue currently received in respect of companies and securities regulation. Under the Heads of Agreement the Commonwealth has agreed to reimburse the States and the Northern Territory to the extent of $102m per annum indexed in line with the consumer price index from a 1989/1990 base. An interim formula has been agreed in respect of revenue foregone in 1990-91 and is reflected in the Budget presented to the Parliament.
The detailed arrangements for revenue reimbursement will be included in the new Formal Agreement currently under preparation.

Mr President, I have already emphasised this Government's grave concern at recent developments in the corporate sector. But our concerns will not end with the passage of this Bill and the associated State and Northern Territory Application of Laws Acts. The Government has a substantial and growing agenda of matters requiring urgent legislative reform-I mention loans to directors and the recently endorsed recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on insider trading, as but two examples.
These and other matters will be the subject of legislative proposals that the Government intends to bring forward to the Parliament next year.

In the meantime the Government is taking the opportunity afforded by this Bill to introduce, in addition to amendments necessary to give effect to the matters recently agreed by Governments, reforms that will give effect to matters on which agreement has previously been reached in the context of the co-operative scheme.

Accordingly, the Bill will include in the Corporations Law provisions on buy-backs that correspond to those included in the co-operative scheme legislation subsequent to the enactment of the Corporations Act, and various amendments necessary to take account of fast moving improvements in technology related to a national corporate information system.

The Bill also deals with a range of transitional matters. These include provisions giving effect to the agreement of Ministers that, from the date of commencement of the new national scheme, the Commonwealth will assume responsibility for the investigation and enforcement of co-operative scheme offences.

The opportunity is also being taken to make some technical revisions to provisions of the Corporations Act that are in need of correction or clarification. One such amendment will put beyond doubt the capacity of the Australian Securities Commission, in the course of an investigation or legal proceedings, to seek a court order for the protection, or the appointment of a receiver, of the property of a unit trust.

Mr President, the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill and the State Application of Laws legislation will together usher in a new era of corporate regulation in this country. The national scheme embodied in that legislative package will offer for the first time in the nation's history a single and truly national regulatory regime that can guarantee a sound and well-regulated environment for corporate activity. Without such an environment, business in this country cannot prosper as it should and investors, both at home and abroad, will lack the security and confidence that is essential to our future economic growth and well-being.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
Mr President, I commend the Bill to the Senate.
EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1990

This Bill amends the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974 to implement the amendments to the Export Market Development Grant Scheme (EMDGS) announced by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce on 28 February 1990. In accordance with that announcement, these amendments will be made retrospective to 1 July 1990.

The EMDGS was set up nearly twenty years ago to support the efforts of Australia's small to medium-sized companies in entering and developing export markets. The Scheme provides financial incentives in the form of taxable cash grants for eligible expenditure incurred on overseas market research and development.

Honourable Senators will be well aware that the Government is concerned to ensure that public funds in all areas are used in a cost-effective manner. Further, as regards export incentives, the Government is committed to ensuring that the expenditure of such public funds results in an improvement in sustained export performance. It is mindful that the EMDG Scheme is an incentive scheme to encourage Australian exporters to seek out and develop overseas markets and not a subsidy for industry.

With this background and a scheduled termination date for the EMDG Scheme of 30 June 1990, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce decided to initiate a comprehensive review of the EMDG and related schemes. The purpose of this review was to assess the schemes' effectiveness against their original objectives and the Government's aim to encourage a more outward looking and internationally competitive Australian industry which can contribute to improving Australia's balance of payments position.

To undertake this review, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce appointed a Committee in December 1988, chaired by Professor Helen Hughes, to review Export Market Development Assistance. The Committee also included Mr John Carden, Executive Director of CRA Ltd; MrAndrew Gisham, Director of Vision Systems Ltd; and Mr Bill Mansfield, Assistant Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The Committee Secretariat was provided by officers of the Bureau of Industry Economics and the Australian Trade Commission (AUSTRADE).
The Hughes Committee presented its report to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce in July 1989.

The Government appreciates the work undertaken by the Committee in comprehensively analysing the current system of Government support for exporters and its strengths and weaknesses. The Committee also addressed, in a constructive way, wider issues, including the economic environment and the pace of reform. I take this opportunity to thank Professor Hughes and the other members of the Committee for their thorough report.

There are, therefore, two distinct but interdependent themes to the Committee's Report. The first addresses export incentives, in particular the EMDGS and the new discretionary International Trade Enhancement Scheme (ITES). The second theme addresses the wider economic policy environment and overall trade competitiveness.

The Committee recommended the extension of a modified open access export grants scheme for a further five years and the introduction of a selective incentive scheme for firms or industry groups that have overcome the initial difficulties of exporting and are ready for a major export effort.
It is against this background that this Bill introduces legislation to continue the Export Market Development Grants Scheme (EMDGS) for a further five years to 30 June 1995.
Let me now outline the major changes that are being introduced in this Bill.

In February this year the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce jointly released the Government's decision on the Hughes Committee Report. The Government agreed with the Committee on most of its proposed refinements to the Scheme.

In particular, exporters will graduate from the Scheme after receiving eight incentive payments; the grant rate will be reduced from 70 to 50 per cent of the eligible expenditure; the maximum grant payment will increase from $200 000 to $250 000 with an export ceiling of $25 million; and there will be a new minimum expenditure threshold.

The expenditure threshold, however, has only been raised from $10 000 to $30 000 (with expenditure after the first $15 000 being eligible for reimbursement) as opposed to the $50 000 threshold recommended by the Review Committee. Such a large increase would have excluded too many promising smaller exporters.
The effect of some of these changes to the Scheme would be to deny access to a number of smaller exporters and also to those exporters who have used the Scheme for more than eight years.
Turning first to smaller exporters, the Government appreciated that, in some cases, further support will be necessary.

Accordingly, the Government has proposed changes to the EMDGS that are designed to benefit those small and medium-sized firms that are endeavouring to develop and expand export markets but lack the critical mass to be truly competitive.

The EMDGS has been specifically structured to encourage smaller firms to collaborate more either among themselves or with larger firms. Joint ventures and consortia will be able to claim grants in their own right, provided they meet certain criteria, and will not inherit any previous claims history of their individual members. In addition, a new category of claimants-approved trading bodies-has been created to encourage trading houses to export the products of smaller Australian firms which, whilst they have competitive products, do not have the resources and/or know-how to successfully export. Small exporters will therefore have a better chance of Government support where they are prepared to work with other firms.

Turning now to the firms excluded by the eight year cutoff, the Government's decision to limit claims to eight was based on the well documented evidence that EMDG recipients' efforts to develop new markets reach a plateau after eight years and that only a few firms continued to open new markets after the eight year cutoff. Furthermore, the majority of the firms excluded are large firms with considerable expertise in exporting.

In some cases, however, the Government appreciates that additional support may be required for those eight year exporters who are proposing to enter completely new markets or launch entirely new products. Partly with this in mind, the Government agreed with the Hughes Committee's recommendation to establish a new discretionary scheme-the International Trade Enhancement Scheme (ITES). I say `partly' because we anticipate the four year Scheme having a far broader impact.

For a start, the ITES will replace to some extent the International Business Development Scheme and the High Technology Exporters Scheme. In addition, it will support new and more innovative approaches by Australian exporters. The Government is particularly interested in seeing the Scheme used to encourage collaboration by smaller companies through consortia and industry associations.

Apart from some streamlining, a broadening of the definition of eligible services to include inbound tourist operators and legal and health services, and giving access to trading houses, joint ventures and consortiums of small companies, the administrative guidelines of the EMDGS will not substantially change from those that now apply. The Scheme is estimated to cost $134 million dollars but given the one year delay in payments, the first budget year for the Scheme will be 1991/1992.

In the February announcement, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce foreshadowed that amendments to the EMDG Act arising out of the Government's adoption of the Hughes Committee's recommendations would operate from 1 July 1990.

The need to consult widely with interested bodies about the precise nature of the new provisions required in a revised EMDG Act to give effect to the Government's decision precluded the required substantive amendments to the EMDG Act being brought forward in the last Parliamentary Sittings.

The Government wanted to ensure that all possible views were taken into account so that the best possible framework, within the limits of the Government's decision, was implemented in respect of the revised Scheme.

Accordingly, the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Act 1990 was passed during the Autumn Sittings as an interim measure to preserve the continuity of the EMDG Act from 1 July 1990 to 31 December 1990.

In accordance with the announcement of February and to limit any confusion for EMDGS recipients, amendments to the EMDG Act will be made retrospective to 1 July 1990. Exporters have been fully appraised of the Government's intention to make such amendments retrospective. To do otherwise at this stage would create needless confusion and uncertainty.

Turning to the other side of the Hughes Committee's equation-economic reform-much of what the Committee has recommended is consistent with the reform agenda of the Government. At the same time, it is always of value to have additional and informed comment on reform priorities and how these should be addressed in both macro economic and micro economic areas. The Committee's proposals are being considered in this broader picture.

Over the past year, two other major reports have examined aspects of Australia's competitiveness and export future-the Garnaut report ``Australia and the Northeast Asian Ascendancy'' and the study of ``Australian Manufacturing in the 1990s'' for the Australian Manufacturing Council. While the differences between the reports-Hughes, Garnaut and the AMC-remain important, the three reports embody a large agreed agenda for reform, including an issue which goes to the core of the whole export question. It is one which this Government regards as critical to the trade related area. We have not in this country, at least not in the manufacturing and services sector, developed a true export culture. The Hughes Committee and the AMC report found that in the wider community and business alike there is a poor grasp of the drive, commitment and risk involved in succeeding on world markets; in being world competitive.

The Government wants to take what action it can to inculcate such a culture. For the present, the revised EMDGS and the new International Trade Enhancement Scheme (ITES) will contribute to this process. Education in export management has been given specific encouragement under the EMDGS, as have industry associations under the ITES, while smaller exporters, as I have already highlighted, will now have a better chance of Government support where they are prepared to work with other firms.

The Government appreciates that these measures will not change our national attitude to exporting overnight. The Government can do more and it will be looking for new ways to pursue this important objective.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill and the Export Market Development Grants Amendment (No. 2) Bill be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.

WOOL TAX (NOS 1-5) FURTHER AMENDMENT BILLS 1990
These Bills will make a number of amendments to the Wool Tax Acts (Nos 1-5) 1964.
The maximum rate of wool tax that may be imposed under each Act is increased from 20 per cent to 30 per cent.

An operational rate of wool tax lower than the maximum rate may be set by regulation. The existing operational rate at which wool tax is imposed is increased from 18 per cent to 25 per cent by these Bills.
A third measure contained in the Bills is a reduction in the rate of tax on carpet wool from 18 per cent to 3.85 per cent.
These changes are effective from 4 October 1990.

Finally the Bills make provision for the introduction of a wool tax surcharge. If it is necessary to impose the surcharge, the amendments provide for it to apply from a date to be prescribed by regulation and that it not exceed a rate of 20 per cent.
A more detailed explanation of the provisions of these Bills is also contained in the Explanatory Memorandum that accompanies this package of Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters says `his decision', but the first step is for the Minister to receive an opinion from the Attorney-General's Department as to the application of section 29 (5) of the principal Act. Until that is received, it is not clear that the Minister would have to make a decision at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I turn now to the National Bioethics Consultative Committee (NBCC) and refer to a reservation that was made in the Committee's report in relation to, I think, program 6. I will be brief. The questions that I placed on notice have been answered by the Department. They were obviously answered subsequent to the Committee meeting. As the Minister is aware, the NBCC has considered the question of surrogacy. The majority of the Committee supported surrogacy and indicated that there should be legislation which permits surrogacy in certain circumstances. I am going to the question of why the NBCC was established. The Minister will recall that then Senator Ryan, in responding in 1987 to the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation, pointed to an alleged attitude of the States as a reason for not adopting the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: The States are not inclined to support a uniform prohibitive approach.
When dealing with the question of the prohibition of the structure of non-therapeutic experimentation Senator Ryan is reported at page 3484 of Hansard to have said:

The matter will be kept under review and the Government will further consider it in the light of experience and any evidence received from the National Bioethics Consultative Committee which the Government proposes to establish and which I now turn to.

On the same page, she was reported to have said that the cooperation of the States and Territories with such a body was vital `in order to achieve a national uniform approach on bioethical issues'. In respect of human embryo experimentation, the response by Senator Ryan clearly meant that a uniform approach would be undertaken, but only if it allowed for destructive human embryo experimentation. There is really no other interpretation that one might be able to put on that. Senator Ryan said that the National Bioethics Consultative Committee would be established because the States were not inclined to support a uniform prohibitive approach. Exactly the opposite has happened with surrogacy-all of the States, without exception, were against it; all of them wanted a prohibitive approach.

The new National Bioethics Consultative Committee, established to get some sort of uniform approach to a particular bioethical question, is making its first recommendation about a major public policy, namely, surrogacy, and it takes a view that is absolutely contrary to the uniform approach already adopted by all the States-in fact, contrary to legislation in some of the States.

What concerns me is that here we are voting money to this outfit-the National Bioethics Consultative Committee-which is currently going about the process of trying to impose its views on all the States so that surrogacy can be approved. That is clear from the fact that it has proceeded to propose certain uniform legislation. I know that the response will be that a working party will be established by the States over this matter. But who will service the working party? It will be the National Bioethics Consultative Committee.

I ask the Minister: is that a proper means of going about things? I believe that it is entirely inappropriate to in effect have this outfit trying to dictate terms to State governments on this matter. Is this not ironic, in view of the fact that the Senate Select Committee came up with a recommendation that was supported by persons from all parties, with two dissentients from one? Members from the Liberal Party and the Australian Democrats, and the Chairman, Senator Tate, and I supported a recommendation that there be a prohibition against destructive human embryo experimentation. The then Minister said, `Because there is no uniform approach in the States, we will set up the Bioethics Commission to have a look at all of these matters'. And the first thing that the Bioethics Committee does is to come down with a recommendation contrary not only to the uniform approach adopted by every State but also to the findings of committee after committee, including the findings of the Family Law Council and the findings of the Victorian Waller Committee. The Waller Committee came to the following conclusion:
. . . surrogate mother arrangements where fees are paid are, in reality, arrangements for the purchase of a child and should not be countenanced.

That matter was dealt with by the National Bioethics Consultative Committee-I admit that-but, importantly, the Committee had grave doubts whether any altruistic arrangements could be in the best interests of the child. The whole point about it is `the best interests of the child'.

One of my concerns in regard to the question of the rights of the child is that the basic right of the child to knowledge of its own genetic identity is now being denied in many areas of reproductive technology by official deceit. That is a question that we, as a chamber, should be concerned about. Some of these children are going to grow up asking, `Who was my father? Where do I come from?'. `Oh', one replies, `Those records have been destroyed. I cannot tell you that'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes those who are conceived naturally do not know who their father is.

—I hope that, by that interjection, Senator Patterson does not mean that there should be some cover-up in reproductive technology-some constant cover-up as is occurring now about the genetic identity of the parents of the children. That is what is happening now. I am sure that Senator Patterson, by her interjection, did not mean that.
—I did not mean that at all.

—Of course not. But it is a question that we need to address at some stage. My worry is that we are throwing money at the National Bioethics Consultative Committee when we, as a parliament, ought to be having a good look at what this body is doing and how, once it establishes its decision, it goes about trying to push these ideas onto the States, using the resources supplied by us to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I note from the responses to my questions that the National Bioethics Committee is going into the question of selective embryo reduction. That is a euphemistic term for the abortion of some unborn children in a multi-pregnancy situation. Who has been chosen to do that bioethical study? It is to be done by Dr David Healy, a pro-abortionist. In fact, he is the one who wants to do the trials in Australia with the drug RU486. These are the types of people that we are paying money to through the National Bioethics Committee. We should be very concerned about that.

Finally, I refer to the Department's response to questions that I had on notice. I asked whether Mr Russell Scott or his firm have consultancies which may raise issues of conflict of interest with his membership of the Medical Research Ethics Committee (MREC). I do not think the Department's response to this was up to standard. However, I must place on record my appreciation of the responses from the Department. We might not like the answers that we get. But we are not here to argue that question; we are here just to get the answers. I would like a further response listing the consultancies of Russell Scott and his firm in relation to the areas which involve consideration of bioethics.

I think it is important that we have that because that person is still on the Medical Research Ethics Committee and his views on the question of destructive experimentation on human embryos are quite well known. It is fair to provide an answer which is a bit more than `The Department is unaware of any conflict of interest in this case'. The Department might be unaware: that might be a factual statement. But the Department should make itself aware as to what the consultancies are and it should obtain a list of them so that they are publicly on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the general points that Senator Harradine made concerning the National Bioethics Consultative Committee are not matters that I need to respond to specifically except to acknowledge that, in the end, it is for those who are elected by the people in the various jurisdictions, either nationwide or in the States or Territories, to take final responsibility for these major decisions. I certainly do not believe that they should be pre-empted, or thought to be pre-empted, by a consultative committee, however eminent it might be. There is a very necessary role for elected parliaments and governments to take the hard decisions and not constantly leave them to the consideration of committees.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the further question of Mr Russell Scott is concerned, I understand that an inquiry was made as to any consultancies and only one consultancy was noted which in any way had anything to do with the sorts of areas that are of concern. I understand from the officials that that consultancy did not lead them to consider that there was any conflict whatsoever. But I will take further the question of whether there is any possibility of that consultancy being publicly made known. I do not know whether there are any difficulties relating to legal professional privilege as to with whom he has a consultancy. All I can say at the moment is that I understand the consultancy was looked at and that conclusion was made on the basis of an examination of that consultancy rather than just accepting the word of Mr Russell Scott.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask about Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits information. I asked a large number of questions on notice regarding classes of records held by the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) and the Department of Community Services and Health. I must put on record here my appreciation of the Department for answering those questions: there were a large number. I am not asking them just for the sake of being difficult; I have a specific purpose for doing so. Despite the fact that the Department did give me a large number of answers, there are some areas that I still have queries about. In fact, some of them were a bit shorthandish and I think they need expanding. The Health Insurance Commission in its answer to my 11 questions about each class of record stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of Questions 1 to 5, 7, 8, and 10, the answers are contained in the entry in the Personal Information Digest for each class of record. I refer the Honourable Senator to the individual entries in the Digest for each class of record. In respect of Questions 6, 9 and 11 the following answers are provided in respect of each class of record.

Included in the classes of records on which this restriction was placed were nine classes of pharmaceutical related records which did not appear in the personal information digest. Both the HIC and the Department were made well aware in the Estimates that these records were not included in the personal information digest.

I ask the Health Insurance Commission and/or the Department of Community Services and Health to answer my questions Nos 1 to 5, 7, 8 and 10 about these classes of records as soon as possible. I do not expect the answers now, but I want to put this on the record so that I obtain them in due course. I would appreciate an answer as soon as possible to satisfy the purposes for which I require this information.

I also ask the Health Insurance Commission and the Department to provide me with a reason for these classes of records not being included in the Personal Information Digest. Maybe it was because the pharmaceutical benefits scheme was being transferred across. I think there should be some explanation as to why that did not appear in the Personal Information Digest. In relation to all the classes of records about which I asked the eleven questions, I noted that the Personal Information Digest does not provide the information that the Health Insurance Commission and the Department claims that it does-and this is where I talk about the shorthanded nature of the answer.

I ask that further information be provided in regard to my questions. The answer to my first question-What information is held in this class of record?-does not coincide with the Digest's statement that `content may include'. The answer to my second question-What information would have to be removed from this class of record to ensure that no individual could be identified?-does not coincide with the information in the Digest, which says, `Sensitive content may include'. I am asking for specific answers to my questions and the Digest does not give me those answers. The answers in respect of my questions 3, 4 and 5, asking for all of the uses of the classes of the records, does not coincide with the Digest's statement that `the purpose of these records are'. Finally, my questions 7 and 8, asking whether any of the information is transferred within the agency or integrated with other classes of records held by the agency, were not answered by the Privacy Commission.

I do not want to hold up the chamber and I appreciate that those answers will not be able to be provided for me on the spot. However, I ask the Minister to give me some assurance that those questions will be answered by the Department as soon as possible.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for Senator Patterson's recognition of the considerable work undertaken by the Department of Community Services and Health and by the Health Insurance Commission in order to attempt to answer her questions. In so far as they have proved inadequate for the purpose which Senator Patterson has not revealed, I am afraid that they may hold something bad in store for the Government.
