Nevertheless, we will assist because we always try to provide the fullest information from this Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: -The information I require does not hold something in store for the Government. We should again put on the public record that I was quite concerned, when I asked a question at the Estimates in April either this year or last year as to how long Medicare data would be stored for, to be told that it has been stored since the inception of Medicare. The Australian public ought to be aware of that. I want to know exactly how data is stored, what data is stored and what classes of data are stored.

SPEECH.PARA: All this matter relates to is something which has grown up. The Department said to me that it was developing a data retention policy. It admitted at that Estimates Committee that it was developing a policy because I had asked the questions. Whatever happens will not be able to be claimed to be a Government initiative; it will be because the Opposition asked questions about the retention of data, and very rightly so. Very sensitive data is still stored concerning every single Australian who has had any medical treatment and has received any medical benefit for that treatment. That needs to be addressed. This is not some flippant request for information that will not be used. It is to enable me to get a handle, as much as I can, on exactly what information is stored. It is appropriate for me, as a representative of the citizens of Australia, to seek that information when there is such extensive and pervasive data on our health and health records.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate that I have received answers to the other matters about which I had reservations. I might not like them, but it is not the point to press the issues here. One could make certain points relating to payments to family planning associations and so forth, but that can be done in another arena.

-I move to the question of funding of hostel accommodation. On page C494 of the Estimates Committee C Hansard for 12 October I was told that the Government's estimate of the cost of a hostel place is $53,000. How was this benchmark figure reached and does it take into account costs such as architectural and consultant fees and planning costs and land costs?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the cost of a place at a hostel is said to be about $53,000 per annum. If I understand Senator Patterson correctly, she is asking whether that incorporates an attempt to amortise the architectural and building costs over time. I am informed that it does include those costs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: -On page 495 of the Estimates Committee C Hansard for 13 October, in relation to the percentage of funding from the Commonwealth for hostel funding, I asked which organisations received 100 per cent funding. It was stated that only Aboriginal organisations received 100 per cent funding for the building of hostel accommodation. The only doubt that existed in the mind of Ms Murnane from the Department was that some organisations may still be operating under the old $2 for $1 provision.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I have been informed that Wintringham Ltd has received 100 per cent funding for the building of its new facilities at Williamstown and Flemington. I understand that that information may not be correct-I stand to be corrected; that is the information I have received. I am told that this information was confirmed by Minister Staples at the Wintringham annual meeting quite recently. I have also been told that the Wesley Central Mission recently was granted 100 per cent funding for a hostel in the western suburbs. I want to know whether that information is correct because it does not fit with what the Department said in Estimates.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officer wants to have recourse to the departmental files to check on that matter. We will provide an accurate answer.

-I appreciate that but I would like the information as soon as possible. If those two organisations have received 100 per cent funding-they are ones that I have heard about; I do not know how many others have-it does not fit well with the answer I received on 12 October. A number of people who are developing hostels in Victoria are particularly interested in this question. I would appreciate an answer as quickly as possible.
—I have undertaken to get that answer. It may be within a few minutes or perhaps after Question Time.

—The other question I would like answered-maybe the Department cannot provide this on the spot, but I would appreciate it as soon as possible-relates to the number of new hostel places that have been approved in the last three financial years. How many of the bed approvals have been taken up to the point where we have residents in beds? I know that there will be a delay factor, but I would like some picture from the Department of the hostel bed approvals and the taking up of those approvals in a form where hospital beds are in existence. I realise that the officers will not be able to answer immediately, but I would like my questions put on the record and I would appreciate an answer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will provide that.

—On 21 September during the Estimates I asked whether any discussion had been contemplated or commenced with foreign governments about the inclusion of addiction studies and clinical skills in overseas universities. The subsequent answer provided by the Department of Community Services and Health did not address the `contemplated' section of the question. I therefore ask the Department whether the Government intends having discussions with the Government of New Zealand or any other foreign government about the inclusion of addiction studies and clinical skills components of the MBBS courses.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; I do not have an officer here who can say whether those discussions are envisaged, intended or even thought about, whatever contemplation might mean. But if indeed there is a definite program in mind to undertake such consultations, we will let Senator Walters know.
—Could the Minister let me know not only `if' but also `whether or not'.
—Yes.

—The working party to review the Australian Medical Council examinations interim report of May 1990 gives some figures for the success rates of some foreign trained doctors wishing to gain registration to practise as doctors in Australia. How many times are unsuccessful candidates at the Medical Council qualifications and clinical examinations permitted to sit exams?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Walters had let us know about this question I would have ensured that somebody was here who could deal with it. I take it that she wants an answer to the question so I certainly undertake to provide it. It is a simple enough question.

—To save time I will hand the Minister the other questions as I have a few others along the same lines. As my original question during Estimates had not been answered properly, I thought that there might be someone here who could answer it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Not to let Senator Walters get away with it entirely, I wrote to her asking whether she had received unsatisfactory and inadequate answers to any matters which she would want to follow up in the Committee of the Whole. I do not think I received a response to my courteous letter to her.

—I refer to the employment of people with disabilities. In the Estimates Committee we asked about the recommendations of the Labour and Disability Workforce Consultancy discussion paper `National Employment Initiatives for People with Disabilities'. We asked what recommendations would be instigated by the Department. We did not seem to get an answer. Could we have the answer as to what recommendations would be instigated by the Department?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Patterson says that the Government's attitude to the recommendations has not been properly indicated to her. I will try to provide a response, if the Government has come to a conclusion in regard to all those recommendations. It may be that it is still awaiting the decision-making process to reach its culmination. If decisions have been made by way of response at the proper levels, we will provide those responses to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We asked a number of questions about the difficulties that we believed disabled people were having in obtaining employment in the public sector. If one goes out into the community, as I do as a senator travelling around the State, one gets information that sometimes is not as easily obtained as when one is here in Canberra. As I have moved around the State talking to people who are trying to implement the Government's program of moving disabled people from sheltered workshops into open employment, I have seen the problem that has occurred, particularly in some of the larger regional centres of Victoria. They have found great difficulty in placing people in public sector employment. All of us agree that if the Government has a policy of moving people into open employment, it is important that that occur for those who are able to be employed in open employment.

SPEECH.PARA: As I move around, these people tell me that it is very difficult. Because of the very few public sector jobs, particularly the Commonwealth public sector jobs available in the regional and rural areas of Victoria and I presume other States as well, if the Government is not keeping up its side of employing a percentage of disabled people, it falls back on the private sector to bear the brunt of the implementation of the Government's policy. I asked a number of questions about how the program was going, particularly in relation to the public sector. In reply, Dr Harmer from the Department said:
From the Department's perspective we have been looking for the public sector also to adopt what we would call enlightened policies in relation to the employment of people with disabilities.
When I asked about a study he said:
I am not aware of any specific study the Department has done to target either public sector or private sector employment.
He then said:
We have had no complaints or criticisms to us about the difficulty that service providers are having in terms of getting access to public sector employers as compared with private sector employers.

Maybe the Department in Canberra has not had complaints but, as soon as I move anywhere near a sheltered workshop or any program where people are trying to get disabled people into open employment, I hear the problems they are having.

Dr Harmer then gave me an undertaking that he would look into the matter, although the additional information with which I was provided does not really constitute what I believe to be an adequate answer to our questions. On page 2,544 of the additional information it is stated:

A recent equal employment opportunities survey found that 6,676 people in the Australian Public Service were self-identified as having a disability. Seventy one per cent of the Australian Public Service did the survey and 7 per cent of the survey respondents reported a disability. Additionally, 20 people in the Australian Capital Territory are employed in the Australian Public Service under the intellectual disability access program. This program has not yet been implemented in the States.

Clearly, that was not adequate information. The sort of evidence that would allay my concerns about whether the public sector was achieving its goals would be if the Government had 30 per cent of public sector jobs and 70 per cent of private sector jobs in a regional centre-I am just plucking figures out of the air-we could expect 30 per cent of those disabled people in those regional areas to be in the public sector and 70 per cent in the private sector. We would be looking at a distribution that reflected the distribution of the sectors in that area. That is the kind of information that should be sought, even if it is only on a sample of some regional centres to see whether the policy is working.

It appears that my concerns about the lack of access to public service for the disabled have been vindicated. I was not privy to information-no one leaked a document to me-but not long after I asked the question the Public Service Commission launched the new strategy for the employment, retention and promotion of people with disabilities. During the launch, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) criticised the Public Service for allowing the employment of disabled people at the base grade level to fall from 5.2 per cent in 1986 to 3 per cent at present. At the very time when the Government has a program of employing disabled people, we see a decrease from 5.2 per cent to 3 per cent of disabled people in the Public Service. This does not say much about how efficient and how good the public sector has been in carrying out the Government's policy of open employment for disabled people.
The Canberra Times quoted Mr Howe as saying:
He said there was a clear need for action. The Government could not afford to accept a situation in Public Service inconsistent with that happening elsewhere.

This is the very concern that I was raising-that the private sector is being expected to bear the brunt of the Government's policy. There it is in the figures. The article, still quoting Mr Howe, continued:
More could and should be done by the service to redress it.
It was essential that people with disabilities had equal access to employment, to enable them to participate fully in their communities.
In the same article, the Acting Public Service Commissioner, Allan Kerr, was quoted as saying:
The time had come for a turn-around: the legislative framework was quite clear.

. . . legislative framework and government initiatives could be only part of the answer. Attitude was the other part, and proper attitudes in managers would be picked up by staff and translated to informed recruitment practices.

When I move around Victoria, I find that that is not happening in some of our Commonwealth statutory authorities and that some of them could offer employment in our regional and rural areas. But I hear comments such as, `We couldn't have someone with a handicap because they might cause an accident'. As I move around sheltered workshops I hear those comments reported by people trying to implement Government policies.

Does the Department have a breakdown of the employment of people with disabilities for individual government agencies since 1986? I would appreciate seeing that. That is the sort of information I was looking for, not some veiled answer. I was pleased to have what I was saying vindicated only a few days later in Mr Howe's launch.

Does the Department concede, because it did not concede in the Estimates Committee hearing, the relevance of my concerns about the relative difficulty that disabled people have in obtaining public sector employment? The excuse that was given to me was, `We haven't had any complaints'. But the figures tell the story. What proportion of finances provided to the disability services program is used to promote the employment of people with disabilities in the Public Service? Was the Department aware of the dropping percentage of base grade employment places in the Public Service which were being filled by people with disabilities? Does the Department agree that there is a need for better communication between individual departments and the Public Service Commission and the Department in relation to what efforts are being made to ensure equal access to employment by people with disabilities?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Patterson has raised the question of the employment of people with disabilities, both in the private and public sectors. She has quite correctly identified her concern that, if the Federal Government has a certain policy, then it should be reflected in its own employment practices. With such a formidable combination as the Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Brian Howe, and Senator Patterson the disabled in our community have very strong advocates and, given the coincidence of the expressions used by Senator Patterson and Mr Howe, I can assure Senator Patterson that her concerns are being put at the forefront of his considerations.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the specific questions-some three or four-seeking further figures, the Department will try to provide them. For example, we will provide a breakdown rather than a generalised Public Service-wide set of figures as to the number of people employed in particular departments or agencies self-identifying or having a disability. It may interest the honourable senator to know that in the Department of Community Services and Health some 218 officers-some 5 per cent-identified in that way as at 30 June 1990. I think that is quite a high figure.

TALK.START.PARA: —It ought to be the best Department. It ought to be setting the example.

—It is a surprising figure to me. Indeed, the Department has developed strategies to advance equal employment opportunities for people with disabilities, including participation in the trial of the intellectual disability access program, which the honourable senator mentioned. I understand that the Department currently employs two persons recruited under that particular program and is considering further placements under the program. There is also within the Department the development of a training package designed to facilitate the integration of people with disabilities into the work areas, and of course the Department supplies special equipment to enable those people with certain disabilities to participate in the work of various offices. I believe that this Department, and certainly the Minister, are taking the matters raised by Senator Patterson very seriously, and the general policy needs to be translated into specific results. Answers will be provided to Senator Patterson's other specific questions.

SPEECH.PARA: We have not been able to obtain an absolute answer in relation to the two hostels which Senator Patterson mentioned. She asked how, if a hostel is not provided for Aboriginal Australians, it could receive 100 per cent funding. The composition of the financially disadvantaged people in the region could lead to that particular situation occurring. I will get the specific answers for the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further questions on the Department of Community Services and Health. If not, we will move to the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

—I have five issues that I want to raise with the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I would like to start with the decision by the Department to transfer clients from the PACS system of alarms to the MSS system of alarms, starting from 23 November. Has this decision been predicated on cost alone? The group of people who are directly affected by this change are the old and the frail, and the daily contact offered by the PACS security alarm system is an important feature in ensuring that the old and the frail are able to remain in their homes with a sense of security. How many clients will be affected by the change?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Medical alarms are issued from the domiciliary services support unit at the Repatriation General Hospital (RGH), Heidelberg. Until recently they were obtained by the RGH from the Queen Elizabeth Geriatric Centre (QEGC). The QEGC recently increased its rates by 20 per cent per week and included an installation charge of $100. As the alarms could be supplied more cheaply by a private agency, Heidelberg is now getting the alarms from MSS Alarm Services. This decision to change the supply was made simply for economic reasons. Recipients of the alarms are now being supplied with the new alarms, which operate in the same way as the QEGC alarms. The change-over is due to be completed by 23 November 1990, and I understand that some 40 clients are involved.

—I thank the Minister. The information available to me indicated that, if the Queen Elizabeth Geriatric Centre alarms, which were the PACS system alarms, were fully utilised, they would in the long term be as cost effective and certainly more socially beneficial than those offered by the MSS service. I understand that one of the important differences is with regard to daily contact. I think there is an extra cost of $1.50 a week between the two services, but that is more than compensated for by the service which the more expensive one offers to the frail and elderly whom we are trying to keep safely in their own homes.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that in fact the daily contact service continues with the MSS system. If that is so, I think that may allay some of the fears as to the social concerns, as opposed to the purely cost benefit ones, with which Senator Newman is dealing.

—I thank the Minister for that information. I was not aware that both systems were offering daily care and that is certainly an important fact which I did not have available to me. I presume that this new system is being monitored and that some information will be available before long as to whether it is as effective as the previous system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a short statement concerning daily contact. Whilst this is considered to be beneficial, it is not considered to be an essential component of the systems. Currently 85 per cent of our clients with emergency alarm systems do not have this daily call contact.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue has been discussed extensively with the domiciliary occupational therapist at the Repatriation General Hospital, and it is agreed that there are often too many complications with the system to make it viable; that is, clients going out shopping, et cetera, and forgetting to activate, going on holidays or just not remembering. It is considered that daily contact is not the crux of the service.

I need to revise an earlier answer. I understand that the MSS service does not offer daily contact on an automatic basis but is technically able to be provided within the system. I am not sure of the steps that need to be taken if the daily contact process is undertaken. I guess the situation of the client would be taken into account by the occupational therapist or by those qualified to make the proper assessment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. Does that mean that it will be provided to, say, that 15 per cent who previously were found to need a daily call? On what basis will it be provided? That seems a bit vague and I would like the Minister to be more precise if he can.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have more precise information. All I am able to say is that there is capacity within the MSS alarm system for that daily contact to be made. I have indicated that the professional views of the occupational therapists and others will be taken into account in determining whether that service should be offered. We will certainly provide the honourable senator with a very complete answer in that regard.

—I hope that the Minister is aware-certainly the Department should be aware-that concerns have been expressed about this. One concern is the question of daily contact; the other is that the difference in installation costs is hardly as important as it might seem at first glance when usually people who are able to remain in their own homes get the usage of these systems for a number of years. Therefore, the cost is spread over quite a period and the initial installation cost starts to become less relevant. I would also like to double check the Minister's statement that there was a difference of $100. Is that what the Minister said?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I mentioned that there was an installation charge of $100. The full sentence I read was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the QEGC recently increased its rates by 20 per cent per week and included an installation charge of $100 . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the installation charge for the MSS?
—I do not have an answer available.
—I would be grateful if I could get such an answer. Could I also receive an assurance that the daily contact needed by that percentage of elderly veterans and war widows will be provided?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said the capacity is there--
—That is not the same thing.

—Senator Newman should let me finish the sentence. The capacity is there and I have indicated that with the proper professional advice that service will be provided to those who need it. As Senator Newman said, perhaps 15 per cent have been assessed as requiring it.

—I thank the Minister. I would like to move now to the issue of community patients in repatriation hospitals. Can I be provided with the total cost to the Department of providing community patients with limbs, appliances, surgical footwear and subsequent repairs in 1989-90, and a break-up by State if possible. The Minister may not have that with him, but I would be glad of any information on that today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is not separately costed, and that the distinction is not made for the purpose of record keeping and therefore is not available.

—I am sorry, I am not quite sure what the Minister means by saying it is not separately costed. Does the Minister mean separately costed from veterans' care or separately costed in the break-up of the items I just spelt out?
—Separately costed from veterans' care.
—Could I ask why that is?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: — Repatriation hospitals are funded out of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) for the treatment of all patients, including members of the general public. There is minor funding through revenue, including payments by private patients. I do not know whether that is relevant, but I think the point being made is that appropriation is made for the treatment of all those who come into the repatriation hospital rather than by category of veteran, non-veteran or community patients.
—So there is no way in fact of being able to quantify the amount by which the veterans' affairs budget is subsidising non-veterans? Is that correct?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am further advised that it is not possible to determine accurately the costs of treating community patients inasmuch as these costs are at the margin. For example, a community patient may be the twenty-eighth patient in a 28-bed ward and major costs such as nursing, medical, electricity and cleaning, et cetera, have already been incurred. The only additional costs in many cases are for drugs, medical supplies and some specialist medical services. I guess that is one of the difficulties in actually apportioning the costs of a group of patients against another group of patients. All the moneys are provided by the Commonwealth taxpayer. The repatriation hospitals are available for use by community patients along with veterans and therefore it is not quite accurate to speak in terms of the veterans' affairs budget in some sense subsidising community patients or other medical services. It is all taxpayers money funding the provision of a medical service. Of course that provides for veterans and then community patients. It is the provision of a service rather than directed to particular categories.

—I thank the Minister. Perhaps it was a good try, but I do not think it is a very satisfactory answer. When we look at the appropriations for the Department of Veterans' Affairs, it is surely an entitlement of the Parliament to know how much of the hospital costs are going on veterans and how much on non-veterans. It is not so difficult, knowing the bed days, to try to do a calculation of the cost of the bed days. What is difficult is to try to find out how much of the budget is going on the additional items such as I listed-limbs, appliances, surgical footwear and subsequent repairs. I believe it is proper and necessary for the Department to be able to quantify that. After all, if it were a private hospital, it would know who to send the bill to and it would be able to quantify it for that purpose. It seems unsatisfactory that that break-up is not provided to the Parliament, at least for an information purpose.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received some further information in relation to the questions on notice and the answers provided to Senator Newman. I find among the sheets one which gives some indicative costs in relation to community patient numbers, bed days and costs. In relation to Hobart, for example, the number of patients identified was 1,213; bed days, 5,707; the indicative cost of $2,260,000 derived from certain assumptions, and so on. I think that takes Senator Newman a long way towards the answer she is seeking in relation to something as easily identified as bed days. In relation to Senator Newman's question about limbs, appliances and so on, a similar indicative costing does not appear to have been undertaken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for recognising that that is a problem. I acknowledge that I received some answers in the Estimates Committee but because there is a gap I am now trying to get some follow-up information. If the Department is not able to give that now, I hope that the next time it comes before us it will be able to find a way, with the computerised system, of identifying it in the explanatory memoranda, and we will be able to ask questions on that item.

SPEECH.PARA: Further to the question regarding integration which was asked in the Estimates hearings, I would like to ask just what costs will be associated with establishing a private patients scheme if, in fact, the repatriation hospitals do become integrated into the State health systems. The first answer I got on program 2.2 about a number of matters relating to integration was as follows:
A proposed private patients scheme has been under discussion with the ex-service community since mid-89.

I presume that, in order to have those discussions, the Department has a fair understanding of what such a scheme would cost. I wonder whether I could get some information from the officers now as to how they see that scheme working and the costs thereof.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The level of costs will depend upon the rates which are negotiated with State governments and private hospitals. I might mention that the exercise being undertaken is not driven by cost savings. The financial and administrative arrangements with State governments have not yet been negotiated. Some contracts have been negotiated with preferred provider private hospitals, mainly in States which already use private hospitals extensively-New South Wales, Queensland and Tasmania. Post-integration arrangements will see greater requirements such as quality assurance and more comprehensive fee arrangements built into preferred provider arrangements.

—I thank the Minister, but I do not think that took us very far. The Minister referred to the fact that private hospitals are used more extensively by the Department in three of the States. Has the Department, in estimating what will happen with a private patients scheme, given some sort of ball park figure to the cost of using private hospitals in each of the States?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that those investigations have not been undertaken.
—That is interesting. Has any estimate been made of the usage in terms of bed days that will take place if such a scheme is made available to veterans?

—Quite clearly and obviously there is expected to be some increased usage of private hospitals, but until the arrangements are negotiated with the States and the public hospital system that cannot be determined.
—Is there an estimate of the percentage increase over the current usage?
—No.

—The Minister is a long way from getting near to a figure, is he not? Has the Minister any information about the increased usage that is expected by the private patients within the State government hospital systems?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officers have made only generalised assumptions about the growth of the use of these particular opportunities for private patients to be treated within the public system. They have made only generalised assumptions based on the demography of the regions concerned.
—Could I have those assumptions then, Minister, please?

—As I say, the assumptions are based on the demography which refers to the age profile and the concentration of eligible persons within a particular State or region. I understand that as the State by State agreements are negotiated those particular demographic assumptions will assume greater importance, become more precise and form the basis for the proper agreements with the States, but that stage has not been reached as yet.

—Is the Minister trying to tell me that the Government has a policy of integration of the repatriation hospitals within the State systems-which includes a private patients scheme which will go to both the State and private hospital systems-and that the Department has no assumptions, no estimates, no forward projections about the usage after integration and therefore no costs have been able to be allocated even on a ball park basis? Does the Minister mean to say that the Government made that decision without that information?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I tried to explain in the course of my earlier remarks, while it may appear somewhat amazing, that would be only if one thought that Government decision making was driven by cost savings forces. In fact, it is driven by other considerations altogether, to do with the better care available to veterans in the community. It is for that reason that the precise matters which Senator Newman raises have not been quantified with the precision which certainly would have been the case had this whole exercise been driven by the need to achieve certain savings.

—I made no claim that it was anything to do with cost savings. I simply asked: Did the Government have the necessary information on which to make that decision? It could be that the proposal is enormously expensive. It does not matter from that point of view. I am asking what information the Government had available to it on which such an important, major decision was made by it for a new direction in veterans' entitlements. If it is the Department that has not done those studies, then the Department must surely be condemned as incompetent. If it is the Government that has made the decision not based on proper information, then the Government is a disastrous government-which we all know. As far as veterans are concerned it is just intolerable that a decision of such importance could be made without the proper information. Which is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have tried to explain that the motive driving this particular exercise from the Government's point of view, and what justifies the policy-which is something which the Government stands by-is the fact, as certainly I know from talking with Tasmanian veterans, that many veterans prefer to be treated closer to their homes. I believe that the ageing profile of the veteran population in the regions away from access to traditional repatriation hospitals is the major reason underlying the integration process. The policy decision has been taken on those grounds. The question of the costs to be borne will be consequential on that particular policy decision and will not drive the policy decision. That is point that I have been trying to emphasise.

SPEECH.PARA: As the need for making proper agreements with the States or private hospitals gets closer, quite clearly the cost consequences of that policy decision will become more evident and precise. It is at that time that the costs associated with this policy decision will be evident. It was not necessary for the Government to have those cost implications and consequences before it when it made the policy decision, because the policy decision was taken on other grounds.

TALK.START.PARA: —So the Government did not know whether it would cost it less or more, or even have any idea what the cost would be when it made that decision; is that what I am to assume?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman should assume that the Government made the decision on proper grounds concerning the care of veterans in the provision of hospital services to them wherever they are and in various facilities outside, if necessary, the traditional repatriation system. That is what the senator has to understand. The consequential costs are matters which the Government is prepared to deal with, having made the right decision on behalf of veterans.

—Well, that is a rum way of making decisions in this Government. It is very interesting to have it confirmed; I thank the Minister. May I ask the Minister once again, at the risk of sounding as if I am flogging a dead horse: Did the Government have any information provided to it by the Department about projected usage of the various hospital systems after integration took place?
—The answer is no.
—Have any discussions taken place on the issue with any State Ministers and, if so, who?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there have been discussions with the State departments, and obviously they would be authorised and allowed to go ahead with the permission and under the aegis of the State Ministers concerned, if Senator Newman means face to face with State Ministers.
—Or over the telephone, by letter or whatever.

—I do not know. I presume that there have been discussions from time to time when Mr Ben Humphreys visited the various States on his rounds, and I understand that he is to do so in Tasmania this month. He will be seeing Mr John White down in Hobart. That sort of round of face to face discussions is taking place at ministerial level.
—I thank the Minister, but can I have some precision in the answer? He is to meet with Mr White in Tasmania next month; is that correct?
—He hopes to or intends to.
—Has he yet met with, spoken to or written to any of the other State Ministers on this issue and, if so, who?
—Yes, he has written to all State Ministers and even the Northern Territory Minister, perhaps.
—When would that have been?
—I understand that it was in about mid-year 1989 after the private patients scheme was announced.
—So he has had answers from all the Ministers to his letter, has he?
—I am sure that they are as courteous as I am and would have replied.
—Has there been any follow-up to his letter? I want to know precisely what stage he is at with each of the State health Ministers.

—Quite clearly, the State by State negotiating process is something that is under way, as we all know at the moment. It is at various stages. I have indicated that he hopes to see Mr John White in Tasmania some time later this month. That sort of process will continue as it is convenient for the Ministers to get together on their various rounds, given their parliamentary timetables.
—So I am to assume that he has not yet had any discussions with any State Ministers; is that the right assumption?
—I understand that he has met with each of the health Ministers at least once since the initial letter went out.
—Can you tell me what has been the response from each of the State Ministers?

—I am sorry; I will clarify that. Since the announcement of transfer there has been a meeting with each of the State Ministers. I thought that Senator Newman's question was more precise as to meeting with them over the question of private patients in the public hospital system.
—My question is directed to the negotiations regarding integration. Have there been discussions Minister to Minister, not departments.
—The answer is yes.
—With all of them?
—I understand that he has met with each of the Ministers since the initial announcement of the decision on integration.
—Has any State agreed to support integration?
—I do not think any formal statement has been uttered by any State Government in relation to this matter.
—Has he received any encouragement from any State Minister?

—The fact that consultations have not been broken off and that negotiations are continuing in a serious way in Tasmania, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia indicates that governments are willing to discuss these matters with a view to seeing whether there can be a resolution favourable to the veterans of Australia.
—I thank the Minister. So at officer level in three States there are negotiations; is that correct?
—I think I mentioned four-Tasmania, New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria.

—I again thank the Minister. Let me turn to the fourth issue. It relates to the large backlog in nursing home accounts. I asked during the Estimates hearings about this and received an answer. How does the Government intend to ensure that management information available is improved so that the Department has appropriate control over nursing home expenditure?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department in its explanatory notes for 1990-91 stated that expenditure decreased by 2.7 per cent to $79,451,383. This apparent decrease is due to an unavoidable delay by the Department in making the June 1990 payment. This explanation was based on finance ledger information and was the best information available to the Department at that time. Subsequent advice from the Department of Community Services and Health has shown that there was no delay in payments and that the payments for June had been processed on the last working day of May 1990. Advance payments by Department of Community Services and Health on behalf of Department of Veterans' Affairs are made prior to the fourth day of each month, with the exception of July. Due to this arrangement the advance is often recorded as expenditure in the previous month's finance ledger. The Department is working with Department of Community Services and Health to resolve the statistical problems with regard to nursing home payments made on behalf of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. In future the Department will have access to a wider range of information, including patients and payment details. This will provide the Department with adequate control in this area of expenditure.

—I thank the Minister, but in the answer I received in the Estimates hearing the Department said that it was taking action to ensure that the management information available is improved to ensure that this Department has appropriate control over nursing home expenditure. How does the Department intend to ensure that that management information is improved? I do not understand how it could be that under-expenditure of $5m was thought to have occurred which was then found not to be the case. It seems to me that that is a pretty serious matter to be concerned about and that information management becomes a pretty important issue.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree that it is an important issue. I understand that the Department of Veterans' Affairs is meeting with Department of Community Services and Health early next week to sort out how information will be collected and reported and will be undertaking a very pointed session to try to get that process right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I move to the last issue I wish to raise, and it relates to domiciliary nursing care. I have a copy of the departmental policy dealing with the employment of domiciliary nurses. I understand that in New South Wales the job of nursing veterans in their own homes is first offered to the Sydney Home Nursing Service and that that service is paid on a fee for service basis. I believe that has been a long-standing arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Sydney Home Nursing Service is not able to provide this service, I understand the Department then calls in private nursing services, and the work is offered to agencies who charge a fee of 20 per cent on top of the nurses' charge. Then, in the event that they cannot cope, it can go to individual nurses. Could it be explained to me on what basis the individual nurses are chosen, and what percentage of work does each of those layers of nursing get? Does the Sydney Home Nursing Service get about 90 per cent and the agencies about 8 per cent-that kind of thing?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the question, Senator Newman, and I will provide the breakdown into the categories at some future time. As to the qualifications, I take it that Senator Newman means qualifications apart from their obviously professional qualifications-perhaps their experience with veterans or semi-geriatric care or something like that. I will see whether there are individual nurse criteria, apart from their professional qualifications, which are taken into account and provide those to the honourable senator.

—I thank the Minister. I wanted to know things such as what other organisations, if any, receive referrals, and on what basis they are chosen. Are there individual nurses who are willing to offer service and are acceptable but for some unexplained reason are excluded? Those are some of the issues that I would like to know. Are there reasons for excluding people as well as including them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will undertake to provide that information.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: WOOL TAX (No. 1) FURTHER AMENDMENT BILL 1990WOOL TAX (No. 2) FURTHER AMENDMENT BILL 1990WOOL TAX (No. 3) FURTHER AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, this is probably one of the most important discussions to come before the Senate this year. I note at this stage that we are addressing the second readings of only a partial number of the wool tax Bills that will surface at various stages today and be dealt with as a full package. But it is appropriate that we get on with the job and dedicate a fair amount of time to the consideration of this most important issue.

SPEECH.PARA: As everyone in Australia knows, the wool debate has very historical, and economic effects and major development consequences for our country. Certainly, anyone who traces the history of wool throughout Australia will know that it is intricately linked to the economics, politics and community development in many areas. We need to recognise that our national economy is in dire straits and that to a large extent the contribution made by wool to our economy is a most important factor.

We are all well aware that we are at a time when confidence is needed in so many of our industries. We must accept that the wool industry is ailing; it is in crisis, like so many other aspects of the national economy. We must deal with these issues today. They must be given urgency. I was pleased this morning when the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) agreed to a change in the agenda to bring forward these important Bills for discussion today. We are all aware that they were guillotined through the House of Representatives only two nights ago under very unsatisfactory debating circumstances.

The House of Representatives is where the Government faces the people and where the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) ought to be making their major contributions to this major and important debate. But that did not happen. The Bills were given a paltry two hours for consideration. The Opposition was denied the opportunity to put amendments that were most appropriate and, in effect, the Government has shown a very cavalier and irresponsible way of dealing with this particular program.

I am sure that when historians take the time to look back on the debates of 1990 and the very important issues that affect the agricultural and the pastoral industries of Australia, they are going to have a field day particularly when they consider the paucity and quality of debate and the issues as reported in the Hansards of last May and, of course, in this last month or so. We have seen in the media a lot of debate from industry groups with regard to so many areas that need attention.

Mr Acting Deputy President, let me highlight the fact that on the speakers list for this debate that has been circulated in the Senate today there are nine senators listed, and the Minister is listed to give a usual reply. There is not one Labor Party senator listed to take part in the debate on this important issue relating to wool. Not one Labor senator is prepared to come in here today and take up the cudgels of this terribly important industry or of his constituency. When we look at the debate in the House of Representatives and at the Labor members who participated in the debate, who do we see participated? Mr Courtice, Dr Charlesworth and Mr Graeme Campbell.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a sensational team.

—I trust that Senator Richardson was being ironic. I would invite him to read the Hansard, because it was not a fantastic debate. In fact, the inadequacy of it was highlighted. I would invite members and senators and anyone who is interested to look very carefully at the contribution by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graeme Campbell, because he spent his entire time giving the Government and the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) a very considerable serve.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to note, in considering the legislation that is before us today, that the Australian Wool Corporation has finally acknowledged what the coalition has been saying for some time: marketing alone will not get the industry out of its problems and production must be dramatically reduced. We believe that the 20 million flock reduction, together with quotas and a 20 per cent surcharge from 1 July, will not bring the supply into line with the demand fast enough. There are major issues in this industry that have to be addressed. The Opposition still believes that a major slaughter scheme is the only realistic method of bringing supply down in the short time available to the industry.

The industry does not have the luxury of time to deal with its problem, and to date this urgency has been missing from the measures imposed. I note that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is to proceed overseas in the next few days on an important international mission. I only hope that he is carrying in his bags the briefs with regard to the promotion of wool that are so essential. The Minister needs to know that he can go from this Parliament with the confidence that this legislation has been passed.

If we are to maintain the floor price at 700c a kilogram, there is certainly a need to increase the wool tax to 30 per cent for the market support fund to pay for the very necessary flock reduction scheme. However, the coalition is critical that the additional 20 per cent that is being proposed for a slaughter levy would destroy too many growers and is not particularly dealt with.

Other important aspects of this legislation need very serious and urgent consideration: for example, confirmation of the operative level of 25 per cent of the wool tax; assistance to the growers affected by last year's floods, particularly in New South Wales and Queensland; the exemption of carpet wools from the scheme; and the ability to use the wool tax for the slaughter scheme.

I took the opportunity to review the annual report of the Australian Wool Corporation that was tabled in this chamber only several days ago. In reviewing that report, I noted that the Corporation, in its annual operating plan for 1989-90, set the following objectives:
* Provide greater stability of wool prices at maximum sustainable levels, subject to the costs of the stockholding.
* Promote wool and develop markets for Australian wool and wool products.
* Initiate research and development leading to greater efficiency and reduced costs in wool production, marketing and manufacturing.
* Optimise long-term returns from commercial activities of the AWC.
* Liaise with the Wool Council of Australia to develop industry policy and provide information and services to Australia's woolgrowers.
* Report to woolgrowers and Government on the state of the wool industry and on the effective administration of AWC assets and liabilities.

In many respects the AWC failed to meet the objectives and the criteria that it set as its own challenge. With the concurrence of the Senate-and I have shown this to Senator Robert Ray, who was in the chamber earlier-I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a summary of the major AWC activities in 1989-90 that was included in its annual report.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
[THE DOCUMENT IS NOT INCLUDED IN THE DATABASE; SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 4233]

TALK.START.PARA: —A review of the objectives that were set and not met, the issues and the lack of concern and consultation with growers will be of concern to many honourable senators and people in the industry. We note that the AWC's operating loss for the year was $336m, after allowing for abnormal losses totalling $613m. Some serious questions certainly have to be asked and addressed. The leaders of the industry organisations have a lot to be accountable for.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not hard to look at where the industry is going when it is combined with other problems in the economy at the moment. The lack of leadership by government highlights the inadequate information that has been made available throughout the year. I wonder about the exchange of information that has passed between the Minister, his Department and industry leaders. Again, in reviewing the debates of last May and the issues as they have evolved in the last six months, it is frightening to talk about the deteriorating economy, the consequences and the responses that are needed for change.

Throughout this year we have seen major changes in the markets of the Soviet Union, China and eastern Europe. We have also seen the dramatic impact and the consequences of the oil prices, attributed, of course, to Iraq. There is a need to call into question many of these issues.

In a debate in the House of Representatives earlier this week on a matter of public importance on the crisis in the rural sector, the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Tim Fischer, made a most important contribution. He stated:

This rural economic crisis is not just a matter for provincial Australia or for small towns or large cities across Australia; it is a matter for all of Australia because the impact will be on the standard of living of all Australians.

Mr Fischer has highlighted the fact that there is a need for urgent attention. It is a fact that Australian agriculture is shattered; investment is uncertain; the risk margins on farm loans will continue to increase; property values will fall; research will be interrupted; and the number of young and innovative people entering rural industries will fall away. The consequences of the rural crisis, such as heavy interest burdens, bank foreclosures, effects on land values, employment on the farm and employment in many associated industries, are being seen and felt.
The Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, addressed the conference of the Wool Council of Australia on 7 November on these important issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did he go at the joint party meeting?

—He goes very well in joint party meetings; he goes very well in this Parliament. With Dr Hewson's ratings and the pollings, it is no wonder that the Australian Labor Party is running scared of him. Dr Hewson has a grip on the economy of Australia far better than anybody in the Government. He knows exactly where the issues are and he has highlighted and knows the fundamental principles that underlie the economy. In his address to the wool conference, Dr Hewson said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is a time to face reality, it is a time to force adjustments as a matter of urgency.
On the Labor Party's view on the economy, Dr Hewson said:

They slammed on the monetary policy brakes. They pushed interest rates higher and kept them there longer than we have experienced in this country. We have never had such a period of sustained high interest rates in both real and nominal terms and, of course, the result is what we have today. Collapses of asset prices across the board, a generalised bust in the entire private sector of our economy and of course a collapse in spending and demand.

Yes, the economy is on a substantial slide and it is going to get tougher because the international scene is hard and we have to recognise that. The consequences in the wool markets and the wool sector will affect many areas that need to be addressed urgently and now. Again, as I said in my opening remarks, not one Labor Party senator is prepared to come into the chamber today to contribute to this important debate.

In looking at the legislation, we note that the decisions which the Government took in October outline a number of initiatives that are long overdue and need to be addressed very carefully. The strategies that need to be put into place for the next three years also need urgent attention. What is the timetable? In his second reading speech, Minister Kerin has said that he hopes that a strategic plan will be tabled by 31 December.

It is interesting to note that because of the problems with legislation in this place the Senate will sit until 21 December. It will be very interesting to see whether Minister Kerin is able to present to the Senate before we rise on 21 December the long term strategic plan that will affect the wool industry and so many areas that require attention.

The problems in the wool industry require very clear thinking and major attention at an early time. I will leave it to the other eight senators who will contribute to this debate and whose electorates are much closer to the industry area than my own to highlight the many issues that will require attention and the impacts on woolgrowers' incomes.
Let me highlight the comments of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graeme Campbell, in the debate in the other place on 13 November:
It is my view that we are looking at the worst financial crisis this country has seen, certainly in recent times. I do not think that message has got through yet.
Mr Hawker interjected to ask, `Just in wool?' and Mr Campbell replied:
No, in the entire economy. When we are dealing with wool, we are dealing with the biggest decentralised industry in Australia and one of the biggest overall employers in Australia.

Mr Campbell's address to the House of Representatives requires very careful and considered study, as do the contributions by the shadow Minister for primary industry, Mr Bruce Lloyd; the shadow Minister for industry and commerce, Mr Ian McLachlan; Mr Michael Cobb and Mr Ian Sinclair-people who know this industry so well. This is an important time to address the matters raised in those contributions. I am pleased to indicate that we will be supporting the legislation, but we will not be supporting the additional 20 per cent surcharge in respect of certain wool-clause 5-at the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important that I start by saying that what is being proposed here is in fact a maximum rate of wool tax. It is not true, as has been asserted by some, that a rate of 50 per cent will apply immediately-at the next wool sale. The operational rate will be increased from 18 per cent to 25 per cent. That is what was originally and consistently recommended by the Australian Democrats with the advice of the Australian Wool Corporation and producers. It is important to note carefully that if this rate had been applied over the past few months when some considerable amount of wool has been sold, the Corporation would have had more funds and therefore a reduced need for this surcharge. The fact is that the rate has not been available and the desperate need for funds is now causing these desperate measures to be taken.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats have some difficulty with the surcharge. This is because it is too easy for the administrators of the scheme to simply buy and stockpile. Such actions will not resolve the problems. The actions we need are those which also address the other side of the equation-the demand side of our wool. Whatever else has happened to the wool industry, far too much attention has been given to bureaucratic means of simply reducing supply and far too little attention has been given to an imaginative means of expanding the demand for our markets.

I should expand on that. In some cases, the demand exists: it simply has not been expressed in hard currency. For example, there is a Soviet demand for our wool. It is pleasing to see that some alternative marketing strategies, such as credit sales, are being considered now-belatedly. These propositions would be more meaningful if some imagination were applied to developing methods of offsetting sales of Soviet Union products to Australia. The whole concept does not rely upon Zetor tractors and Lada cars, even though they may have some value in Australia. We need to look beyond what we might immediately think of when we think of trade with the Soviets.

I am very pleased to acknowledge Senator Calvert's efforts as he especially pointed out that a Soviet vessel could have been considered for use by our Antarctic Division. It might have been appropriate for those who were conducting our wool trade negotiations with Russia to encourage the Tasmanian Government to seriously consider purchasing a replacement Bass Strait ferry from the Soviet Union. It is an interesting irony that the likely purchase price of such a vessel is of the same order of cost as the amount recently owed by the Soviets for our most recent wool sales-that is, about $150m.

We are talking about big ticket items here-the sorts of expenses which play havoc with Australia's current accounts. Those who have been paying any attention to this whole situation would have observed that during the past several months Australia's current account deficit has suffered regularly from the burden of other big ticket items. What I am talking about here is the purchase of aircraft overseas. The problem is that now that Australia's publicly owned airlines have been given away, there is little capacity for the Government to direct purchases.

There should be some capacity remaining to actively encourage purchasers of aircraft-whoever they may be-to consider some Soviet aircraft for particular applications within Australia, whether they be fixed-wing aircraft, helicopters or whatever. We seem to have our minds set that these are the sorts of things we should be buying from the United States of America or Europe. We have not seriously considered Soviet options. That is a pity because in aviation history probably one of the most notoriously unsafe aircraft has been the Douglas compilation which seemed to fall out of the sky quite regularly. We seem to have our minds set that Soviet aircraft might not be as good. The track record is that they are perfectly adequate. We just do not seem willing to consider them.

Those are the sorts of alternative marketing strategies that should be supported when we are considering how we can expand the demand for our products overseas. I am amazed that we do not have enough initiative in these areas. Some of the things I have just suggested could and should be supported by other activities such as joint marketing ventures and direct Australian assistance in the establishment of apparel production for the domestic Soviet market. It is as though our minds are set against considering such options. It is to the peril of the Australian wool industry that there is not enough imagination and that alternative positions are not taken. Whether those schemes involve Australian participation in a domestic establishment with the capitalist system, or free market set-up-or whatever the Russians are exploring-Australian participation in offsets could be one of the options available. We could and should explore the options for different forms of equity in Soviet enterprises in return for their purchase of Australian wool.

Of course, these options are not limited to trade with the Soviets. We have not seen enough evidence of imagination being applied to marketing strategies for China, Korea or, for that matter, African nations. We do not see any evidence that the people who are in charge of marketing Australian wool are addressing the problem with imagination. The requirement to apply the surcharge could be reduced if the industry itself could see the other side of the equation and not just consider reducing supply. The requirement to apply the surcharge could also be reduced if the industry could redirect its production to those segments of the market which are most likely to continue with strong sales. Of course, it is realised that such a redirection does not take place overnight. It should be recognised that it is part of a long term view which the industry should be taking.

The measures in this legislation are essentially short term, they are temporary and they do little to redirect the industry to a future which is sustainable. The foreshadowed quota system and the slaughter scheme do not promise long term solutions either. Anybody who understands the wool industry knows that the sheep population in Australia has fluctuated over the years. Even a proposition to slaughter about 50 million sheep this year could not have a permanent effect on the sheep population of Australia. Out of something short of 180 million sheep, 40 million a year can easily be bred each year. About that number was born this year. To propose to reorganise the industry simply by a slaughter scheme is not facing up to the direction, the balance and the profile of the industry.

Any proposal to reduce the size of the national flock should be discriminatory. By that I mean that it should not remove from our national flock any sheep from those market segments that are successfully selling all of their produce. From what I have heard of this proposed quota system so far it seems that it would be an overall non-discriminatory quota system which has the potential of removing from production those sheep which are producing the wool which we are able to sell at the moment.

In some areas it is not so much that we are producing too much wool but rather that we are producing too much of the wrong type of wool. There are market niches and wool production specialities which we should in the long term be expanding. We can immediately begin to expand those areas. Obvious areas are the fine wool and superfine wool segments. These segments should not suffer any suggestion of quotas or sheep disposal.

Similarly, I will return to one of my favourite topics-the carpet wool producers. The carpet wool producers of Australia are engaged in direct import replacement at the moment. While we have a situation where we import 85 per cent of the carpet wool which is processed in Australia, it is ridiculous to suggest that we should reduce its production by a single kilogram. From what I understand of this proposed quota system and slaughter scheme, there is no proposition to isolate any segment of the industry. We would be cutting off our nose to spite our face if we could not see the sense in identifying and discriminating in favour of those areas of the wool industry which are successfully selling the entire product at the moment. There are other regional and type specialities which we should be encouraging in any long term plan.

The wool industry is not unified in either supporting or rejecting these proposals. It has come to my notice that there is as much dissent, confusion and discussion about this matter as there is about any number of other issues confronting Australia at this time. We have to be very careful and temperate in considering the advice we have received, whether it be from woolgrowers organisations or from so-called marketing experts. I have received a deluge of representations in my office. They have ranged from people who are involved in the industry to many people who believe they can solve the world's problems in half an hour. I understand that is fairly typical.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a lot of them.

—That is right. I have been willing to listen but, in listening, I have found that the only consensus which has been expressed is one that, for all its faults, the tax proposal has to go forward in principle. It has been suggested that the Australian Democrats should use this debate to abandon the reserve price scheme, to disband the Australian Wool Corporation and to move to a free market situation. Apparently, this is because all that is wrong in the industry can be directly attributed to the reserve price scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot accept that suggestion. It is quite obvious to me that there are many factors involved in this situation, including such things as the interest rates that we are currently suffering, the exchange rate that Australia has with the rest of the world, overseas events, climate factors and the domestic situation. There are any number of aspects and not one of them can be isolated and blamed for the faults.

I have already mentioned that it is my opinion that the long term picture should show an evaluation of the present production profile of the Australian wool industry. That is something that the industry itself needs to address as well as any measures that are taken here. We also have a vulnerability in certain aspects of the market where demand fluctuates. Due to circumstances beyond our control, certain countries to which certain styles and classes of wool are exported change either their capacity or willingness to buy. Our supply mix of wool is really not wide enough and our sales tactics, quite honestly, are in fact pedestrian, to say the least.

What is important to consider is a modification of our wool industry. We should do this rather than accept the suggestion that we throw the whole lot out. The wool industry has a basic soundness, a basic experience and a basic knowledge. We lead the world in terms of the industry's longstanding efficiency of production. But the administration of our industry and our policy leadership can be challenged.

We cannot afford suddenly to compromise the industry and the basic experience and unification that we have by completely abandoning the established mechanisms. Such a simplistic measure would leave us with anarchy-some people describe this as free trade. Australia does not have the capacity to operate successfully in a wool market without rules and regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't do badly in the wheat market.

—Senator Panizza interjects that we do not do too badly in the wheat industry. I can remember Senator Panizza addressing in this Senate our incapacity as a nation to meet the subsidisation that is being offered by the United States to its wheat growers, and that is the very point I am making. While I agree with Senator Panizza that we do rather well in producing and promoting Australian wheat, we do suffer in that jungle of competition which our Government has not been able to protect us from. Some people are suggesting that we abandon whatever protection and support as well as cooperation and experience that we have and let our producers operate in a free trade jungle. We hear complaints about the tactics that other governments use to support their producers. Those very things are the hazards to which we are being asked to subject our producers and I for one do not think that that is a sensible way to go about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Some parts of the industry have, in fact, developed markets and established trading links outside the reserve price scheme. They can now justify their exemption from that scheme. We have successfully followed this model in the carpet wool industry and I suggest that other producers could well benefit from doing the same. It must be a question of evolution rather than revolution.

The wool industry in Australia is far too large and far too significant a component of the world wool trade for us suddenly to abandon all of our capacity to control it. To send our producers into a free market without some reserve price, without some industry-wide recognition and without some sharing of responsibility, strength and experience would be very much a case of abandoning them as babes in the wood.

Some of the tough guys who have contacted me have told me that they could survive in a free trade jungle. But as a nation we cannot afford to abandon the great bulk of our producers who would be eaten alive by the international trade manipulators. We need to preserve a system which allows wool producers to concentrate on what they know best-produce wool.

There is no argument that our present system is not working well; it is not working well in coordinating and directing the industry. But what should be done is that the system should be modified, not abandoned. These measures that we have before us, and those which have been telegraphed, in fact achieve that modification.

We have some serious concerns about the forthcoming suggestions regarding quotas and flock reduction proposals. Consequently, I intend to move an amendment to ensure that any proposal to put quotas on our production and limit the size of the wool industry is applied in a discriminating way and recognises those parts of the industry which are able to sell all of their product. Such a proposal should discriminate in favour of those parts of the industry so as to achieve in the long term what I have suggested-that is, to encourage our wool producers to move in the long term from producing the types of wool which are not supported in the international market to producing the types of wool which are in fact now, and in the future, recognised as being readily saleable. By doing that and not simply looking at short term measures, there will be a greater long term benefit to the wool industry.

The short term measures include such proposals as slaughtering anything from 20 million to 50 million sheep. As I indicated initially, this will not achieve any long term benefit. We are talking about something short of 180 million sheep. But there is still the capacity, if we allow the due process of nature to take its course, to immediately reinstate those sorts of numbers of sheep. So, such a proposal would not have the sort of long term effects that we should be looking at. It may save us the production of one shearing but it certainly would not reorient the industry to the extent that needs to be done. So, such a proposal really can only be seen as a very short term panic measure.

This legislation contains proposals which offer only short term solutions. Legislation in this area should be concerned with the development of the whole industry. We will support this legislation begrudgingly. We consider that at least the initial part to do with taxation is consistent with what has been the Democrats position all along.

In closing, I would like to point out again that if the position which was suggested by us some months ago and supported by the Nationals had been recognised as containing the wisdom which it did-it was based on advice from the industry-there would be less need to panic at this point and introduce such a requirement for a surcharge. The funds would have been available months earlier for the Corporation to administer, as it needed to. But, regrettably, that suggestion was rejected. I will not say, `We told you so', but at least we should have the luxury of saying that our advice should have been taken. I move:
At end of motion, add:
``but the Senate condemns the Government for not taking the following essential measures to ensure the long-term stability of the Australian wool industry and in particular for failing:

(a) to include in any national flock reduction strategy, discrimination in favour of those market segments which demonstrate the potential to continue sales at or above 70% of their production capacity;
(b) (i) to ensure that any proposal to limit the production of individual wool producers shall not be applied equally to all producers; and
(ii) that any proposal to limit the production of individual wool producers shall consider the market potential of the type of wool produced; and
(c) to ensure that the Australian Wool Corporation shall actively pursue alternative marketing strategies to ensure increased sales of Australian wool in all international markets.''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly did not think I would be standing up now speaking in a debate on wool legislation with no Minister present. Yet, here we are, two years down the track from the time the wool industry was Australia's leading export earner at $6 billion and is still earning over $4 billion today. Not one Minister has chosen to be present in the chamber for this debate. Senator Cook, who represents the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, in this place--
—Senator Cook would not know a wether from a wheat sack.
