—He may or may not, Senator O'Chee, but I will give him the benefit of the doubt that he does. At least I thought he would have been here. That is what the Government thinks of the wool industry. Although the industry still earns $4 billion worth of export income, we do not have a Minister at the table.
—And there is no Government member to speak on it.
—That is correct-no Government senator has been listed to speak.
—It is an indication of their lack of concern for the industry.

—It is obvious that there is lack of concern altogether. Madam Acting Deputy President, as a woolgrower and a very interested person in the welfare of the industry, I am pleased to take part in the debate on the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 3) Further Amendment Bills 1990. When I was speaking last May on the same subject I certainly did not think we would be debating it again quite so soon.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to speak about what has happened in the last couple of years. In May 1988 the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) decided that, because of the high price of the wool at the time-in fact, the indicator was 1,300c a kilogram and the floor was 670c a kilogram-the floor price should be increased to 870c a kilogram. The Corporation had the misguided belief that wool would always remain at that price or even go higher. Although I felt that wool had a great future, I did not believe that those high prices would remain for ever or that they would not go up and down.

At the time the Corporation implemented its decision to raise the floor price to 870c-and mind you, most decisions are implemented on 1 July of each year-it had a credit in the bank of $1.8 billion and virtually no stockpile. The indicator by then, however, had dropped to 1,000c a kilogram. So there was only 130c between the floor price and the indicator at that stage.

By October 1988 things had changed dramatically. The indicator had fallen back because of less demand for wool and the two levels met at 870c. That was the start of the disaster. From then to May 1990 the stockpile had reached two million bales. The industry approached us looking for a 25 per cent tax. The AWC told us that that would turn the situation around. This was one of the two times that I have believed the Corporation. We supported the 20 per cent tax that the Government brought in. I know the Australian Democrats wanted 25 per cent and Senator Bell referred to this a moment ago.

But the Government had made a decision and we certainly supported the idea on the basis of advice from Mr Beggs and the Wool Council of Australia that that would be sufficient. Of course, that 20 per cent was implemented on 1 July 1990. But at that time the Corporation was not prepared to bring down that ridiculous reserve price of 870c-a price which was already in trouble. It had the misguided idea that by having a heap of extra money available, demand would build up overseas. I do not understand the Commission's logic but it thought it would frighten buyers into the position of having to pay the 870c because they knew that they could not get wool any cheaper.

Of course, a few things happened around that time. We had Russia pulling out of the market. Then there were problems with China and Tiananmen Square. Still the Corporation would not agree. Mr Kerin then stepped in and brought the price down by regulation.

At that stage the credibility of the Corporation and the Wool Council should have been questioned. I certainly questioned it. I believe that 54 per cent of Australians questioned it. But it was not questioned as much as it should have been. That decision was duly implemented on 1 July, and then we saw the results. At 1 July the Corporation had been purchasing around 38 per cent of the clip on the floor. By October of 1990 the panic had set in and it was purchasing 75 per cent. The stockpile has reached the unbelievable level of 4.2 million bales. Of course, other matters, such as increased production, contributed to that. The Government made an announcement on 4 October that there were 4.2 billion bales in the stockpile and the Corporation was $2.2 billion in debt.

We might ask why other people did not question the performance of the Corporation which turned around a $1.8 billion credit on 1 July 1988 to $2.2 billion debt by 4 October 1990. That is a turnaround of $4 billion. One high flying enterprise in this country recorded about a $1.3 bil

The mismanagement of the Corporation and the Wool Council has not been questioned anywhere near enough yet. We hear about peripheral matters such as why wool has not been sold, why there is too much wool, and slaughter schemes. But the actions of the Corporation and its chairman, backed by the Wool Council, have not been questioned.

One of the reasons we have reached such a position is increased production. In the 1980s, Australia sold an average of 3.7 million bales. We certainly were able to place that wool and we received good prices. But, unfortunately, two things happened: the Corporation did not achieve increased markets and production had increased by two million bales. On the assumption that the demand for wool remained static, the damage was done by increased production.

The reason for the problem is simple: we are producing 5.7 million bales and selling only 3.7 million. Together with a reserve price system, this is a recipe for disaster. What is more, the Corporation is still quoting Australia's production at around 5.2 million bales. The industry around the country tells me that the true position is vastly different. People in the industry have told me that that production is quite a bit higher.

We must ask ourselves why we have such a high production. Of course, one reason is the artificially high price that was set. We have had an artificially high price and no limit on production. There was a certain turnaround in the wheat market in 1988-89. Some wheatgrowers-not a great number-turned to wool-growing. If I may say so, the wool industry is a lot easier to work in. One can keep ones hands a bit cleaner. The arti- ficially high prices caused the overproduction.

I suppose that now we must look at how we are going to increase sales and how we are going to increase the price if we need to. As I have said before, you either increase your demand or you cut production. I am not advocating that we go one way or the other. I believe that demand and production can be brought closer together in the short term and then, hopefully, in the long term both can be increased.

It has been mooted by the Corporation and the industry that we can have a slaughter scheme. There are two sorts of slaughter scheme advocated: 50 million sheep, costing $400m and needing a levy of about 10 per cent; and 20 million sheep, costing $100m and needing 2 1/2 per cent levy. Before someone jumps up and says that those figures do not conform, we are talking about killing 20 million old sheep that have virtually no commercial value. These sheep would be bought off farmers at $5 a head roughly.
The other method that has been advocated is quotas. I am certainly well against and my party is well against-I think Senator Bell mentioned this in his speech-this proposal.

If we think about it, this proposal advocated by the Wool Council is ridiculous. By applying quotas right across the board we will be cutting the sale of wool that has a market. Quotas will apply to top lines, which generally sell, and to oddments, which may not sell. Growers of fine wool and wool used for carpets will have the same problem. It is ridiculous even to suggest a quota.

But more ridiculous is the method by which the quota would be applied. I know that this Bill is not concerned with quotas but the Corporation is talking about them. If this Bill goes through untouched, quotas will be operating by next year if the Corporation has its way. It is ridiculous that the Corporation should propose quotas on a one-year basis only because of the variations that can occur across the country. There have been floods in New South Wales, droughts in certain spots of South Australia and other things happening in Western Australia. A production chart put out by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) shows that the position between States is inequitable.

In respect of quotas that may come in, the Wool Council believes that we should get back to 752,000,000 kilos, which roughly equates to the 3.9 million bales that we used to sell quite easily. The ABARE chart shows that we last produced 752.7 million kilos in 1984-85. Since then we have had an overall 34 per cent increase in wool production in Australia and this has caused the present problems. I will read into Hansard how that has come about. Wool production in New South Wales has increased 48 per cent; Victoria, 34 per cent; Queensland, 23 per cent; Western Australia, 28 per cent; South Australia, 15.6 per cent-they had a few problems; and Tasmania, which does not rate very high in the wool stakes-in fact, it has gone backwards-13 per cent.

If we are to have quotas, they should be imposed on a long term basis. A big advantage should not be given to New South Wales at the expense of someone else. So it is totally inequitable. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table showing Australian shorn wool production by State; a graph showing shorn wool production by State for 1981-82 to 1990-91; and a graph showing shorn wool production by State for 1982-83 to 1990-91. I have given these documents to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins).

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?

—I normally never seek to prevent honourable senators from incorporating documents. I never have. But with the greatest deference to the honourable senator, I would respectfully ask him whether he would consider tabling them rather than incorporating them. The reason, quite simply, Madam Acting Deputy President, is that the last bar graph is just almost indecipherable and it would not reproduce. The other two are in the same condition. Unfortunately, even the set of tables has got two columns of figures that have been written in by hand-I rest my case-and are almost indecipherable. So, with the greatest respect, Senator, could you table them rather than incorporate them? You cannot even decipher the two handwritten columns; you cannot even read the percentages. It would just be impossible for Hansard to do it.
—I understand the table is the problem.
—Can I just say, with respect: I try to assist wherever I can. I have taken actual technical advice on this and I am assured that the documents would be quite impossible to reproduce.
—Does that include the table, Minister?
—It does. The table itself would have been fine but you cannot read the two columns of handwritten figures that have been superimposed over the actual detail.
—I will go along with that idea and I thank the Senate. Unfortunately, this has taken up a couple of minutes of my time.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional order, we will proceed to a discussion of matters of public interest.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, under this head of matters of public interest I want to take just a few minutes of the time of the Senate to say something on the subject of political parties and the importance of political parties to our democracy. Unfortunately, parties in this country have become much maligned. I think it is important that we take time now and again to realise the cornerstone role that they play in maintaining democracy and the freedoms under which we all live.

SPEECH.PARA: I had a fascinating experience at the beginning of this year at a conference in Europe to meet with representatives of most of the new democratic political parties of eastern Europe. I am pleased that my Party, through its international relationships, has helped some of those parties in practical and philosophical ways.

I had the privilege of visiting the offices of a number of those new parties in such places as Bulgaria, Romania, Czechoslovakia and Hungary. I regard it as a great privilege to have been able to give them the benefit of our experiences. It was stimulating to have noted the excitement with which these people are organising their parties to become the cornerstones of new democracies. It is something that moved me and that I will never forget.

In the context, therefore, of the fact that we take our political system, our political parties and our democracy too much for granted, I want to take the opportunity today to put on the public record, presuming that I am given leave, a speech that was given recently by the oldest of the living Federal Presidents of my Party, Sir Robert Southey. In his speech titled 1945-1990, A Brief Historical Perspective, given on 6 October this year, Sir Robert reflects on the history of the Liberal Party of Australia, particularly the common thread of political philosophy that has run through its life over the years that I have just mentioned. He looked at how the Party has had to adapt to a changing Australia, and he looked at some of those who played key roles during that period in moulding the Party.

I am proud of the history of my Party and I would like to encourage the placing on the public record the histories of my and other important political parties that have played key roles in the development of the political system within Australia. I therefore seek leave to table the speech to which I have been referring.
Leave granted.

I have recently had representations from both the Kalano Community Association Inc., which is situated near Katherine in the Northern Territory, and the Milikapiti Community Government Council, at Snake Bay on Melville Island.

SPEECH.PARA: Both of these communities have been experiencing internal-I could call it political-and administrative problems. The people in the Town Camps are quite correct when they say that the Urban Aboriginal people are jealous that Kalano is up and running well and is doing so by the Traditional Aboriginal people.

They are correct when they say that these people are jealous that Government has the trust in Kalano to put funds such as $4.5m T.C.H.I.P. directly to Kalano. Everywhere else it went through the Local Government Authority.
They are correct when they say that these people want to get their hands on the money that is going into Kalano.

The Fraud and previous financial mismanagements that went on in the past at Kalano were all done by Urban Aboriginal people. The Town Camp people know that and they are very very concerned that if these people do win their power struggle that Kalano will financially go down and that the Traditional people will be pushed out of their jobs. The Town Camp people were the victims for years and years of mismanagement at Kalano by these people. They have every right to be concerned now.

There is also a great concern in the role of the Northern Land Council in this power struggle and this concerns the Traditional people. They believed that the N.L.C. was set up to help Traditional people with Land Rights. What is happening in Katherine is that the N.L.C. Office, and the equipment is being used as a base for this Power Group. This has been going on for over two months. The Camp people are disgusted that the N.L.C. Office and some of their staff are involved in the undermining of Traditional Aboriginal people.
What chance have these Traditional Aboriginal people got?
1. They have been blackmailed, and not supported by their ATSIC Regional Director.
2. They have had access to Katherine Aboriginal Legal Aid cut off in seeking Legal Assistance against the slander because the Senior Solicitor there is the Legal Advisor for this power group.
3. They cannot use the Katherine N.L.C. as they are supporting the power group.

4. They cannot go to the N.T. Government as the Health Department have been implicated in this undermining by the involvement of Health Department Staff-use of Health Depart. Offices/Equipment etc. in the beginning of the power struggle.

Kalano Staff have brought their Union in, not just out of concern of what ATSIC did to their boss the Kalano Council but also because the staff have been totally disrupted in their work and placed under stress because of the actions of this power group.

The staff were going to do a mass walk out a couple of weeks ago, however, they decided against it because of concern for services to the Town Camp people and also to keep fighting for what the Council stood for.

However, if the Power Group do get control of the Kalano Council at the Annual General Meeting coming up in November there will be a mass walk out of staff. There will also be a withdrawal of Town Camp people in their use of Kalano Services. These people are already organising alternatives. Unfortunately they are not Aboriginal alternatives but European. However they have more trust in their money being looked after properly by the European services than they have of the Urban Aboriginal people controlling them.

It is a sad day for Aboriginal people when this sort of thing goes on. In a lot of ways Government has a lot to answer for because of their lack of understanding that Aboriginal people are different. Traditional Aboriginal people do have different needs yet-how many of these people are in decision making roles? how many are in identified Aboriginal Public Servant Positions? The questions could go on.
There seems to be a level of thinking that `just because you have some Aboriginal blood in you, you understand Aboriginal people'. Traditional Aboriginal people will say different.
I have enclosed a Copy of an open letter, that the Kalano Community Association's President wrote to the Aboriginal Community of Katherine.
The Town Camp people are calling for help and someone to listen to their concerns. They need this help urgently. They are calling for Traditional Aboriginal people in Government to help them now.

The Kalano Council and the Town Camp people have tried to get their voice heard by going through the right channels. They did not want to lower themselves to the slanderous actions of this power group. However, it seems that doing things the right way get them no where as no one seems interested in the voice of the Traditional Aboriginal person.
I am requesting that you help these people now.
Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr Perron
This Community is experiencing very real difficulties in the administration of our CDEP program due to the interventionist and dictatorial practices of the local ATSIC office.

Some twelve months ago, Council identified areas which required attention in order for the program to fulfill its potential. Specifically, these were the employment of an experienced financial advisor and qualified coordinator, the expansion of office space available to CDEP staff, the changeover to a computerized accounting system and the establishment of storage facilities for CDEP plant/equipment. A great deal of effort and planning went into the implementation of this strategy.

It is to our dismay that these efforts have not been recognised by the local ATSIC office and in particular, the Regional Manager, Mr Theedom. Over the past six months we have been under sustained attack from this officer and yet he is still to visit our community.

On 6 September 1990, this officer through his local Project Officer, issued a number of directives concerning the operation of CDEP. Some of these represented a significant change of direction such as the prohibition on advance wages and allocating funds toward certain identified CDEP projects. Naturally, some members of the community were hostile toward this and our Council tried to explain that we were merely acting in compliance with Mr Theedoms' directions. On 5 October 1990, we sought confirmation in writing of these directions in order to verify with the community, the changes that had been enforced. Mr Theedom has yet to respond to this request and as a result, argument and disputation continue on the community.

It seems that ATSIC have adopted a``pro-active'' role in CDEP. This is evidenced by their insistence that budget variations be at their instigation and their nomination of what activity can or cannot be classified as a CDEP project.

Almost every letter we receive from Mr Theedom, contains some sought of threat to withdraw funds should we not comply with his instructions. What concerns us so much, is that this treatment is dished out in an environment where we have dramatically improved our financial reporting to the extent where ATSIC are provided on a monthly basis, a full return comprising of bank reconciliation, list of unpresented cheques, debtors/creditors trial balance by function and bank statements.

We at Milikapiti are very proud of our achievements in the area of financial management as both our Council and CDEP functions are fully computerized for accounts and wages. We have also, at our own cost, initiated on-site computer skills training with local people. Achievements of this kind would have been unthinkable 12 months ago. We do accept that from time to time errors creep into the system and these need to be identified and rectified. To this extent we have no problem with the local ATSIC office, in consultation with the community, monitoring development within the CDEP project. The ADC and DAA used to conduct their business in this fashion, ATSIC do not.

The latest broadside hurled at this community is a letter signed by Mr Theedom requiring the preparation of 3 separate quarterly Financial Statements for the CDEP. This will effectively treble our workload and setback local training programs months, and possibly years. I draw your attention to earlier comments on the scope and detail of our financial reporting to ATSIC which provides all the information necessary for evaluation and acquittance of Grant Funds including a split-up of the various functions, ie. wages, on costs and support. Mr Theedom happily quotes Part 3 of the``Rules and Administrative Procedures Relating to Grants'' and yet our present financial reports comply with all of the provisions contained in Part 3. I am also advised that no such additional reporting requirements of this type were introduced into the Katherine region of ATSIC. There appears to be a rather obvious``local arrangement'' here, and one must ask the question, why us?

We understood that the Federal Government was supposed to be the pacesetter in Aboriginal Affairs. Concepts such as self determination and self management are often bandied about us at will by the politicians and bureaucrats. Why then are we returning to the dark ages? The type of consultation with Aboriginal people that we have been experiencing went out of fashion 25 years ago, we thought! ATSIC is characterised by overbearing, dictatorial, interventionist and paternalistic practices unrivalled by any other organisation involved in Aboriginal Affairs. Quite frankly, we get the impression that Mr Theedom is playing games with us, that he does not care about the community and is more interested in``scoring points'' than assisting in a meaningful and positive fashion.

This attitude is in stark contrast with the NT Office of Local Government who subsidize the operations of our Council here. Although we are disappointed at the reduction in funding allocations through the Grants Commission in 1990/91, we respect the manner in which these Officers deal with us. They treat us like adults and allow us to run our own affairs without the interference which has so characterized ATSIC.

The CDEP at Milikapiti belongs to the Milikapiti community. It is not the plaything of some over zealous and pedantic bureaucrat in Darwin. We accept in its entirety, the requirement for accountability and are doing our utmost to ensure that all the necessary information is provided so that grants can be properly accounted for and acquitted. We suspect that the Darwin Regional Office is so impoverished in the area of financial expertise that they cannot assess adequately the information provided to them. We urge you to bring these matters to the attention of the Minister, Mr Tickner before the situation gets completely out of hand. Already some staff have indicated that they may resign if the present process of harassment continues and we simply do not know what the future holds for us.
Any assistance on this most urgent matter would be appreciated.
Yours faithfully
Pius Tipungwuti

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, will be absent from the chamber today. Senator Cook is interstate on Government business. TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Yesterday in answer to a question from Senator Knowles I made a terrible Freudian slip, which has been well picked up by Hansard, to the effect that Mr Peter McAuley took the proper decision to hand materials over to Mr Brian Burke. Of course, I intended to say Mr Brian Bull, the Commissioner of Police in Western Australia.

—I thank the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs for that clarification. It had us somewhat confused. My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Why did the Minister selectively quote from the front page of yesterday's West Australian newspaper the seventh paragraph instead of the first and the third paragraphs, which stated that the Western Australian Ombudsman had called for a Fitzgerald-style royal commission with extended powers to investigate the secret files of Robert Smith and other related matters? Why was the Minister briefed six times on the subject of one investigation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two different questions there. As to the quotation from the front page of the West Australian, I indicated that my only knowledge of what Mr Freeman had allegedly said about a royal commission was indeed from my reading of the West Australian and that I found the report somewhat confused. In fact, I thought that the Opposition should take several elements of it into account. I never denied that Mr Freeman had called for a royal commission; I simply put it to the Opposition that he had apparently also said that the investigation by the police ought to be allowed to proceed for some three months; that it would be under the surveillance or supervision, in a sense, of his successor as Ombudsman; and that some three months ought to be allowed for that to take place. I was simply pointing that out. There was no attempt on my part to say that Mr Freeman had not called for a royal commission; I was just pointing to that extra element in his statement.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of why I was briefed about a matter relating to telephone interceptions, I am quite often briefed by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) in relation to such inquiries. The particular investigation into these sorts of matters of bugging and telephone intercepts took quite some time. So the AFP kept me well informed. But, as I said yesterday, at no stage was the name `Mr Burke' mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister was briefed six times in one year, in 1988, and Commissioner Bull has now had the file for two years and nothing has happened to date, how come it takes the Ombudsman only two working days to decide that a Fitzgerald-style inquiry is necessary? Has the Minister missed something along the way?
—Those questions ought to be addressed to the Commissioner of Police in Western Australia, not to me.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It is on the subject of petrol taxation. Given that Australia buys so much of its crude oil at world prices-I understand that about one-third of our refinery needs are imported-are relatively low petrol prices in Australia due to relatively low taxes on petrol in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Energy Agency statistics provide a good indication of Australia's comparative position amongst Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries in terms of both taxes as a proportion of petrol prices and prices themselves. The latest published statistics of the International Energy Agency for the first quarter of 1990 indicate that in Australia the percentage of taxes representing revenue collected by both Commonwealth and State governments to petrol prices was 45.5 per cent. This was the third lowest level of taxation of the 23 countries surveyed by the Agency. Australia's taxation collection from petrol was significantly lower than most other OECD countries. Taxation collections in 14 countries were higher than 60 per cent, including Italy at 76.4 per cent, France at 76.2 per cent, Germany at 65.8 per cent, the United Kingdom at 63.1 per cent and Sweden at 61 per cent. Australia has maintained its relative position for the last decade in respect of those sorts of statistics. The relative position for Australia, as determined by taxation percentages on petrol in this period, broadly reflects the relative price position for petrol. Specifically, Australia's petrol prices have been and remained within the lowest four among OECD countries for the last decade.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the other implication in Senator Maguire's question, I point out that the October prices reflect this position, with average Australian prices at US0.64c per litre compared with the United States, 0.35c; Japan, 0.91c; Germany, 0.93c; the United Kingdom, 0.98c; France, 1.14c; and Italy, 1.37c.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Administrative Services aware of the fact that an official from the Comcar depot at Fyshwick has advised hire care businesses in Canberra that unless the owners of those businesses and their drivers are members of the Transport Workers Union of Australia they will be given no Comcar work after this Friday, tomorrow? I ask the Minister: Who initiated this no ticket, no work policy? Why was the no ticket, no work policy not advised in writing to the hire car business operators?
—Shame!

—We hear calls of shame from Opposition senators, all based on the premise that what Senator Parer has said is right. If it is right, it will be a precedent. All I can say to Senator Parer is that I am not aware of this matter. I will try to find out about it as soon as possible and alert him to it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's response that he will investigate the matter and find out about it and let me know. I ask him: If my information is correct, and bearing in mind that the time limit is tomorrow, will he take immediate action to stop this illegal industrial blackmail by someone in his Department and also the thuggery by the Transport Workers Union?

—That is nothing more than an emotional, hypothetical question based on an assumption which has not been tested. The only responsible course of action I can take is to ascertain whether what the honourable senator says is true and alert the Senate as to whether it is or not.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of a report which appeared in yesterday's Australian that Essington Ltd is to withdraw from the Cape York spaceport project? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the reaction there has been to his press release of 18 October in which he called for registrations of interest by all companies interested in participating in the spaceport project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware, of course, of the decision by Essington Ltd, which was reported in the press as Senator Loosley points out. I appreciate the effort put in by that company in getting the project to its current status but I believe that the interests of the project will not be harmed by Essington's action in withdrawing. Indeed, about 10 companies, both local and international, have contacted the Australian Space Office since my press release to which Senator Loosley referred. The project managers, United States Boosters Inc. (USBI) of the United States of America, visited here last week and have confirmed the commercial viability of the project.

ANSWER.PARA: There appears to be a considerable level of interest in the project from the business community now that the US Government has given approval for the involvement of United Technologies as manager of the project. An Australian Government delegation is now travelling to Tokyo, Washington, Moscow and Paris for a series of meetings to progress a wide range of intergovernmental issues raised by the project. Congressman Robert Roe of the United States House Committee on Science and Technology is presently in Australia with a delegation and inspected the Cape York site, I think yesterday, and I shall meet with the congressman next week.

While the Government is offering all the encouragement it can and doing what it can to facilitate the project, I again have to stress that it will not proceed without a satisfactory outcome of the environmental impact study currently under way, without agreement being reached with the Aboriginal community and without a firm belief that the parties undertaking the project have the financial strength to see it through.

I must say that the spaceport since the first feasibility studies were done has had to go through a few hoops. Some of those hoops have been gone through. The major hoop was getting the agreement of the United States Government to allow the participation of the American project manager. There were also considerable negotiations with the Soviet Government about the use of Soviet rockets, which are an integral part of the proposal. As I have indicated, there are still problems to be resolved in terms of the site.

The business involvement in the project at the present time is not finalised. The project is and will continue to be a private venture and I stress again that the Government's role is that of facilitator and it will not be taking an equity position in the project directly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question today is not directed to Senator Button but to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Does the Minister agree that the scope of the secrecy provisions of the National Crime Authority Act in effect prevent the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority carrying out its statutory duty to supervise the NCA? Does the Minister agree that amendments are necessary to widen the scope of information available to the Committee subject to an obligation on the Committee and its members not to disclose matters which would prejudice legal proceedings, the operations of the NCA or the safety and/or legal rights of persons identified in the material?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Parliament has in its legislation to do with the National Crime Authority tried to strike a very difficult balance. There is a need to ensure that that Authority acts with the requisite degree of secrecy in order to secure victory in the fight against organised crime, particularly drug trafficking, and for that reason certain secrecy provisions of a strong kind were inserted into that Act by this Parliament, but at the same time Parliament has, quite rightly, given the extraordinary powers wielded by the National Crime Authority, given to one of its own joint parliamentary committees a supervisory role. In order to discharge that role it has to have access to certain information.

ANSWER.PARA: Quite clearly, in trying to strike that balance the Parliament has set down certain provisions. The result of the application of those provisions may not always be satisfactory and I believe that, if one were to look at those provisions again, the sorts of matters which Senator Spindler adverted to would certainly be relevant factors such as not jeopardising the operations of the National Crime Authority in ensuring the safety of persons working for the National Crime Authority and of witnesses who might come before it. Of course, Senator Spindler would not want any action to be able to be taken by a parliamentary committee which might jeopardise criminal prosecutions instituted as a result of investigations undertaken by the Authority which hands over its brief, of course, to the Director of Public Prosecutions for prosecution.

I understand Senator Spindler's concern in these matters. I think he has raised very interesting criteria that might be used in looking at striking that balance. I am sure the Attorney-General would be extremely happy to discuss Senator Spindler's concerns with a view to ensuring that Parliament gets that balance right.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer to a report in the Australian of 9 November 1990 which outlines the dangers of ultraviolet light from suntan parlours, solariums and home sunlamps. Is it a fact that ultraviolet B rays are carcinogenic and that ultraviolet A rays can augment the cancer-producing effects of ultraviolet B? Will the Federal Government or any of its agencies be warning the public about the dangers of so-called safe ways of tanning?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret to say that I seem to have come into the chamber without my brief on community services and health matters. I had it in the chamber earlier when we were dealing with the Estimates Committee.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no doubt that exposure to harmful rays in the fashionable suntan parlour industry is a matter of concern because of the damaging effect of exposure to the particular rays emanating from the suntanning machines. However, I will guarantee to have an answer for Senator Colston which I might seek the leave of the Senate to read at the conclusion of the formal Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to his answer to a question from Senator Parer on Tuesday relating to redundancy payments. Now that the Minister has had the opportunity to consider the purpose of redundancy payments, will he please explain to the Senate why redundancy payments are being paid to drivers who are presumably redundant but who are then being replaced?
—That has already been answered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague Senator Collins has said, this is a question that has already been answered.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The basic point is that if Opposition members want an answer I will give them one, but I am not going to try to shout over the rabble on the other side.

ANSWER.PARA: The basic and first point to make-one that the Opposition should understand but probably does not-is that there is a common approach to redundancies, not only in the public sector but also in the private sector. If one wants to change the culture of an organisation or if one wants to change the direction of an organisation, whether it is in the private sector or the public sector, in terms of normal industrial processes-ones that have been adopted in terms of Comcar in this particular instance-the redundancy approach is very commonly used.

What Comcar has done here is nothing different from what any private sector organisation could do and, in effect, what similar private sector organisations are doing. There have been redundancies and people have left the organisation. As I say, it is similar to large public and private organisations.

It is a common practice and a normal industrial practice. In this case there was a review of Comcar operations, one that Senator Parer, even with little knowledge of the area, would understand. As a consequence of that review, there was a proposal which is being adopted and is being implemented in order to rearrange both working hours and conditions of the organisation and, in the process, to ensure that redundant drivers are given a chance to get out with some dignity.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not redundant if they are being replaced.

—I am attempting to answer this question, but Senator Hill, with some sort of exuberance, keeps interjecting. The points I make are, first, that drivers have taken redundancy packages; secondly, some extra drivers have been recruited; and, thirdly, as is happening in other large public organisations of a similar nature, redundancy packages were offered and were accepted. It is quite obvious that the Opposition is not seriously looking for an answer to this question, and, having said that, that is all I shall say.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Spain, led by the President of the Senate, His Excellency Senator Juan Jose Laborda. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate and trust that your visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite the President of the Senate to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr President Laborda thereupon entered the chamber, and was seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given that one of the options in the Gulf being considered by the United States (US) is an attack on Iraq, and that Australia would presumably support such a move, how would the multinational force obtain United Nations (UN) legitimacy for such an attack in terms of the United Nations charter, given that there would need to be an explicit resolution passed by the Security Council and that France and China would possibly not support it? Is it true that the United States, the United Kingdom and the French military staff commands are combining their resources into something approximating a de facto United Nations staff command or, at the very least, an informal `crisis' committee, and are attempts being made to activate the United Nations Military Staff Committee, which currently exists in name only? I further ask the Minister what the United Nations Security Council can do to prevent a military strike by the United States and other nations. Finally, will the Australian Government consider withdrawing its support from the multinational force, seeing that such a force has no legitimacy to wage war?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first question, Australia has of course consistently supported a peaceful resolution of the Gulf crisis. If, however, as the Prime Minister and I and the Minister for Defence have said, the sanctions strategy and associated diplomacy do not achieve the objectives to which the international community is committed, we have to be prepared to contemplate military action, if that is the only course left which will ensure Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait.

ANSWER.PARA: As to Australia's likely response in the event that military action does occur, which we all hope it will not, I have said many times that this is an issue which the Government will make considered decisions about on the basis of all the circumstances applicable at the time, and no assumptions either way should be made at this time.

There is no reason for assuming that a further explicit United Nations Security Council resolution would be strictly necessary to confer legitimacy, as Senator Vallentine described it, for the conduct of military action against Iraq. Article 51 of the Charter, which, it will be recalled, was specifically affirmed by the original resolution 661, makes it very clear that the United Nations Charter does contemplate military action in response to such circumstances as the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. If there were to be a further specific resolution of the Security Council, it would no doubt be to authorise the use of force against Iraq pursuant to Article 42 of Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter. This would need nine affirmative votes in the Council and no veto by one of the permanent five. There are no such proposals before the Council at this moment, but that is not to say that there may not be. France and China, which Senator Vallentine specifically referred to, have supported all Security Council resolutions on the crisis to date, and I have no evidence to suggest that they would necessarily oppose a resolution authorising force were the Security Council to consider one.

As to the second question, there is no joint command for the multinational naval force (MNF). There are well established procedures for coordination among the participants in the MNF, but I should stress again that Australian naval deployment in the Gulf is under Australian national command.

As for the forces on the ground in Saudi Arabia, I am not aware that the United States, the United Kingdom and France have established a joint command of the kind that Senator Vallentine refers to. I should say that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has expressed its interest in having the UN Military Staff Committee, comprising military representatives from the permanent five members of the Security Council, assume a greater role in this crisis. That Committee meets regularly but has not yet moved to play a role in resolving it.

As to the third question, from my discussions in Washington and in New York I know that the United States is acutely conscious of the need to maintain the international coalition against Iraq, particularly through the United Nations. This will be a factor the US will obviously be considering very seriously in any new move it might make to resolve the crisis. As was evident during the recent consultations of US Secretary of State, Mr Baker, in a number of Middle East and European capitals over the last few days, the United States still has under very active consideration the possibility of obtaining more specific UN Security Council authority if any military action does become necessary.

Finally, the Australian Government will not consider withdrawing its support for the multinational naval force. That operation and Australian involvement in it is in full conformity with the United Nations Charter. The MNF is acting legitimately and fully in accordance with binding resolutions of the Security Council.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I ask the Minister whether he is aware that, at a recent pensioner rally in Sydney, his Parliamentary Secretary, Mr Sciacca, told pensioners:

QUESTION.PARA: A lot of you won't understand this, I can see you going . . .

And he then proceeded to tap the side of his head implying that those present were clearly stupid. Is the Minister aware that the rally, which started relatively peacefully, ended in a near riot after being addressed by the Minister's Parliamentary Secretary?

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, ha, ha!
—The Minister can read the Australian if he does not want to take my word for it.
—The Australian was there, was it? It would know about it!

—Senator Richardson was there, was he? So he would know all about it as well. The Minister said recently that the Government had failed to sell its policies. Is the Parliamentary Secretary's behaviour an example of what the Minister had in mind? What action does the Minister intend to take to ensure that the type of debacle caused in Sydney on 26 October does not occur again? Do Mr Sciacca's actions simply lend support to the recent remarks of John Gayler, who described Mr Sciacca as totally lacking ability for his job as Parliamentary Secretary and as unheard of in his electorate because he spends 60 per cent of his time politicking and the rest overseas? Can the Minister confirm that these are credentials for elevation within the right wing faction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can imagine why Senator Alston, fresh from his triumph in the joint party room-his and his Leader's-would get up to ask this question.
—Thuggery.

—No, it is all right; I am not in a ruthless mode today. One has to be continually very kind to Senator Alston to keep him going. I get up each morning and thank God that I got him as my shadow. First off we are told that Mr Sciacca tapped his head and indicated to a group of pensioners at Sydney Town Hall that in some way they were stupid or whatever. The reality is that what occurred at the meeting is that one among the number at the back of the crowd had made a circular motion with his finger at the side of his head to Mr Sciacca and Mr Sciacca responded in a similar fashion. People in the front who could not see what happened at the back therefore were getting themselves aggrieved.

ANSWER.PARA: By the way, I really wonder about the `near riot'. At the Sydney Town Hall on the Friday the week after the Budget, I attended a meeting where there were 2,000 to 3,000 very angry pensioners. They gave me a very hard time indeed. When Mr Sciacca attended this rally, as Senator Alston calls it, even though it was organised by the same people only 160 attended, because in the course of the two months I, other members of the Government, Mr Sciacca and a host of people had explained those policies-which I might say Senator Alston supported up until he was rolled by the National Party. Fortunately, because we were successful in getting that message over, only 160 people could attend. If we can get the number down from 3,000 to 160, it shows that we are doing our job.

So what action will I take? I will encourage Mr Sciacca to do more of what he has been doing because he is doing exactly what we want. Those opposite will see that, for all the efforts that they make, the sad thing is that their audience was down to a lousy 160. If I had a head like that, I would not tap it; I would not advertise. I just have to say that, as far as Mr Gayler's comments are concerned, I did actually make some comments yesterday. I do not seek to add to them except to say that I would prefer to take the view that the Premier of Queensland takes of Mr Sciacca than the view of Mr Gayler, and I think that is in accord with the wishes of 99 per cent of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware of Australia's having achieved a world record in the environmentally friendly activity of aluminium can collecting? Can he inform the Senate of the benefits of this activity and what more can be done to encourage recycling?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Zakharov drew this matter to my attention because Australia's 1989 recovery rate for aluminium beverage cans was 62 per cent, and that is the highest in the Western world from voluntary or non-deposit legislated schemes. It is, of course, an incredible result and a credit to all concerned. It can be attributed to the comprehensive collection programs established by the industry itself which include continuing education and promotion, the intrinsic value of aluminium scrap, because it is worth something, and of course the increasing environmental awareness of Australians. The recovery and processing of aluminium cans has benefits in terms of conservation of natural resources and, of course, savings from reduced waste disposal. Energy savings are significant as only 5 per cent of the energy required to produce a can from raw material is needed to produce one by recycling. An indirect benefit of lower energy consumption is, of course, a lower rate of greenhouse gas emissions-and, of course, we are all trying to achieve that.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's excellent record in this area of the collection of aluminium cans is, however, not matched by a record with overall waste because the volumes overall of waste are still rising. Some major waste materials are hardly recycled at all in this country as yet. I refer, of course, to plastics in particular and also to demolition waste. Fortunately, because of the activities of former Labor Senator and Minister Susan Ryan, who now heads the Plastics Institute of Australia Inc., we are now seeing a change in the attitude of the plastics industry and I am very confident that we will get some progress in that area very soon.

As a first step we have been having some round table meetings with industry and the States to discuss these issues to try to develop a national waste minimisation and recycling strategy. We will have to make sure that our collection systems around Australia from households in particular as well as from industry are improved dramatically if any strategy is to work. I am certain that a strengthened commitment to recycling will come out of the development of the strategy, and I hope that it can be adopted by the middle of next year and be agreed to by industry, conservation groups, State and Territory governments-and, most of all, by the public who in the end will have to contribute most of the work.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL UNION FOR THE CONSERVATION OF NATURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. Is the Minister aware that the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources is holding its conference in Perth later this month? In view of delegations of indigenous people representing their nations, including representation from Aboriginals by Mrs Lois O'Donoghue and others, is the Minister aware that Australia's smallest minority and its northernmost citizens, the Torres Strait Islanders, have not received an invitation? Will the Minister arrange to have included a small delegation of Islanders to represent their people at this conference?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not aware of this conference. I would have to put a slight caveat on any undertakings I give for the obvious reason that invitations to this conference are being issued by the people who are organising it. Without knowing anything about it, I can fairly firmly say that it is not the Commonwealth Government. No doubt Senator Boswell has had representations from his constituents in the Torres Strait regarding this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: I will certainly make inquiries about this conference. I will ascertain who is organising it and who is responsible for issuing the invitations. It is probably a private organisation that has nothing to do with the Commonwealth. If that is the case, I will make inquiries as to how it is possible for invitations, if that is appropriate, to be given to people from the Torres Strait.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to a report in Monday's Sydney Morning Herald of 12 November 1990 concerning the control of genetic engineering. Is the Minister aware of a release of a genetically modified bacterium into the South Australian environment in order to test its control of the wheat disease `take-all'? Will the Minister explain to the Senate if the modified bacterium poses a danger to the environment because of those genetic modifications?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say at the outset that it is good to get a question that is constructive and also based on fact. Senator Crowley is, in fact, right in the question that she asks. A team of scientists, trialling at the moment at the Roseworthy College in South Australia and working from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Division of Soils, has isolated a naturally occurring strain of soil bacteria which may reduce the disease in wheat called `take-all'. This disease is a rather enormous one and may decrease yields by more than 50 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: The bacterium which has been isolated is from the pseudomonas group and was discovered by Dr Ryder's group in the soil around wheat roots in Australia. This is very important. It is a natural biological control. The main purpose of the continuing research is to track the bacterium in the soil so that the scientists can answer questions on its ecology, how far it moves, how quickly the bacteria multiply, their survival, and on which part of the plant root they act to curb `take-all'.

Tracking this strain of bacteria in the soil is difficult and that is why scientists have had to tag two artificial genetic tags onto the bacterium. The tags have been tested extensively in the United States of America. They are attached to the bacteria in order to distinguish them from other soil bacteria, which are also naturally occurring. The main reason for this is that there is a concern that the genetic tags on the bacteria may move into water systems or affect other soil processes.

Scientists from the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee (GMAC) have considered this particular concern and are confident from both laboratory and field tests in the USA that the modified bacterium does not, of its own accord, move more than a few centimetres and as a consequence will not cause problems. Given that the GMAC has approved the testing in South Australia, we are looking very closely at the testing and the trialling which is going on at the Roseworthy College with a view to ensuring that all assistance can be given to perfecting this particular bacterium which may reduce `take-all' disease levels in wheat crops.

In terms of the enormous impact of this development, when it is considered that it could save Australian wheat farmers in the vicinity of $500m per annum, it is quite obvious that the Government will take a close and continuing interest in the developments here.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to either the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Customs or the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, depending on which of them is prepared to face up to the problem. In view of repeated assurances by both the Government and the Federal Airports Corporation that security at international airports, particularly Sydney, is satisfactory-that was in response to my repeated questions about last year's damning report revealing gross inadequacies by the Auditor-General-what does the Government now intend to do about today's report by a House of Representatives committee revealing continuing inadequacies on security and calling for government action to improve airport security, particularly in view of the Chairman's statement that an increasing amount of drugs is being smuggled into Australia and that probably only 15 per cent is being caught, but that the Government has no idea what quantities of drugs are getting in?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I sat here for five years and for four of those years I listened to Senator Withers in Question Time being asked questions which arose from the morning's newspapers to which he always responded by saying, `I never read the newspapers'. I have to say that I do not read reports of the parliamentary committees which were published this morning.
—I do.
—I think it would be a mistake for any Minister in this Government to respond on the basis of a departmental note or a cursory reading of a parliamentary committee report published today.

ANSWER.PARA: However, let me say that after days of questioning at the Estimates Committee in relation to the Customs part of this question, Senator Baume knows perfectly well that the Customs strategy has been one of targeting on the basis of intelligence, particular cargoes, passengers and so on. As I understood it, by the virile nodding of his head at the Estimates Committee and other comments he made, Senator Baume approved of that strategy. In so far as there may be some fresh allegations in the report published today, I am sure that Senator Collins and I will address them and give the honourable senator a positive and appropriate answer as early as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services to the decision last year of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission determining family day care givers as employees and the current uncertain situation while awaiting the results of an appeal against that decision. I also refer the Minister to the indication given to him by the Metropolitan Municipal Association Inc. of Victoria that a significant number of local councils will abandon family day care if appropriate funding mechanisms are not put in place if care givers are determined to be employees and are subsequently granted the award wage. I ask the Minister: First, as the Government has known for some time of the likelihood of a decision favourable to care givers, has it set aside any funds to cover the potential shortfall to be incurred by local councils as a result of increased labour costs? Secondly, what action has the Government taken to ensure that any decision favourable to care givers does not result in substantial fee increases for parents with their children in family day care centres? Finally, will the Minister give his firm assurance that, in the event of a decision favourable to care givers, the Government will maintain the viability of family day care services and ensure that none of these services need close?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some material that may be of assistance to Senator Lees in answer to her question. In September 1989 Commissioner Brown found that family day carers in Victoria and Tasmania were employees of the councils administering family day care schemes. That decision opened the way for an award to be struck for family day carers in those States. However, as the honourable senator knows, that decision was appealed to the Full Bench of the Industrial Relations Commission by the Victorian and Tasmanian councils. The decision on that appeal has been reserved and it is not known when the decision might be handed down. Further, even if the Commission dismisses the appeal this would merely open the way for an award; it would not make an award. The process could therefore take a considerable time. There has been no setting aside of funds to cover the cost of an outcome which is still surrounded by so much uncertainty. However, the Government is very concerned that the uncertainty surrounding the decision should not be unfairly exploited by either the councils or the unions. The needs of parents, children and carers should be uppermost.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has made it clear that it remains committed to family day care as a central component of its provision of child-care. The Government has written to all councils requesting them not to exploit the current uncertainty and informing them that the Government remains willing to work with them to guarantee the future of family day care. I understand that the Minister has also written to all carers in Tasmania and Victoria in similar terms. Significant improvements in the fee relief system announced during the Budget will also help lift the remuneration of carers without reducing affordability for parents.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the crisis in our trade negotiations with Europe arising in the Uruguay Round. What degree of flexibility, in the Australian Government's assessment, is there in the negotiating position of the European Community now that the European Community has belatedly put forward a totally inadequate offer of a 30 per cent cut in subsidies-a cut which even the United States Agriculture Secretary, Clayton Yeutter, derisively has criticised as `almost a non-offer'? How close is the risk of a complete breakdown of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks? I am aware that there may well be rapid developments even in the last few hours before the meeting. Is there, in the words of Dr Blewett, `no chance of reaching a final conclusion' at the December meeting? Will the Prime Minister enter the process and attend the talks in Brussels next month or a summit meeting? What solutions will the Australian Government now offer to resolve this crisis in Australia's best interests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regrettably, as a result of the intransigent position taken by the Europeans, the outlook for the conclusion of the Uruguay Round, at least by the scheduled conclusion date of 7 December, does look very gloomy indeed. It is at the point now of requiring not just six runs off every ball but about eight, which means that it can be done only with four runs plus four overthrows. Obviously that is not realistic in the time available.

ANSWER.PARA: That is not to say that the Round is necessarily doomed to complete failure. There is the option of spilling over to next year, although, if negotiations run longer than the end of March next year, there is the necessity for the United States Congress to confer new negotiating authority upon the executive, which will create its own new series of difficulties and dilemmas.

As to what flexibility there may be in the European position, it is probably not helpful for me to speculate about that. To some extent it is being domestically driven obviously by the German elections in the first week of December, but there are some very intransigent positions that have been mapped out by other countries within the Community and it will be difficult to shift them.

The most important way in which we and other countries can contribute to shifting the Europeans is to do what we have been doing: that is, making very clear the total irrationality of the European position, given the relative insignificance of agriculture-certainly in their exports and even, to a significant extent, in their gross domestic product as compared with manufactures and services-and making it absolutely plain to the Europeans that they simply cannot expect any reasonable result in the Round in terms of general tariff reductions, intellectual property, trade and services or any of the other things the developed countries want, unless they are prepared to make some fundamental moves forward in the area of agriculture.

Beyond that, there is not a great deal that I can say. As to whether the Prime Minister might attend some crisis meeting on this or the ministerial meeting itself, that is a matter to which he is giving some consideration in consultation with other relevant heads of government. It may be, I fear, too late, given the complexity of the negotiation and the difficulty of bringing a negotiation that extends across 15 subject areas to fruition by that time scale that we are talking about, and it may not be productive to have such a meeting. Then, again, it might be. That is a matter which is under active consideration at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. It concerns child-care services available for women returning to the work force. Is the Minister satisfied with the level of Government subsidised child-care centres presently available to these women? Is the Minister able to provide details of the percentage of supporting parents who are currently using the services of the centres?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will never be fully satisfied with the level of child-care available to working families in Australia, despite the very substantial progress made since 1983. When the Government came to office there were only 46,000 funded child-care places in Australia. That figure has now more than doubled to 122,000 such places. The system of affordable, quality, community based child-care that this Government has developed since 1983 is recognised as one of the best in the world. That record on child-care received a ringing endorsement during the election when the Opposition's regressive tax rebate policy was rejected.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government recognises that more needs to be done. During the election the Government promised a further massive growth strategy of 78,000 places. By 1995-96 we estimate that a quarter of a million funded child-care places will be available in Australia-five times the number available when we came to office. It is estimated that more than one quarter of all children in funded services are from sole parent families. These parents in particular benefit from the generous fee relief system introduced by this Government. During the election the Government also announced sweeping changes to the fee relief system. An estimated 90,000 families with children in currently funded services will benefit from the new fee relief. A further 35,000 families with children in commercial centres also stand to benefit from 1 January 1991.

The Government is not satisfied with the current availability of child-care. We are satisfied with the strategies we have in place to bring affordable quality care within the reach of many more Australian families.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has seen or had reported to him the comments made some weeks ago by Dr John Stocker when, in giving evidence to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts of this Parliament on behalf of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Capital expenditure is where there really is a crisis in the organisation at the moment.

The report further stated that capital investments as distinct from recurrent expenses were depreciating at $30m a year and being replaced at only $20m. I therefore ask: Has the Minister studied the points made in the CSIRO submission? Does scientific research have any priority for capital funding? Will the Government introduce a capacity for CSIRO to argue special cases for extra capital funds so that the intellectual capital of the organisation can be sustained and regenerated?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know in what form, but I have certainly had Dr Stocker's remarks drawn to my attention. In so far as he says that capital expenditure is a problem, if I can use a colloquialism, he is not Robinson Crusoe. That is a problem across a wide range of institutions and in the corporate sector. However, this issue has come to the Government's attention and is currently being examined. I cannot foreshadow the Government's decisions on these issues, but I think they are being examined in a favourable environment, if I can put it that way. When I say `favourable environment', that does not mean that the outcomes which any organisation such as CSIRO might seek will be agreed to. I think that there is a sensible approach led by my colleague Mr Crean in terms of providing a satisfactory response to that question.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that in a recent news report a number of post offices in all States were described as `antiquated buildings' to be sold off in the next 12 months? Given the architectural heritage value of many of Australia's post offices, some of which have National Trust listing, what guarantees will the Minister seek to ensure that these buildings are not arbitrarily disposed of and that Australia Post recognises their heritage value?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia Post is indeed engaged in doing this. At a recent auction--
—Why?

—To rationalise its services and to provide revenue for creating new ones. Australia Post has recently sold, I think, 30 post offices in Victoria for a total revenue collection of about $16m. I think yesterday it auctioned 25 post offices in New South Wales. As all honourable senators will be aware, particularly if they have travelled in country Australia very much, very many of these post offices are quite irreplaceable in terms of their heritage value. That is one of the reasons why Australia Post is doing this. Many of the offices-and there are in excess of 1,000 owned by Australia Post around Australia-that are owned by Australia Post are 60 years of age or older and are now in a state where it is simply not economical or practicable to upgrade them to the point where Australia Post can usefully use them.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia Post has assured me through the Minister for Land Transport, Mr Brown, that it is very conscious of the heritage value of all of these properties. I can assure Senator Reynolds that Australia Post has given a guarantee that the preservation of the heritage value of these buildings, where that is in fact the case under relevant legislation, is being taken into account in the sale of each one of those properties where the building has a recognised heritage value.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce advise the Senate when he expects a recovery in the Australian economy and what is the basis for determining his forecast date?

—I said in this chamber the other day that the art of forecasting is to give a date and an outcome but not put them both together. I am certainly not going to put them both together. I believe there will be an improvement in the Australian economy next year--
—Recovery or improvement?

—I said an improvement. Identifying the elements and extent of that is not something about which I can speculate. Just as particular industries went into that downturn in the Australian economy at different times and with different levels of severity, I expect that they will come out of that downturn at different times and with different levels of severity. That makes speculation in order to answer a bland question, such as Senator Tambling is sometimes given to asking, a very difficult task and I do not propose to embark upon it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I notice that the Minister was very cautious in his use of the word `improvement'. Why does he therefore hold a view different from that of the Prime Minister who, in Question Time today in the House of Representatives, said that he expected a recovery in the economy in mid-1991. Why does the Minister hold a view different from Mr Hawke and is there any consistency of opinion amongst his ministerial colleagues?
—People talk about the waste of time during Question Time and I do not think we should waste it with all of this semantic rubbish.
—It is not semantic rubbish; that is what the Prime Minister said.

—If the honourable senator finds that exciting he will leave Question Time feeling excited. The point is that there is very little, or no, difference between the Prime Minister's views and mine, or amongst Ministers, concerning this issue.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Traditionally, articles sent by sea mail have cost less than if they were sent air mail. For example, last year a greeting card endorsed `card only' cost 65c to send by sea mail to England and 70c to send air mail. Could the honourable senator explain to the Senate why Christmas greeting cards cost 95c to send sea mail to England this year but only 90c to send by air mail?
—No, the senator cannot but the senator will.

—At this stage in Question Time I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health whether he has an answer in relation to the question I asked earlier about ultraviolet lights and sun lamps?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am now in a position to answer the question asked earlier by Senator Colston. The National Health and Medical Research Council has issued a warning statement concerning suntanning parlours, solaria and home tanning equipment. It is an important statement which was prepared in consultation with the Australasian College of Dermatologists and the Australian Cancer Society as part of their respective campaigns.

ANSWER.PARA: Council recommended the following forms of sun protection; avoiding sunlight, in particular between the hours of 11 a.m. and 3 p.m; wearing clothing of tightly woven fabric and broad-brimmed hats; covering unprotected parts of the body with a broad spectrum sun screen of SPF 15 or SPF 15+; further, and relevantly to Senator Colston's question, avoiding artificial forms of ultraviolet A and ultraviolet B radiation as used in suntanning parlours, solaria and home tanning equipment. There is overwhelming evidence that intentional and unintentional exposure to sunlight is linked to the development of the more common types of skin cancer and most melanomas. Skin cancer causes the death of 1,000 Australians per year, with a further 150,000 people presenting annually for treatment.

Ultraviolet B, the burning rays, are the most carcinogenic; however, recent studies indicate that ultraviolet A, or lower energy rays, can augment the cancer producing effects of ultraviolet B. In addition ultraviolet A rays can penetrate the top layer of the skin and cause damage to the lower layer, leading to changes in the skin which were previously attributed to the effects of ageing. The Federal Government, under the national better health program, is targeting preventable cancers as an area of priority. I believe Senator Colston will welcome that.

The initiatives being taken indicate that there is no safe way to tan and there are associated risks. Therefore, I have requested the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to place the safety of solaria on the agenda of the Commonwealth-State Consumer Products Advisory Committee and will seek advice from that committee on any uniform action that should be taken by the Commonwealth to improve the safety standards of tanning centres.

I have also requested the issue of advertising claims that solaria tanning methods are safe to be referred to the Trade Practices Commission for investigation of possible breaches of the Trade Practices Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that answer should have taken place after Question Time, so I will allow another question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, who, as the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, was closely involved in the decision to nominate Shark Bay for World Heritage listing. Did the Commonwealth decide to nominate Shark Bay on its own initiative or at the request of the Western Australian Government? Has the Western Australian Government ever asked the Commonwealth not to proceed with the listing?

—The Commonwealth discussed the nomination of Shark Bay with the Western Australian Government over quite a long time and, as I understand the situation, came to an agreement with the Western Australian Government. I cannot give the honourable senator a date, although I will seek it for him. The honourable senator asked whether the Western Australian Government ever requested the Commonwealth not to list it. I think that the new Premier, Dr Carmen Lawrence, was more inclined to do it than either of her predecessors. Certainly, as I understand it, the Western Australian Government has agreed.
