—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister did not answer the second part of my question. I direct him to that. As a supplementary question to the first part, if there was a joint discussion, who initiated it?
—I did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In Question Time today Senator Parer in his normal way made some allegations about Comcar. I am advised by Comcar that it would not discriminate in placing work with hire car companies on the basis of union membership, but only on the contract prices offered. The demands alleged by Senator Parer, I am further advised, were not made by Comcar. I am also advised that Comcar management is in contact with the hire car companies to discuss the situation and assure them of this.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members-Who made them?

TALK.START.PARA: —You bloody well find out.
—Order!
—Mr President, I withdraw.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Newman proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The requirement for the Prime Minister to honour the promise he made to the veteran community at the Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital on 24 April 1989, namely that-

`. . . no Repatriation General Hospital will be transferred to a State until a satisfactory agreement has been reached on matters such as priority of access, and quality of health care for veterans and war widows, and unless the interests of hospital staff have been adequately safeguarded, and no formal decision will be taken if the RSL has reasonable cause for dissatisfaction with the proposed arrangements . . .'
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, does this promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) remind you of any other promise that the Prime Minister has made publicly in recent times? To me, and to those on this side of the House, this is a great, resounding reminder of what the Prime Minister promised to the children of Australia, and this promise appears also to be inoperable.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Humphreys, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, only recently-in fact, this year-told the veterans' community in Melbourne a totally different story. When he was addressing the veterans at the Returned Services League State Conference in July in Melbourne, he said:
. . . and don't, please, think that by burying your heads in the sand or writing furious articles this proposal will go away. It won't. It's the right way to go and the Government is committed to it

So much for the Prime Minister's promise of consultation and saying that the proposal will not go ahead until everybody is satisfied with it. We all know that the word is out that Concord Repatriation Hospital is due to be handed over to the State Government by the end of this financial year if the Federal Government can achieve it. It is hell-bent on it, regardless of the wishes of the veterans of Australia.

Let me remind the Senate that these veterans are old. They need stability. Change is worrying for this age group. These are the people to whom we owe a debt for compensation for war service. These are the men and women who fought for our country. They are very concerned about the Government's proposals. They have reasonable cause for concern. They have reasonable cause for dissatisfaction with the proposed arrangements that the Prime Minister said that he would not go ahead with while they have reasonable concerns.

The veterans' community-the combined organisations-wrote to the Government many months ago. They asked 25 questions and said that, depending upon the results of the answers to those questions, they would make up their position finally on integration of the hospitals. Yet, when finally they got their answer, it was very much along the lines that Senator Tate gave by way of a precis of an answer to Senator McLean in this chamber last week.

Let me raise some of the issues that they asked in their questions. They were concerned about the answer they got about the need for integration. They were told that 50 per cent of all veterans' and war widows' needs were now met by non- repatriation hospitals. The fact of the matter is that those repatriation hospitals may be coping with a smaller percentage of the whole, but the whole has grown. In fact, although the total number of veterans is starting to decline, the Government has a study which demonstrates quite clearly that we will not reach the peak usage of hospital care for veterans until 1995-96. In fact, it will not be until the year 2000 that we are back to the usage level that we are at right now. So much for the Government's statistics. It can use them any way it likes. The veterans know that there will be a growing need for beds, not a diminishing need, as the Government would make out.

The veterans are also concerned at what seems to be indecent haste. The Prime Minister promised that he would not proceed until they were happy, and yet all the Government does is quote the Prime Minister's promise. At the same time, behind the scenes-as was clearly evidenced in the answers given to the Committee of the Whole on the Estimates this morning-the Government is trying very hard, on a bureaucrat to bureaucrat basis, to negotiate a hand-over-or a sell-out, if you like.

One of the answers that the Government gave to the veterans community related to the question, `What if a State government refuses to integrate?'. The Government said that it believed this unlikely, but that if it did occur there would be no option but to close the hospital over time. If I were a veteran, I would be pretty dissatisfied seeing the repatriation hospitals closing because the State governments did not want to take them on board. That is another area of dissatisfaction. Again, in answer to another question, the veterans were told that they would have no representation of any kind on the boards of the hospitals where they would be treated in the future. That does not satisfy them either.

Then in answers to other questions it was clear that, for all the Government says that there will be priority of access, it is impossible for it to guarantee that priority of access. Let us remember that in very few country areas of Australia are there substantial quality private hospitals able to do major surgery. There are very few government hospitals in the bush that can do the sort of specialist surgery that these veterans have been entitled to and expect in their repatriation hospitals. Let us remember that in every State of this country there are enormous queues for elective surgery in the big public hospitals. All that is happening is that veterans will be expected to come in from the bush or from wherever they are if they want major surgery and they will have to join a queue along with every other citizen in the land.

It is a matter of medical judgment whether a patient gets priority in a hospital, and it is totally misleading for the Government to be suggesting that in some way it can achieve a miracle and give a veteran priority of access. I have said that the answer the Government gave about private hospitals is not satisfactory and State hospitals also cannot guarantee that priority. There will be no priority of access to the repatriation hospitals either. That became clear in the answers given by the Minister to the veterans' community. He made it quite clear that that cannot be guaranteed. There is no guarantee that Concord and Greenslopes in particular would not be closed. That came in the answers by the Minister to questions.

The situation regarding outpatients is very unclear. That has been an important part of the care provided by the repatriation general hospitals, and the importance that the outpatient system has given to support of veterans and war widows. Yet the answer that Senator Tate gave to Senator McLean last week-and no doubt we will get it again in his speech today-seems to canvass these same things over and over again without being able to give more detailed information which can and will satisfy the veterans. The Government has been found wanting by the veterans' community, and I believe rightly so. The Government has not really come clean.

The Minister is telling us that the Returned Services League (RSL) is out of touch. One wonders why the Prime Minister in his promise specifically referred to the RSL having reasonable cause for dissatisfaction. In that clause he did not mention the other veterans organisations. He said, `and no formal decision will be taken if the RSL has reasonable cause for dissatisfaction with the proposed arrangement'. Well, the RSL does have reasonable cause for dissatisfaction, but it is not alone. So do the other organisations. The reality is, for example, that members of the Vietnam Veterans Association in Queensland collected a petition of 1,131 signatures which they tried to take to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Humphreys, in his Brisbane office only to find that he refused to see them if they came accompanied by the media. That was the younger generation of veterans making sure that the Minister understood that they, too, were concerned about the integration proposals.

The questionnaire to which I have been referring and which the Minister has answered so inadequately was a matter of great concern not just to the RSL but also to the war widows, to the Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Association, to the prisoner of war bodies, and to members of the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council-all are concerned, not just the RSL. It is right that they should be concerned. They are realists. They can see that the answers are not there; the Government does not have the answers.

Let me remind you, Madam Deputy President, that only this week in the Senate, when I asked Senator Tate about the waiting lists at the Royal Hobart Hospital in our State, I was told they have doubled in this past year, and that the usage of that State Government hospital by veterans has also doubled. What are they going to do in the future as those waiting lists grow? Are they going to be able to give priority of access to our Tasmanian veterans in the Royal Hobart Hospital, our other major government hospital in Tasmania? They cannot give that guarantee, they will not give that guarantee and they would be very foolish if they did. Yet, they are trying to get the veterans' community to understand that they can give that priority of access. All Australians know and it is similar around this country because every State has this problem with waiting lists, yet these veterans are to be shunted off onto those public waiting lists for elective surgery.
Only last month in New South Wales, the Minister for Health, Mr Collins, told the veterans' organisations-and I am quoting from a paper that he put out for them:
. . . that the State does not and will not hold out any guarantee of priority for Veterans . . . must always be in accordance with medical need.
Now, we know that. Why does the Government fool itself or try to fool the veterans?

Mr Humphreys himself is also one of the concerns that the veterans have because, under his responsibility, he is allowing the existing repatriation hospitals to not receive the capital that they need to maintain the quality of care. My colleague Senator Herron will be talking about quality of care in more detail. I draw attention to a couple of letters which relate to Western Australia, but similar situations have been occurring in other States. One is a letter from Mr Humphreys to the honourable member for Canning, Mr Gear. Mr Gear wrote about personal representations for the Returned Services League in Western Australia and about what was happening in Ward 17 in the Hollywood Repatriation General Hospital there. The Minister said he would point out to Mr Gear that:
. . . the case for refurbishing Ward 17 would be stronger if the Western Australian Government agreed at sometime in the future that the hospital must be transferred to the State.
In other words, what a gun at the head there.
Then the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, wrote to Mr Hall, the State President of the RSL in Western Australia, pointing out the same thing:
Mr Humphreys has assured me that until a permanent solution is found his Department will continue to make every effort to maintain the Ward in a serviceable condition.

But that ward does not need servicing; that is one of the wards that have had rain coming in through the roof. I think they have managed to fix some of the rain coming in the roof, but it needs upgrading to give the veterans the quality of care to which they are entitled by their service to this country.

Let me just draw attention to what we discovered today in the Senate, and this is one of the most damning things of all. In the Committee of the Whole, I was trying to find out, from the Minister who represents the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in this place, just what the basis was on which the decision to integrate these hospitals was taken. What did the Minister tell me? It was quite clear from his statements and from the advice from the Department of Veterans' Affairs advisers that the Government had made that decision based on no projections at all as to the usage by veterans of the repatriation hospitals, of the public hospital system or of the private hospital system.

Although they know what the numbers will be from now until 2000 and beyond and have detailed studies of projections, they could not or did not advise the Government as to what their projections would be for the usage of the different systems nor did they give the Government any advice at all on cost-whether there will be an increased cost of the proposals for the new arrangements, whether it will be a cost savings scheme, or what.

Apparently, this Government makes such important and far-reaching decisions, which change a tradition that we have had in this country since the early years of this century, based on no hard evidence or information. I ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President: what sort of decision making is that? So that is where the Government stands in my opinion-totally condemned for its cynical treatment of the men and women who have fought for this country.

The Prime Minister's promises to our children and to our ex-servicemen and women seem to have been made to be broken. The Prime Minister may think that war widows and veterans are just little old ladies and silly old buggers. But Australia will judge this Government on the way it treats its children in poverty and its returned service men and women-in other words, the vulnerable in our community and the people who most have a claim on our care. So, after breaking his solemn promise to our children, the Prime Minister cannot afford to break his pledge to our veterans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will maintain the pledge of this Government, as has been the case with previous governments of both sides in Australia's history, to the veterans who have returned from service overseas, who have put themselves at the service of the country in the defence forces and, of course, those who depend on them, such as their widows. The fact is that the Prime Minister's assurances, which have been given in the quotation to be found in the matter of public importance, are taken extremely seriously by this Government and I am quite sure that the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL) will find in the undertaking that all of its reasonable causes for dissatisfaction will be examined and remedied. The RSL will find that that undertaking will be fulfilled in its entirety. In fact, as shown in a letter from Ian Gollings, the National Secretary of the RSL, published in the Australian Financial Review quite recently, I think 7 November, the RSL recognises the inevitability of integration. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The RSL is not, as a general principle, against the integration proposal in its proper place and at its proper time . . .

He went on to say that it does not think that proper time has arrived because it seeks further assurances from the Government. But the RSL recognises in principle that this particular proposal from the Federal Government is designed to assist those veterans who need hospital treatment to be provided with that treatment in a way that is more accessible to them, particularly in those areas away from the major repatriation hospitals in our major cities.

Many veterans look to receive the hospital care that they need in a location which is close to their family and friends; therefore, being able to be close to their family and friends and the doctors with whom they are familiar is more satisfactory from their point of view. I would have thought, given the ideological assumptions that underlie so much of the activities of the Opposition so far as choice is concerned, for example, that this element of the proposal that goes under the general title of integration would be extremely appealing to it.

The point I am making is that the RSL sees the benefits of this integration proposal and sees integration as inevitable but nevertheless seeks certain assurances. As I have said, the Prime Minister has given an undertaking that any reasonable cause for dissatisfaction will be examined, remedies will be found, the scheme will be modified and the proposals will be adjusted in order to deal with those reasonable concerns of the RSL.

Indeed, Sir William Keys, who is one of the most respected of ex-servicemen in Australia, has said in a letter dated 29 September 1990 that he believes that the Government's offer was most satisfactory in that it included private patient status to give veterans a wider choice of hospitals, including private hospitals and choice of doctor. He went on to say:
We all know that at the present time entitled veterans are seeking hospital treatment in a satisfactory institution closest to their homes.
The benefits are obvious.
It enables the family to keep in close touch with the veteran and it enables him, when he is feeling better, to make brief trips to home.
And it gives him the opportunity of being treated in his own community.
When a person of the status of Sir William Keys recognises the benefits of integration in those terms, one cannot--

TALK.START.PARA: —Stooge.

—Senator Newman says that Sir William Keys is a stooge. I find that a remarkably offensive epithet to throw at a man who has had such a distinguished career both in the armed forces of this country and in service to the returned services community. That is the type of hysterical debating style which Senator Newman engages in, to the great unsettling of members of the veteran community. To call Sir William Keys a stooge of the Government I think is totally offensive, certainly to Sir William and, I am sure, to many members of the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: It is typical of Senator Newman to go around the community making those sorts of comments. It is nice to get them on the public record instead of in the various visits that she makes to the repatriation hospitals around Australia and to meetings of veterans. I note that, when she did the round of State RSL conferences shortly after assuming responsibility for veterans' affairs, she distinguished herself by wearing a badge saying, `Hands Off Our Hospitals'. I wonder whether she told the same unionists of the coalition's policy to contract out hospital services, as indicated in the supplementary notes to the Liberal and National parties' Economic Action Plan. Dr Hewson, who was then the shadow Treasurer, indicated that candidates for contracting out which could be identified included: security in hospitals, repairs and maintenance of hospitals, cleaning in hospitals, catering in hospitals, laundry services in hospitals, waste disposal in hospitals, et cetera.

Senator Newman might wear the badge of the union in order to give herself a little bit of an in with those at these rallies she tries to organise but, in fact, she does not admit to the fact that she would undertake actions, as part of the coalition, which would undermine the very union whose badge she professes to wear.

The fact is that the Federal Government will maintain its responsibility to veterans; it certainly will not pass to the States. It is a very real responsibility which is taken with due gravity by the Government. The whole idea is that veterans should receive treatment where they can perhaps be treated locally and have a choice of doctor and hospital. I know from Tasmanian experience that travelling down the Midlands Highway from the north or across the Bass Highway from the north-west to be treated in the repatriation hospital in Hobart means a lot of travel, inconvenience and difficulty for them and their relatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they don't have to under the current arrangements.
—That is right. We are saying there should be a reinforcement of that obvious desire by veterans in relation to the proposals, which, as I say, are entitled `integration'.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the priority of access question is concerned, quite clearly one is in a situation where the repatriation services which will be available for veterans will be organised in a way which ensures that a veteran can receive the sort of hospital treatment that is assessed by his proper medical advisers as being required. Whether that is in a repatriation hospital, as a private patient in a public hospital, or as a private patient in a private hospital, the fact is that the Australian Government will honour its obligations to ensure that a veteran receives the treatment in hospital that is required. As I say, it can be by way of various places of treatment being provided. As there is some difficulty in some instances in getting access to a hospital bed, the private hospital sector can then be looked at and, as a private patient, the veteran would be treated within that private hospital.

In relation to the question which is put in the matter of public importance about the interests of hospital staff being adequately safeguarded, once again we have a process of consultation taking place, quite properly, by the Government in order to ensure that staff interests are, indeed, properly protected. Over recent months the Commonwealth officers have been discussing these matters with both the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the relevant unions.

I am pleased to say that these negotiations-and Senator Newman must know this-have resulted in a very large measure of agreement. The few remaining issues will be discussed directly by the ACTU and the unions with Ministers. I believe that even next week it is hoped that particular meeting can be arranged so we can move to a final resolution of the staffing questions. These are very real concerns and they need to be dealt with in a proper and fair manner. I am confident that the ACTU, the unions and the Ministers will come to such a resolution next week.

I believe that the integration proposal can be made to work in a way which will derive a lot of support not only from the official organisations of the veterans' communities but also from those many veterans who do not belong to particular organisations but nevertheless need to have their voices heard and their concerns addressed.

The alternative use of the hospital system, which I believe Senator Newman speaks about, where more members of the general community go into the repatriation hospitals in order to keep those hospitals functioning, is something that I do not believe the Government nor, I would have thought, the Opposition should accept. There is no reason for this, particularly in light of the new federalism which is bringing an era of commonsense to the arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States as to which government ought to undertake the provision of certain services. I would have thought the idea of having general community patients going into repatriation hospitals in any great numbers would go against the general policy, which is that the provision of public hospital services should be by the States concerned for their communities.

I believe that the final matter which Senator Newman raised, which was the question of the Government making decisions without proper costings-she claimed-being available to justify those decisions, reveals how driven the Opposition is by monetary and financial considerations. The fact is that this Government can come to a policy decision which it knows to be right, useful and beneficial for veterans. The consequential effects of that decision in relation to the costs and the financing are matters which can then be dealt with. But these decisions were not taken in order to achieve certain cost savings; they were taken in order to provide a better service. That is the order of the consideration of these matters by the Government.

The former shadow Minister, now Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Fischer, is reported in the Mercury of 17 March 1989 as saying that integration would be more valid when the number of veterans, nationally, dropped below 10,000. Unless we become involved in another war, we can expect to get below 10,000 veterans with theatre of war qualifying service some time around 2025 or 2030. I do not know whether Senator Newman would agree with that particular pronouncement by Mr Fischer-whether that is the coalition's timeframe for integration or whether she has some other timeframe in mind. But it is quite clear that that is an inordinately stupid timeframe for integration.

The timeframe set down by the Government is one that is being negotiated with the States. It is a matter for agreement with the States. Nobody can be bludgeoned into the particular series of agreements being negotiated in the various jurisdictions by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) together with the various health Ministers in the various States of Australia.

As those agreements move closer to being negotiated to conclusion, there will be public statements from time to time, such as the one by Mr Collins, which can be interpreted in a negative fashion. I believe they are just part of the negotiating stance in these final crucial stages. I believe that Mr Collins, together with Mr Humphreys, will be able to reach a resolution of the matters which will enable veterans-for example in New South Wales-to receive the hospital care and treatment which they deserve given their history of service to the Australian community, even to the stage of putting themselves in great peril and jeopardy and being in a position where they could be killed in conflict.

That gives rise to certain obligations in the Australian community. The responsibility to meet those obligations is fairly and squarely on the Commonwealth Government. It will undertake those responsibilities; it will never shirk them. But it believes that it can, in a practical sense, discharge those responsibilities in a cooperative and collaborative agreement with the various State governments. That is what is being negotiated now. I believe that the reasonable assurances the RSL seeks in these matters can and will be given in a way which ensures that veterans are provided with the most beneficial range of hospital services to care for them in their health requirements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the proposition that Senator Newman has put before the Senate. She suggested in this proposition that it is a matter of public importance that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) honour a promise to a particular section of the community, a very special section -the veterans of this nation. It is a matter of public importance that such promises be honoured. But, of course, this promise stands among many.

SPEECH.PARA: Veterans in the Australian community have been promised and assured things by Prime Ministers from Billy Hughes onwards. The Prime Minister of today, in terms that would be understood by veterans, is carrying a baton that has been passed on from one government to another since the time of Billy Hughes. Those obligations have not been diminished one iota in that time.

The Prime Minister made this particular promise in April 1989. Seven days ago in this place I asked Minister Tate representing Minister Humphreys whether the Government was prepared to honour promises-they were described as ironclad promises-that had been made by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) in October 1988. The responses I got from Senator Tate representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs were interesting. He alleged that I was rumour mongering, scaremongering, being irresponsible in raising these issues and putting fear among the veterans' community, suggesting that I would be creating distress among the veterans' community by asking whether the promises of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs were to be honoured.

Today in response to an interjection by Senator Newman, Senator Tate has suggested that the veterans' community would once again be distressed. I think the veterans are distressed. They are distressed not by today's interjection, not by my question of last week, but by the fact that they have been promised for decades that certain things would stay in place. Those things are changing. Despite the assurances offered here last week, or even today again by Senator Tate, or by Senator Reynolds in previous times when responding to my earlier questions-despite all the assurances-the veterans now find that with the integration of the two systems they are being let down. They are in queues for general hospitals whereas previously there were not in queues for their own specialised repatriation hospital. There is distress out there; there is uncertainty. It is our responsibility to bring that uncertainty in here and to place it squarely back where it should be-with the Government.

The assurances that we have had are that, if the Returned Services League (RSL) has concerns, those concerns will be resolved. Of course the RSL has concerns. I can quote from a letter which appeared in the Australian Financial Review which suggests that the National Secretary of the RSL, Ian Gollings, still has grave concerns that this system of integration will not deliver. In that letter he cites the assurances that began 70 years ago. He cites the fact that after 70 years veterans are being subjected to what many of them, and frankly I, see as a sell-out.

One can qualify it, as Senator Tate did the other day in responding to my question, by citing a survey that had been done among veterans. The survey showed that 70 per cent of the veterans favoured the change. But we know that it depends on what questions are asked of people. If they are asked whether they would find it more convenient to be hospitalised near their homes and near their loved ones, of course they would say yes. But they were not asked whether they have confidence that they will be delivered that hospitalisation in a satisfactory way. I am quite sure that far less than 70 per cent of the veterans would have expressed confidence in the system. Even if they had expressed confidence months ago when they were asked, if they were asked today whether they have that confidence they would certainly say that they do not have it because they are currently having a bad experience. That is what is happening in the hospitals.

Let us look at the political administrative dimension of this. The other day in my question to Senator Tate I cited the fact that at least the New South Wales State health Minister said that he would not offer any assurances while a price tag of $150m was associated with the assurances. The same reservation was expressed by the Western Australian health Minister and the Tasmanian health Minister. Of course there is that reservation. The buck is being passed-literally. The responsibility is being passed but it remains to be seen whether the buck will be passed to the State governments to take up that responsibility.

In responding to the question I asked of him the other day, Senator Tate said that I was not up to date with Mr Collins's position. I rang Mr Collins's office this morning and asked him what his position was. I could not get a position. Of course the Government will not get an assurance. Of course the State Ministers want to keep their options open.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should they tell you what their position is?

—Why should they not? If they do not tell me, why can they not state their position to the veterans community? Perhaps they will not tell me, but let them tell the veterans. If this service depends upon the attitude and assurances of State Ministers, let them give those assurances, otherwise the Prime Minister cannot honour this promise. Unless he has the assurances, he cannot honour the promise he has made to veterans. No assurances are available. Therefore, this transition cannot occur in the manner that has been promised.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the decision for this to occur has been taken irrespective of the consequences. Irrespective of the outcome, this transition will occur. Frankly, I believe there is an air of indifference about what the veterans feel or experience. I illustrate that indifference. When I first became spokesperson for this portfolio in 1987 I attended a meeting in Coolangatta. Three thousand veterans were there to express concern about things like that. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs did not turn up. In 1988 I attended a public rally in the Sydney Town Hall. It was an overflow crowd that spilled out into the streets. There were about 3,000 people. The Minister did not turn up. Do honourable senators know what he called it? He called it a rent-a-crowd. Yet, at that meeting were the leaders of the RSL movement and the leaders of the veterans' movement. They had convened the meeting. People came to express concern about this process, and their Minister, who was not there, called them a rent-a-crowd. A year later, in 1989, a similar rally was convened. The other shadow Minister and I were there; again, the Minister was not there.

After the last election I was staggered to find that this Minister retained that portfolio, so low was the confidence of the veterans' community as a result of these snubs, decisions and sell-outs. There is disillusionment and cynicism in the veterans' community. And rightly so, not only because State Ministers, irrespective of their political colour, cannot and will not give the assurances necessary for this transition to occur satisfactorily for veterans but also because the veterans can perceive the fact that there has been a dramatic erosion of their entitlements. Senator Newman and I have stood in this place and listed, on behalf of veterans, entitlement after entitlement that has been eroded over the last few years. This is but only another dimension of what is happening.

I recently saw a copy of a letter-I do not have it here but the Minister will be aware of it-sent to the Prime Minister by the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia. The letter said in part, `We are the next generation of veterans; we are in the present generation of veterans. But when the old and bold go we, in our late forties and fifties, will still be here for another 20 or 30 years.' Those obligations made by successive government after government are as real now as when they were first uttered 40 and 50 years ago and this is a dramatic real erosion of those obligations. So there are two quite real dimensions to it. Veterans are concerned that their entitlements, at large, are disappearing. Privileged hospitalisation is only one of them.

The other dimension to their concern is the fact that suddenly this responsibility has been passed elsewhere. It has been passed to those who do not have an historic obligation to it and who do not, cannot and will not have a commitment to the type of hospitalisation warranted for veterans and which will not now be available to them irrespective of how many promises the Prime Minister, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs or Senator Tate make. It will not happen any more because the system is being dismantled. The veterans have the right to be concerned. By virtue of the history of this Government in addressing their needs in recent years, by virtue of this Minister's behaviour and by virtue of the erosion of their hospital system, they have the right to be cynical-and they are profoundly cynical about what is happening to their circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The repatriation hospital system has been built up over the last 50 years and now it will be destroyed in five. There are six repatriation general hospitals in Australia: one at Concord in New South Wales, one at Heidelberg in Victoria, one at Daw Park in South Australia, one at Hollywood in Western Australia, the repatriation general hospital in Hobart in Tasmania, and one at Greenslopes in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I attended a public meeting in March this year that was called as a result of a advertisement in the newspaper before the election. It was interesting that 400 people attended that meeting. There was standing room only. There was no rent-a-crowd. They were ordinary people who had been served by the repatriation hospital scheme. There were warders, cleaners, cooks, medical officers, nurses and veterans who attended as a result of that notice.

I learnt something at that meeting. I had thought, as a previous serving member of the 11th Field Ambulance, a former President of the Australian Medical Association (AMA) in Queensland and surgeon to the Royal Australian Air Force in Queensland, that I knew a lot about the repatriation system; that I had seen it from the other side. I learnt from that meeting that the veterans and their dependants had been given an assurance that they were to have a superior system of quality care-not public hospital care or private hospital care, but a superior system that had been guaranteed to them as a result of their war service. They risked their lives and their families suffered and we, as a nation, owe them a superior quality of care, not an ordinary system. They have earned it and they deserve it.

The present Government is promising and proposing that they be dumped onto the public hospital system. What is the state of the public hospital system in Australia? Public hospitals are overcrowded and underfunded. As my colleague Senator Newman said, waiting lists for elective surgery, particularly in Victoria and New South Wales, have lengthened dramatically. I draw the attention of the Senate to today's Sydney Morning Herald-so I am speaking about today. It states:

Medical services at Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Sydney's largest teaching hospital, are so overloaded that patients booked to come in for medical treatment or tests rarely get in. They could be admitted only as emergencies . . .

Last week Dr Jean Lennane was sacked for campaigning against the closure of wards and services at Rozelle Hospital and a few weeks ago the Medical Superintendent at Campbelltown Hospital was demoted for stating that the Hospital was underfunded and for saying that from the end of the year there would be no resident doctor on duty in intensive care. This is the State that has the best fiscal management in Australia. One can only guess at the problems which are today facing the public hospitals of Victoria, Western Australia and Tasmania, considering the enormous financial problems facing those States as a result of the mismanagement of the Labor governments.

Common to all States, however, are the problems of an ageing population. In the next 10 years two in every 10 Australians will be over the age of 50 and accompanying this ageing will be a constant increase in chronic illness. There are, and will be, even greater strains on the public hospital system.

Paradoxically, my State has further problems with a rapidly increasing population. Up to 800,000 people are expected to come to Queensland and increase the population to that extent in the next 10 years. Capital expenditure on the public hospitals in my State for the next financial year is $10m for the whole State. A survey of the Royal Brisbane Hospital has shown that $400m needs to be spent urgently to bring it up to the current southern standards. That is the system to which the repatriation people are supposed to go.

Hospitals are not just bricks and mortar. There is an ethos about hospitals. Each hospital has developed over many years. There are needs peculiar to the patients of those hospitals and the staff and already repatriation general hospitals are integrated with universities and university teaching hospitals, both at undergraduate and postgraduate levels, for medical students and for students of nursing, physiotherapy, occupational therapy, dietetics and other areas. This aspect is of enormous importance and it cannot possibly be absorbed by the existing public hospital system.

Another matter is the fact that the repatriation hospitals cater for non-veteran patients in order to maintain their standards as acute care institutions and to develop the opportunity of medical research into the particular conditions that are more common in veterans, such as hypertension. Some researchers at repatriation hospitals have developed units of world standing. For instance, in my State the unit at Greenslopes Hospital is headed by Professor Richard Gordon, who has achieved world renown because of his developments at that hospital. Similar units doing research exist in other States. Of course, there is some variation between the States as to the number of community patients that attend repatriation hospitals. At Concord Hospital this year it has reached 35 per cent-it is 20 per cent at Greenslopes Hospital. I believe that the original aim was to have a 20 per cent development of those numbers to allow the continuation of acute care.

It is interesting to note, as my colleague Senator Newman said, that 50 per cent of the needs of veterans and their dependants are met at this time by the repatriation hospitals. Half of those eligible actually use these hospitals and, of the remainder, two-thirds go to public hospitals and one-third go privately. Of course, this depends upon the percentage of people who have private hospital cover, the facilities available and the proportion of the population living in capital cities. Notwithstanding that, public non-veteran patients cost the Department of Veterans' Affairs approximately $88m last financial year.

A further factor is the declining number of veterans with increasing age but, of course, coincident with this is the increase in treatment required because of their advancing age and the increasing incidence of chronic illness among those veterans. It is believed that this demand will not peak until 1995-96, as has already been mentioned.

In summary, firstly, veterans have been guaranteed superior quality care in the past-not public care or private care; secondly, the requirements of veterans will not peak for another five or six years; thirdly, the State public hospital systems are already overcrowded and underfunded; fourthly, the demands of a rapidly ageing population in Australia and the cost of pharmaceuticals and technology will exacerbate these problems; and, fifthly, the ethos of these fine institutions as training and research facilities will be destroyed. Is it any wonder that the Opposition considers these matters to be ones of public importance?

I cannot let this occasion pass without responding to Senator Tate's remarks about Sir William Keys. Senator Newman interjected that Sir William Keys was a stooge of the Government. Earlier this year, on 26 May, I attended the AMA National Conference held in Canberra. Sir William Keys spoke at that meeting as Chairman of the National Office of Overseas Skill Recognition. He came to that meeting and delivered a paper on the necessity of registering migrants with overseas medical qualifications without any consideration of the number of medical students that we are already graduating from the hospitals. His speech outraged the people who were listening to it. They could not believe that a person of his standing and calibre could deliver a speech of this nature. He was attacked from the floor by many speakers. He was spoken to afterwards and we discovered that he had arrived back in Australia from overseas that morning, had gone to the Conference and had delivered a speech that he had not actually read. It had been handed to him by the Government Department before he went to the Conference.

I do not know what the definition of a stooge is, but I think that that definition would fit somebody who would be capable of attending a meeting, delivering a paper handed to him by a government and then trying to defend it without having any idea what was in the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on priorities for reform in higher education and seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING ENTITLED `PRIORITIES FOR REFORM IN HIGHER EDUCATION'

For the information of honourable members, I present a statement containing the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Priorities for Reform in Higher Education. The report was released on 26 June 1990 and was tabled in the Senate on 22 August 1990.

The Government finds the report disappointing in that, while the issues it discusses clearly are important for the future of higher education in Australia, the specific recommendations arising from this discussion are of limited usefulness. In some cases the recommendations are framed at too high a leve of generality to provide the basis for practical government policies. In others, there is a failure to take account of steps already taken by the Government. Overall, the report fails to acknowledge the substantial priority the Government has already given to addressing many of the concerns it raises.

In my response I have addressed the seven recommendations made by the Committee. In addition, I have responded to some of the more significant issues in the report which did not lead to particular recommendations. A number of these issues will be taken up when the Government responds to the policy paper of the Higher Education Council, Higher Education; The Challenges Ahead. This paper is due for public release shortly and the Government intends to respond early in the new year.
QUALITY OF HIGHER EDUCATION

The main theme of the report is its concern with the quality of higher education offerings. The Committee began its public hearings for this inquiry in May 1989 when the reforms arising from the Government's White Paper on higher education, which was released in July 1988, were in the early stages of implementation. In part, the Committee is critical of the Government's approach in the White Paper for concentrating on structural reform at the expense of quality, and it goes on to identify those dimensions of quality which it believes are open to criticism. At the same time, the Committee acknowledges the high standards of the Australian higher education system in the technical areas of the curriculum.

The Committee focuses on the narrowness of the academic curriculum, and the lack of importance accorded to languages and cultures other than English; lack of preparation for the process of lifelong learning; and failure to emphasise effective communication skills. It also raises questions about standards of teaching in higher education, citing submissions drawing attention to poor quality teaching and to the lack of reward for excellence in teaching.

Quality has been, and will continue to be, a major focus of the Government's initiatives in reforming the higher education system. At the outset of its White Paper, the Government stated its commitment to ``growth and quality enhancement across the whole of the education and training system'' and these have been the major objectives of the series of reforms to the higher education system since 1988. It is somewhat artificial to separate structural change from improvements to quality. In most cases the rationale for the structural change in higher education was to improve academic opportunities and to provide for a higher standard of education. The amalgamation of higher education institutions, for instance, a significant component of the structural change the Committee refers to, has as its major objective the improvement of educational effectiveness and efficiency by expanding the range and flexibility of studies available within each institution, increasing the strength of academic departments and support facilities and concentrating research and development effort.

Apart from the evidence put forward in individual submissions, the Committee relied heavily in this area on the findings of discipline reviews or committees of inquiry especially appointed by the Government to examine particular fields of study in higher education. Since 1985 the Government has supported a program of reviews of major discipline areas in higher education which, among other things, look at the adequacy of the curriculum. Each of these reviews and inquiries, which to date have covered the fields of law, engineering, teacher education in maths and science, accounting, agriculture, Australian Studies, Asian Studies and languages, was in effect an acknowledgement of the need to improve the quality of delivery of programs in these areas, and each led to reforms and action in the particular field of study affected. It is unfortunate that the Committee, while citing evidence from these studies, fails to go the further step and examine what reforms have been put in place as an outcome of these examinations.

The effectiveness of the discipline review program has recently been evaluated by a working party of the Higher Education Council which has suggested ways in which the process can be made more cost effective and the implementation of recommendations of reviews assessed.

While the discipline review program is funded by the Government as an external measure of quality assurance, as the Committee itself emphasises it is important to respect the autonomy of institutions in relation to curriculum matters and approaches to teaching. These matters have for long been removed from central control, although the Commonwealth expects a commitment from higher education institutions to maintaining high academic standards and is aware that most institutions regularly re-examine individual course content and focus. There is no intention on the part of the Government that this approach should change.
Five of the report's seven recommendations relate to quality and the standard of teaching, and I will respond to those now:
Recommendation 1

The Committee recommends that the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) sponsor an Australia-wide program to assist institutions to evaluate the purposes and structure of the undergraduate curriculum across all disciplines with a view to encouraging them to broaden the nature of the educational experiences provided.
Response

The Government would have difficulty in accepting a recommendation as general as this. What the Committee appears to be proposing is an exercise of vast scope which would require the commitment of extensive resources. It is not at all clear what an Australia-wide program of the kind proposed could achieve, or whether it would be warranted. It is questionable whether the objective of broadening the curriculum that is laid down in the recommendation is appropriate across all institutions and disciplines. The structure and content of the undergraduate curriculum is essentially a matter for higher education institutions to determine. Some institutions have deliberately broadened their undergradate curriculum, as the Committee itself acknowledges, and options are always available to students, particularly in the larger, amalgamated institutions, to broaden their educational experiences. This then becomes a matter of individual choice, and is not an area where the Commonwealth ought to intervene.

The Commonwealth is of course concerned that appropriate standards are maintained in the higher education system. The program of discipline reviews mentioned previously exist as an external quality control mechanism supported by the Commonwealth. The Register of Australian Tertiary Education (RATE), set up by the Australian Education Council, has a Register Advisory Committee which is concerned with national standards. The Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee has also established academic standards panels in selected disciplines to advise on standards in honours courses across institutions and there is scope for this work to be extended as a quality assurance measure.

With these systems in place, in addition to other Commonwealth initiatives directed at improvement in the quality of higher education programs, the Government considers it unnecessary to invite NDEET to institute a wide-ranging review.
Recommendation 2
The Committee recommends that funds be made available from the Commonwealth's Reserve Fund to support and evaluate curriculum innovations and to disseminate information about them
Response

In the two years that the Reserve Fund has been operating, funds have been provided for curriculum developments in areas of national priority in higher education. The rationale for the grants is to seed initiatives which will benefit not only the host institution but higher education generally. The 1990 Reserve fund program includes curriculum developments in environmental studies, multicultural education and Asian languages and studies. The priority areas for the 1991 program include Australian studies as well as those just mentioned.
Recommendation 3

The Committee recommends that the Australian Research Council (ARC) provide funds for a research project into the communication difficulties of students in Australian higher education institutions. The project should consider both oral and written communication and base its findings on a range of institutions and disciplines. The principal objectives should be to:
(1) assess the proportion of students whose performance is adversely affected by communication difficulties;
(2) identify the kinds of difficulties commonly experienced; and
(3) recommend appropriate remedial measures.
Response

The Government questions the likely value of such a project on this scale, although it would draw attention to initiatives that are already being taken in this area which have a narrower focus. For example, a number of projects currently being funded by the ARC relate to learning and teaching problems in particular disciplines, as well as communication and other problems experienced by students.

Most higher education institutions have established support units for students with communication problems. These units are in the best position to appreciate the extent and nature of the problems experienced and to know what remedial measures are appropriate.

Under the Government's Higher Education Equity Program, funds have been provided to institutions to assist the provision of programs designed to improve opportunities for students from disadvantaged backgrounds. These programs have included learning assistance centres, study skills programs, and preparatory and supplementary support programs in literacy, numeracy and communication skills.
Recommendations 4 and 5

4. The Committee recommends that the promotion of good teaching within higher education institutions be designated a national priority area and that, in the context of the development of profiles, institutions be requested to provide information on policies and programs which they have adopted to achieve this aim.
5. The Committee recommends that funds be provided on a competitive basis through the Reserve Fund to support projects aimed at improving the quality of teaching.
Response

The Government acknowledges that traditionally in higher education, a high standard of research performance has been valued above excellence in teaching. It is however becoming increasingly common for institutions to evaluate teaching performance with a view to rewarding excellence. The Higher Education Council has addressed this issue in its policy paper, Higher Education: The Challenges Ahead and the Government has also taken steps to ensure that teaching skills are accorded the same value as research. In its negotiations on academic awards under the Structural Efficiency Principal, the Government has emphasised its commitment to improving the quality of teaching and to staff development. It has also funded the establishment of the Staff Development Fund to assist institutions to expand their staff development activity. Continued support for the Fund will depend on the development of institution-based staff development strategies consistent with nationally determined guidelines.

For 1991, ``improved academic teaching'' has been identified as a priority for applications for support from the Reserve Fund. This was included in the Guidelines for application which were distributed in April 1990. All proposals aimed at enhancing the quality of higher education, including the quality of teaching, will be assessed on a competitive basis with the aim of incorporating into the program the highest standard projects.
TEACHING AND ACADEMIC STAFF

The Committee makes a connection between its concern with the standard of teaching and academic staffing policies, drawing particular attention to a decline in the relative value of academic salaries, a lack of promotion opportunities and factors in the employment environment which affect the attractiveness of university teaching as a profession. It also expresses concern about likely shortages of academic staff, and considers it a priority to ensure that accurate information is available on the extent of that shortage.
The Committee acknowledges that the Government has taken action by appointing a working party to analyse the labour market for academic teaching staff. This leads to a further recommendation:
Recommendation 6

The Committee recommends that the NBEET consider the results of the study of the labour market for academics when they become available, form an assessment of the nature and extent of the problems of academic staff recruitment and retention which are likely to emerge, and make recommendations concerning the measures required to ensure that high quality staff continue to be attracted to academic teaching and research in sufficient numbers in all disciplines.
Response

Through its involvement in the negotiations on academic staffing matters under the Structural Efficiency Principle, the Commonwealth has indicated its readiness to fund substantial salary increases and has actively sought improvements in a number of non salary matters relating to career structures which would improve the attractiveness of an academic carrer. These negotiations are still under way.

The Commonwealth has taken action also to address the potential shortage of academic staff. The Department of Employment, Education and Training has initiated a labour market analysis referred to in the recommendation to determine the extent and nature of existing recruitment and retention difficulties for academic staff and to prepare forecasts of supply and demand to the year 2000. A report is expected later in the year. A decision will be made at that time as to how its findings would be most appropriately dealt with.

The Government has also acted to increase the allocation of additional places in higher education to higher degree students (a significant proportion of the additional intakes to be funded in 1993 will be set aside for higher degree students), to increase the number of Australian Postgraduate Research Awards ( an additional 100 awards will be available from 1991), to improve the financial assistance available under postgraduate awards, including the provision of loadings for awards in high priority areas, and to liberalise the migrant and permanent resident entry provisions to facilitate the entry of overseas academic staff.
The labour market analysis referred to above will assist the Government in determining what further steps might be needed.
LIFELONG LEARNING

One of the other major areas of interest of the Committee is lifelong learning. This is indeed an issue which will assume increasing importance in Australia, as demographic trends and award restructuring create a climate where students will expect to enter and leave higher education at different stages of their working lives. In the light of its concern that adult and continuing education should not be a marginal activity within higher education, the Committee has made the following recommendation:
Recommendation 7

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth establish a permanent policy focus for adult and continuing education at the national level. This mechanism should be established within the structure of NBEET and should report in the first instance to either the Chair of NBEET or the Chair of the Higher Education Council. It should assume a leadership role for continuing education and develop policies appropriate to the emerging educational needs of Australian society.
Response

The Government accepts that continuing education or lifelong learning will become a major priority for higher education in the future. The recommendation for a ``permanent policy focus'' does not seem particularly helpful at this stage. In its paper Higher Education: The Challenges Ahead, the Higher Education Council has taken into account the likelihood that the student body will become increasingly diverse as a result of award restructuring and other trends and has therefore proposed a number of strategies in relation to admissions policies, course design and accreditation and modes of delivery. The Government will respond to the Council's proposals in the policy paper to be released early next year, and will also be giving consideration to developing a reference to the Council on this issue. At this stage, the Government has not decided on the most appropriate administrative mechanism for advancing the issue.

The Government has acknowledged the importance of continuing and adult education through the establishment of new distance education arrangements, through the provision of significant additional funding for the development of new teaching technology and curricula focusing on adult learning and with the consistent emphasis being given to credit transfer and course articulation issues, and with its support for cooperative education programs which involve joint activity between higher education institutions and sponsoring companies.
ACCESS AND EQUITY

The Committee has devoted a chapter of its report to the questions of access and equity, but acknowledges the comprehensiveness of the initiatives the Government has taken since the White Paper and the strategies set out in A Fair Chance for All, which sets out a national equity strategy and sets targets for increased participation for each of the identified groups. The Government certainly shares the Committee's view of the importance of equity in access to higher education. The Committee makes no specific recommendations on this issue.

It does however make the suggestion that close monitoring of institutional commitment to the achievement of equity objectives is required, a view shared by the Government which, in addition to monitoring institutional achievements through the profiles process, is also canvassing a range of options to establish a closer link between equity performance and Commonwealth funding. As a first step, equity program funds, from 1991, will be allocated to institutions on the basis of equity plans included in institutional profiles, rather than for specific projects as in previous years.

In addition, the Committee strongly urges that the Tertiary Awareness Program (TAP), an initiative funded under the Commonwealth higher education program since 1985, should be extended to other regions. The effectiveness of TAP in encouraging post-school participation among the socioeconomically disadvantaged youth in Western Sydney has recently been evaluated. I am satisfied that the TAP strategies are effective and I am currently exploring options for the continuation of TAP initiatives with the support of the Commonwealth, relevant State authorities and higher education institutions, within the new equity funding arrangements. Institutions in other regions have been encouraged to incorporate, where appropriate, similar strategies into their equity plans.
OTHER ISSUES

The Committee has raised a range of other issues relating to the management of the higher education system. It does not however make further specific recommendations. In most cases, the concerns raised by the Committee have in fact been taken up by the Government in the process of implementing the White Paper reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I wish to make a few comments on the Government's response to this report. Reluctantly-it does not give me any pleasure-I must describe that response as disturbingly bureaucratic. It displays many of the features that have now become part of the way business is being conducted in Canberra, regardless--
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President. As soon as I heard this item I came immediately to the chamber, but I have not heard that the report has actually been tabled. Is a copy available?
—It looks as though it is coming around now.
—In response to Senator Teague, I have been a recipient of this report for only a short time as well. Senator Teague-We have not seen it over here.

—I am responding firstly as Chairman of the Committee but secondly as an individual backbencher in the Parliament to the Government's response. As I have indicated, many features of the Government's response have become part of the way business is being conducted in Canberra, regardless of whether a Liberal or a Labor government is in power. I would like to congratulate the bureaucrat who wrote this because he or she seems to have unerringly tried to close the debate at a time when the community wants to see the whole issue of what we want to do with higher education opened. I guess that is the aim of bureaucracies everywhere, especially a bureaucracy as socially and intellectually isolated as some of the parts that service us in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: I will go into some of the details as to why I have come, reluctantly as I said, to that conclusion. The Government's response criticises the report for providing specific recommendations that are, to quote the Government's response, `of limited usefulness'. In response to that I need to remind the Government that the Committee is not an interdepartmental committee that sought to provide a bureaucratic model for future action. Our aim was to tease out the questions, to challenge assumptions and to suggest some courses of action. As a committee, we always assumed that the detailed mechanisms were a matter for government to decide.

Disappointing also is the Government's unwillingness to use the full powers and responsibilities of a national government to bring about reform. A number of statements are made throughout this paper in which the Government refuses to accept the challenge that the Committee's report placed before this Parliament. I will specifically indicate those at a later point. On page 3, for example, in relation to a review of disciplines or the curriculum, the Government again says:

These matters have for long been removed from central control, although the Commonwealth expects a commitment from higher education institutions to maintaining high academic standards and is aware that most institutions regularly re-examine individual course content and focus . . .
There is no intention on the part of the Government that this approach should change.

In other words, in many ways it is said through implication that the Government has no intention of interfering in any way in the situation in which the universities or institutions themselves make decisions about course content and focus. The Committee did not indicate in its report that the Government should be prescriptive or that it should step into this arena and force institutions to move in a particular direction in terms of broadening and analysing their curriculum; the Committee was saying that the Government should involve itself as a disseminator of information and should examine what goes on in institutions around Australia; it should then pick the best in terms of what is being done and disseminate those models through the system. In other words, the Government's role as a disseminator of information, ideas and models is what the Committee recommended. The Committee did not recommend a forced intervention in this area on the part of the Government, yet the clear implication in the Government's response is that it will not change its approach, which at this stage is basically an approach that leaves it up to the institutions themselves to decide.

Similarly with the curriculum, the Committee indicated that it believes a broadening of curriculum in higher education institutions is very desirable. In discussions after the report came out, we talked about the phenomenon of the skilled barbarian-that is, the person who is technically very well equipped and well educated when he comes out of our higher institutions. At the same time, the Committee said that many young people who graduate from our institutions, although technically competent in their own field of activity or endeavour, or their own discipline, are fairly ignorant of the wider society into which they are going. They are fairly ignorant of the interrelationship between their own disciplines and the wider society around them. The Committee used the examples of doctors, lawyers and engineers, who knew their own disciplines very well but had very little idea of how those disciplines related to society at large. The Committee was pushing the notion that curriculums ought to be changed sufficiently and that models ought to be set up around Australia to encourage people to broaden their outlook. The Government does not seem to be interested in that particular proposition.

The Committee also recommended that the Commonwealth Government involve itself in a number of ways in research projects, either directly or through funding individual institutions, which would examine the curriculums and the type of activities and innovations that were being carried out in certain institutions. The Government indicated that it believes it is doing enough. On page 4 of its response it cites some of those activities:

The 1990 Reserve Fund program includes curriculum developments in environmental studies, multicultural education and Asian languages and studies. The priority areas for the 1991 program include Australian studies as well as those just mentioned.

That is quite laudable. It is interesting that even in the question of that vital area of lifting the percentage of people in Australian society who can speak a second language-after all, we are an exporting country-the response does not mention the need to continue the teaching of European languages. It does not mention the declining number of students in Australia who are learning European languages. It does not mention the need to examine this whole issue. There are 580 million people in Europe, a major market which in 1992 will become one unified market. A very significant number of people in that market speak German as a first or second language, particularly in eastern Europe. There is nothing to suggest that the Government under any circumstances has investigated the phenomenon of the declining percentage of students studying German in our higher education institutions.

Again we come back to the question that the bureaucrat who wrote this basically said, `Enough is what we can put on this paper. We don't need to broaden our horizons. We don't need to question the assumptions that underlie what we are doing. What we are doing is catalogued here and it should be sufficient'. That is a disappointing response to a report that took a year and a half to write, a report that went into depth in many areas and had a wonderful response from a significant number of major players in the game in higher education-from students, from teachers, from institutions themselves and from outside groups. It seems to me that much of that work will have been wasted if this is the sum total of the Government's response.

The question is not whether or not the Government agrees with the specific recommendations suggested in this report. After all, as I said, we did not intend to act like an interdepartmental committee that was going to give specific recommendations for action. We wanted to raise the issues. We wanted to get people to think about higher education at a greater depth than is currently the case at government level.

The response is disappointing. It is defensive. It does not take into account one of the major underlying assumptions that we made-that the major improvements to the higher education system in Australia will come not through forced government intervention, and I do not think through the activities of the universities or the institutions themselves, but through assistance from a Commonwealth government which sees itself as an organisation in this area prepared to take ideas and find good models on which all reform can be based. We have said that the best way to reform the higher education system is to look at, analyse and then disseminate those good models of teaching, planning, curriculum development, funding operations and structuring which can be of use to other institutions.

I suppose the thing which struck me more than anything else as I looked at these institutions, as I looked at the submissions and as we read the literature associated with this area was that there is much good work being done in our higher education institutions, but that work often remains isolated and discrete in the institution where it is being done. The model is not being taken and disseminated throughout the academic community. Government's role ought to be to take those models and disseminate them; to encourage people in Melbourne, for example, to spread their ideas to other universities; to say to people in Sydney who are doing effective work there, `Have a look at this'.

This paper is basically a defensive, unimaginative response and it does not even take into account the notion of disseminating models. It seems to me that in many ways it falls into the same sort of trap that so many other responses of government have fallen into over the last 10 or 15 years, but this trend has got worse. The domination of the economic view of public issues-by economists, by bureaucrats who like nice, neat systems-has been the major problem in so many areas.

What we as a committee tried to do was to open up the debate, to say to Australians in this area, `Think about the possibilities; think about cooperation; think about sharing ideas; think about debating your major assumptions before you get into structural reform. Ask yourselves: What do you want out of your higher education institutions? When you have debated that, when you have come to some conclusions and you have asked the difficult, embarrassing questions, then you start bringing in structural reform'.

There is simply no point in amalgamating higher education institutions if at the end of the day we have not debated what we want to do with them, what we want to come out of them. All we end up with then is a bigger organisation which may have just the same lack of a sense of direction, and just the same lack of concern for quality teaching and learning, as the previous two institutions.

There is simply no point in a government setting up a funding research operation, centralising decisions about research funding in Australia, if at the end of the day it has not asked itself the basic question: What should be the balance between research and teaching? How do we reward good teaching? How do we promote good research in institutions without damaging the effectiveness of teaching in those institutions? How do we reward and promote good teachers in institutions but at the same time not lose those academics who are most skilled at research? When do we bring together a capacity for research and a capacity for good teaching? How do we set down regimes where rewards, financial and otherwise, are given to those people who say to themselves and to those around them, `I want to be a good teacher in a higher education institution, but I want the same rewards as someone who is an important researcher'?

Those basic questions have to be asked before we involve ourselves in structural reform. That has been the main criticism I have made for some time now of the approach taken by Minister Dawkins. I have said, `Get the debate going before you make the structural changes. If you don't like the debate, that is tough luck because in a debate people are going to say things about you which you don't like. They are going to criticise your assumptions; they are going to criticise your policies. But if you open your heart and your mind you will learn from what people put in'.

When we looked at the responses that came to our Committee we saw a great deal of goodwill from people in institutions. We saw a lot of defensiveness, but we saw many people-from students to academics to members of the general community-who wanted to reform our higher education system; to be able to stand up and say, `I am an academic. I am proud of it. The sector that I work in is a productive sector that is doing something for this country, and I get job satisfaction'. The Minister and the bureaucrats who wrote this response have to ask themselves: Is that happening? Can an academic stand up in public now and say, `I am proud of what I do. I am effective. My institution is effective. The Government is helping me in the best possible way. The Government is helping me learn from my colleagues around Australia'.
