Implicit in all of this is the need for us to have a truly national system of higher education. That does not mean, as I indicated before, that the Government has to get prescriptive in every detail about what that unified national system ought to be, but it does indicate quite clearly that the Government has to be that disseminator. It has to be that agent in the middle that can help institutions get together, that can promote debate, that can at the end of the day make our higher education system highly relevant.

It is very important to remember that the percentage of people who have university degrees and the number of students who go on to find places at universities is only one part of the question. We can spend millions on achieving that goal. The second part of the question is: What is the quality of their education? What has their education done to make them better citizens, more civilised people with all-round knowledge and abilities, with an interest in their own society at large and a willingness to contribute to that society?

Have we turned out from some of our universities young people who are skilled in one area-the area of the particular narrow discipline that they have studied-and who do not want to know about, and have no interest in, other areas? Are we producing engineers, for example, who are aware that engineering affects a great deal of what we do; that engineers are in the middle of the great environmental debate; that it is not good enough for engineers to come out with a knowledge of the very narrow confines of their discipline; that what they do for the most part can have a very big influence on society around them?

In Tasmania the Hydro-Electric Commission is basically a very big government or semi-government operation run by engineers. Technically it is a very competent organisation. Yet of all the semi-governmental and governmental organisations in Tasmania, it was the one that caused the most politically disastrous situations over the past decade. This happened primarily because its decisions were almost wholly and solely engineering decisions. The people who ran the Hydro-Electric Commission from top to bottom in many ways saw themselves only as engineers and dam builders. As a consequence Tasmania was thrown into political turmoil for a decade or more because of the narrowness of the people who were running that very important institution. That is just one example of what can happen when people are trained to be simply competent technicians, the skilled barbarians, the people who do not have a sense of the way their particular discipline impacts on the society around them.

The main aim behind this report was to get people thinking about higher education; to get them to question the assumptions that they had; to get them to talk about quality of learning and quality of teaching in our institutions. The aim was not to make specific recommendations about the structures that the Government should create. That is up to the Government. We wanted a questioning of this whole issue. What we have here is a document that narrows the debate and which defensively tries to tighten every knot, every loophole and works against debate.

More than anything else I want to give a message to the people behind this paper, and it is a simple message. I say: `Arise, Sir Humphrey, spread your wings and fly. This paper has got you grounded totally.' And the Minister should not have accepted this paper as a statement of what the Government's intentions are in higher education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to follow the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training with whom I participated in the inquiry on priorities for reform in higher education and in the writing of the report and recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with the Chairman's summary that this is a disappointing, defensive report. I go much further than that. I think that it is simply a disgrace. Not only has a bland bureaucrat put together some words to give an evasive Government response, but that bureaucrat has convinced the two Ministers-the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin)-to accept these words as fitting the prescription that I can only surmise Minister Dawkins put to those bureaucrats that he required those bureaucrats to write. I say Minister Dawkins because, although this is presented here today over the name of the Honourable Peter Baldwin, M.P., Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, the response has all the prescription of the senior Minister in his immediate remarks responding to the report when we published it. I regard it as a disgrace and I say, conscious of standing orders not to reflect upon persons in the other House, that the junior Minister, a person whom I respect, Peter Baldwin, has been duped by his senior Minister. He has allowed the Minister's prescription to be the one that the bureaucrats have written and that he has had to accept. Where is the conscientiousness, the imagination and the initiative of a Minister who ought to be a rising Minister in this Government and who ought to be applying every good idea to improve higher education because that is his responsibility? It is a disgrace.

If we look at any Senate inquiry in which we not only invest our thought and our carefulness of report and recommendation but also do our best to summarise hundreds of submissions which come from the Australian public and which seek to improve an area of public life, and if we got this kind of response, we would experience the same emotion of regarding this as a disgrace. It is unbelievable to me that the Ministers of this Labor Government, Mr Dawkins and Mr Baldwin, have poisoned themselves to this Senate inquiry, as it would appear, from the beginning. I think that it can be for political reasons.

I do not know whether that is because they do not like the eight personalities who made up the Senate report. I do not know whether it is because the agenda in education over the past three years has been that very limited agenda which Mr Dawkins dreamed up in the first month he was Minister-or it may have been in the first half day before the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) invited him to be the Minister. He certainly did have a strategy which was announced shortly after the 1987 election and precious little has been done in education, apart from that personal agenda of Mr Dawkins. He has driven that right through the Green Paper and the White Paper and in the implementation of so-called reforms in higher education against all the protests of this chamber and of representatives of higher education in this country.

The response the Minister now gives to this report is the same kind of poisonous response that he has given to all those protests in this chamber over the past three years and to the higher education public over that period. These Ministers have blinded themselves to any fresh idea coming from the public or from this chamber.

In the House of Representatives-and I do not seek to reflect upon that House because to do so would be against the Standing Orders-when there have been education Bills and an opportunity to discuss education in that House during the past three years, the Government has brought in the guillotine and only one or two hours has been spent on bringing forward any new idea about higher education, schools, technical and further education or skill formation. It has been understandable, when there has been no opportunity in the other half of this Parliament for any debate on education, that the only debate in this Parliament occurred in this chamber.

In the light of those debates we have taken up a reference given by the Senate to look at questions of reform in higher education. What are the priorities for reform in higher education? That was the question we were addressing, and there were enormous responses from around the country. We analysed those responses. We had hearings in each capital city. We did a year and a half study of those matters. Frankly, whatever the criticisms expressed by any of us over the past two to three years at the drastic measures for just reforming quantities, where the resources are, which institutions are to be amalgamated, new requirements for defining profiles and so on, ad nauseam, and whatever criticisms we had of that Dawkins agenda, we nevertheless in good faith were wanting to look at priorities for reform and to address ourselves to quality in higher education, and to bring those genuinely to the attention of the Government and indeed of all members of the House of Representatives and of the Senate so that they could be acted upon.

What have we got in this response? I have been able to read it through only once in the 20 minutes that Senator Aulich was speaking, because the document was incorporated and I did not have any prior notice. I have made a number of underlinings, circles, exclamation marks and arrows on each page of this nine-page response.

The Government's responses to the seven particular recommendations that are set out here are evasive, defensive, and not only disappointing but in a form of words which says: `No, no, no. We are not going to consider your recommendations. We are self-satisfied that this Dawkins-Baldwin Labor Government has got it all right, and we do not need a Senate report from persons that we do not seem to respect to bring any additional ideas to the attention of this self-satisfied Government'.

Maybe there is a cycle in these affairs in the life of a government of any country; after it has gone past five years-and certainly after seven-it gets a kind of self-satisfied smugness that is impenetrable, even by an important Senate report. It is disgraceful that there is not an ability in the Ministers of this Government to take on merit the findings of such an inquiry. On the first page of the response there is a put down of the whole report. It says:
. . . the recommendations are framed at too high a level of generality to provide the basis for practical government policies.

I suppose that, as a debating technique, any government Minister at any time could argue subjectively that the findings of some group or the suggestions that are made are so general that they cannot be translated into a particular decision. I can test that absolutely. This is the second general accusation that is made:
In others, there is a failure to take account of steps already taken by the Government.

In other words, it is self-satisfaction again-`The Government has got it all right; you have not taken full account of the achievements of the Dawkins-Baldwin-Hawke Labor Government and, because you have not, we will bring you up to date in a few pages of response that say that we are not going to implement any of your recommendations, and we will point out a little bibliography of reports and achievements of this self-satisfied Government to bring you innocent senators up to date with the great achievements of the Dawkins-Baldwin miracles'. That kind of put down is not accepted by me as a senator and ought not to be accepted by this Senate, and, as I said in some remarks on Minister Dawkins's initial response when we published the report, the Minister has gone very close to contempt of this Senate in his unfounded criticisms of senators, of the Senate committee process, and of this particular inquiry.
I could go through all of the seven responses to the particular recommendations. For instance, the response to recommendations four and five contains this sentence:

All proposals aimed at enhancing the quality of higher education, including the quality of teaching, will be assessed on a competitive basis with the aim of incorporating into the program the highest standard projects.

That is the kind of language of this response-put down, put down, and no, no, no. The Minister is saying, `We have got it all right. We are not receiving any new ideas. We will regard any suggestion, especially ones asking for money, only on a competitive basis, so that it can go through all the gauntlets'. That is the language right throughout this response. In contrast, let me just briefly refer to a meeting held less than a month ago that I addressed at the Queensland University of Technology. On 23 October, I was invited to go up to the Queensland University of Technology to meet with the Vice-Chancellor, the Deputy Vice-Chancellor and, through the tertiary education unit, to speak to deans of faculties and other senior staff. There was also a representative from Griffith University and the University of Queensland. We had an afternoon in which I was to address this important Senate report, Priorities for Reform in Higher Education. I not only gave a short address but then had a discussion and answered questions of those who were present. Unanimously, that worthy body of education leaders in Queensland welcomed this report. They said that it was highly relevant, and asked when the Government of this country would do something about it.

Let me, as a sample, address our first recommendation. We did not actually enumerate them but in our recommendations we list six qualities that we believe any undergraduate ought to have on passing successfully from a higher education institution-not only the old established universities but also the new universities. All graduates in this country ought to have not only knowledge and skills-which by and large we acknowledge they are receiving-but also five additional skills or qualities. The Queensland University of Technology educators welcomed this description:

The Committee believes that Australia is producing graduates who, all too frequently, are not familiar in any disciplined sense with the society in which they are going to practise their chosen profession.
The educators say with us, `Yes, that is a second quality that we believe any undergraduate ought to achieve in a course'. The description continues with the third quality:
. . . who are not analytical, creative thinkers . . .

The Committee was disappointed not to find a sufficient quality of outcome in undergraduates in this area. The educators, together with the Senate Committee, say, `Yes, any graduate ought to be an analytical and creative thinker'. The fourth quality we state is:
whose education does not provide the basis for adequate flexibility.

We believe a graduate ought to have an education which is flexible; which can adapt to the circumstances of that person's professional life; and which indeed increases knowledge. Fifthly, graduates should be attuned to the need for life-long learning. Sixthly, a graduate should be a good communicator.

I asked that group of 30 or 40 educators, as a sample of any of the universities of this country, `Would you regard anyone who did not have these six qualities as an adequate graduate of your university?'. Not one of them said that they would be happy if any of their graduates failed in any of these six areas. They were crying out, `Of course you are right, Senator Teague, and the Senate Committee is right. We are pretty good at number one but we are not very good at two, three, four, five and six because our courses do not actually address these additional qualities in a graduate', whether it be good communication, life-long learning, flexibility, analytical and creative thinking-which senators would fully understand-or the need to take a body of learning, a knowledge or skill and make it relate in a disciplined sense to the society in which that knowledge is going to be applied.

They said, `Mea culpa. Woe is us. Higher education in Australia is lacking in these additional characteristics and, yes, we do need to address them'. I give that as just one example of one meeting of educators in relation to this report. That was very recently, only three weeks ago, and I believe I have fairly described that meeting. If that is the response of the educators, the response of the Ministers is totally contrary. Their response is the put down, the no-the defensive, dismissive, disappointing disgrace that we have had given to us here in the Senate today.

I believe that the only way ahead, given the way that Ministers have soured this report to the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, to the Higher Education Council, to their own Department and to themselves, is for a fresh response to these matters; I was going to say, `by a change of government' but, unfortunately, that is too many months away because the next election is still two years away. But there will be a refreshing approach and a return to a constructive response by Ministers to Senate reports when there is a change of government.

All I can say as another consolation is that institutions can read the report, as they are doing all over the country, and make their responses to the findings set out therein. I refer to individual vice-chancellors, deans of faculties, lecturers, appointments committees-those responsible for encouraging teaching in institutions and those who want to remedy the shortfalls in the quality of undergraduate courses, the concentration on adult education, lifelong learning and the access and equity questions that we have addressed. All of these matters are perfectly able to be responded to by the higher education institutions themselves and by individuals.

In this Committee, of which I have been a member for 12 years until a few months ago, we have always, and only, said that we want to be judged on the displayed evidence and argument in the report and we commend our conclusions to others-not with any sense of authority because we have some divine insight into education matters but rather, to the extent that we believe we have reached sound conclusions and that anyone independently looking at the evidence could, following our reasoning, come to similar conclusions. To that extent, let it be ad hominem persuasive directly in the institutions. Let the institutions bypass these inadequate Ministers, this self-satisfied Government, and let us see a response to the Senate report which is genuine in higher education institutions themselves and not the disgrace that has been brought to the Senate today by these Ministers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on priorities for reform in higher education. As a member of the Committee, and now as Deputy Chairman, I have to say that the fact that this report was tabled this afternoon and that members of the Committee were not given the courtesy of seeing it beforehand makes it rather difficult for me to speak on it. I do not want to fall into the trap that many of the vice-chancellors and other senior academics fell into when they spoke out about the report in response to Mr Dawkins's response to it without having read it. We saw what happened. We saw the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee condemn the report. Then we saw a gradual turnaround after the vice-chancellors had read it. One of the examples of this was from the President of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, Professor Brian Wilson, who was reported in the Australian of 1 August as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The president of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, Professor Brian Wilson, has expressed sympathy with the Senate education committee report which attacked universities for turning out ``barbarians''.
Professor Wilson described the report as ``much more sensible'' than it was portrayed and praised its emphasis on the need to liberalise the educational backgrounds of students.

His positive comments contrast with the official line taken by the AVCC and the academic unions which, he notes, ``derided the authors, saying basically that they didn't know what they were talking about''.
``The Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, also castigated his parliamentary colleagues,'' Professor Wilson says . . .
We know all about that because we read about it, and I will refer to it in a moment. The article continued

``But it would be stupid for us to simply write off the report's conclusions because of what may well have been an inadequately organised study relying solely on written and oral submissions and anecdotal recollections of the past.''

What he is talking about was that there has been criticism of it. We do not claim that we set out to do a comprehensive research project on higher education. What the Committee was doing was inviting the academic community, the people who receive the services of the academic community-the students, employers and the community-to respond to us as to what they thought were issues and needs in higher education. That is what we were doing to set up the debate. From what Senator Aulich and Senator Teague have said, and from my brief and cursory look at this response, what has happened in the Government's response is exactly what a number of people were asking not to happen. Minister Baldwin, let me say, has been left holding the baby, so to speak, as Minister Dawkins has done his dash in higher education and has run out of the door, leaving a fairly tired and beaten around the head sector for Minister Baldwin to deal with.

I will just give some examples of responses to the report when it first came out. For example, one was a letter from a person in politics at Flinders University to the Australian, headed `Let us open up the economic debate-not close our minds'. That is what was being said. People who were responding to the report were saying, `This is the beginning of a debate'.

As we moved around the universities as a committee, when we first started off there was tremendous disquiet and a sense, I suppose, of depression amongst academics as they had been responding to the forced mergers and writing out profiles. Let me say that I was part of this. Before I came into this chamber I was an academic. The institution that I came from merged voluntarily because we knew that mergers were on the boil. That was not an easy experience. It is tiring; it is exhausting. Those in smaller institutions especially spend hours and hours in committees.

One of the other things that concerned me was that those in colleges placed an enormous emphasis on their teaching and were rewarded for it in those institutions. As they moved across into the universities I believed they would find it difficult to have their teaching recognised for promotion. That was another issue that came up. But, as we moved around the institutions, we found that people were tired. I do not think that some of the submissions and some of the questioning that we had at the beginning was as productive as later on when people started to come out of the depression that they were in and began being creative about all sorts of things, and ideas were shared.

The report gave us great hope about some of the issues and some of the points raised in our recommendations. Many of us on the Committee have been out to universities to talk to groups about the report. I have been invited by academics to speak at various institutions and I have found them to be responding positively, as Senator Teague has, to the report. They have been prepared to stand back and accept the criticisms and say that there are things that they need to do. But the Minister is not prepared to do that. He says, `No, it is all okay. That has been done in the White Paper. That has been done in the Green Paper. That has been dealt with by some research fund.' But that is not what the academics were saying to us in response to this. They were saying, `What we need to do is to address those issues that have been raised. Yes, we have a long way to go.' What this academic from Flinders is saying is `Let us not close our minds'. He-or she; I am not sure-said in the letter:
It has been clear for some time that the Australian public and media do not want an in-depth debate on the full range of higher education issues . . .
None the less the debate does continue, despite the general indifference, thanks to the efforts of a hardy few-
that is us-

who take the longer view. It is in this context that the reception so far afforded to the Senate Standing Committee's report Priorities for Reform in Higher Education, only released recently, is so important, and so disappointing.
The letter continues:

Here is a report which tries self-consciously to open up debates, on issues that have been relatively neglected so far in the 1980s-and which is almost immediately condemned out of hand by the minister, distorted by most of the media, and slammed by too many official spokespersons for academe.
Despite its nearly 200 pages, bibliography, compilation of hundreds of submissions and testimony, and weeks of valuable staff work . . .

We must not forget how the staff of the Committee must feel with this sort of response following the effort they have put in, and it was no mean feat. We had hundreds of submissions. They went through them with us and produced a report, then we had this flimsy response from the Government. I will be interested to see their reaction when they get their hands on this. The article continues:

. . . the report seems destined for oblivion-because it dares to ask ``What is higher education for?'' and ``What quality of graduates do we want?'' and to suggest that a better curriculum and better teaching could help bring about higher quality of education.

In passing, let us note that the report fairly specifies that these problems are neither new nor unique to Australia. Moreover, on Mr Dawkins's ``reforms'', it carefully suggests that further investigation is required as the evidence is not all in, while also noting the need for greater support (especially in finance and morale) in order to build and retain high quality institutions.

This is not a quick and superficial report, not a dogmatic, impartial interpretation. There is much that is questionable in the exercise, but it does deserve to be read and to be debated seriously. It at least dares to attempt the difficult tasks of relating quantitative and qualitative changes, structural and academic content dimensions, in higher education.
That is just one quote. What does Sam Lipski say in the Bulletin about the report? On 17 July, he said:
At $19.95, Priorities for Reform in Higher Education-
that might take me on to the efficiencies in the Australian Government Printing Service, but I will not do that at the moment-

is somewhat more expensive than the average paperback but it deserves to be a best-seller at the Australian Government Bookshops which began stocking it last week-especially among those who want the talk about Australia as ``the Clever Country'' to be more than just talk.

Teachers at universities and high schools should pin the report's conclusion on their walls and, even if they throw darts at it, read what it says: ``The Committee believes that Australia is producing graduates who, all too frequently, are not familiar in any disciplined sense with the society in which they are going to practise their chosen profession . . .

I will just stop there for a moment. I had a conversation the other day with someone at a meeting we happened to be attending. He asked me what I did and I told him and we started chatting about privacy issues. He is a lecturer in computer science. He told me how concerned he was that most computer science courses in our Australian universities failed to have concomitant courses in privacy. He sent me in the mail a copy of a course from Armidale University where every unit in computer science addresses privacy issues and the ethics in computer science. That is the sort of debate we were trying to raise in this Committee. They are the sorts of issues we were trying to address to make academics and the community aware of the need for us to ensure that we do not have C.P. Snow's two cultures, that we do not have technological barbarians on the one hand and those educated in the arts on the other hand-that they are integrated; that those in arts and those trained in technology, engineering and computer science understand the ethical implications of technological change and the effect on their society of change.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Senator Harradine says, `Hear, hear!'. He has an interest in medical issues. We should ensure that our scientists who are working in the biological field address ethical issues. I go back to what Sam Lipski was saying:

SPEECH.PARA: ``The Committee believes that Australia is producing graduates who, all too frequently, are not familiar in any disciplined sense with the society in which they are going to practise their chosen profession, who are not critical, analytical creative thinkers, whose education does not provide the basis for adequate flexibility, who are not sufficiently attuned to the need for `lifelong' learning and who are not good communicators. In short, we are producing highly trained technicians who are under educated in the broader sense of the term.
Sam Lipski continued:
Priorities-
that is his nickname for it-

is the latest report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. In the United States, Canada or Britain, any comparable bipartisan parliamentary inquiry about the serious shortcomings of tertiary education would have touched off a national debate about the issues raised.

When someone like Senator Aulich stands up in the chamber and is critical of his own Government's response to our report, and it is not easy to do, that ought to be hailed by the press-but it will not be; there will be some criticism-as what this House, the Senate, can do. It takes a bit of courage and a bit of guts to raise issues, to address them, to be fair and to say what one thinks about an issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Objectivity.

—And objectivity, as Senator Coulter said. We do not see that in this place very often. We are constrained by members of the press, who say as soon as we criticise something that the party is falling apart-whether it be the Labor Party, the Liberal Party or the Australian Democrats. If we make a criticism and if we open up fair and reasonable debate, what happens? We are slammed. We should be thanking Senator Aulich, who is prepared to come out and say what he thinks. Members of the public are not aware of what happens in parliamentary committees-of the cooperation. All they hear is the argy-bargy that occurs in Question Time. The press picks up the adversarial role of this House.

SPEECH.PARA: But here we are, on both sides of the chamber, arguing that this is an issue that needs to be debated, that we ought to raise the profile. This Committee will go on doing that as long as the Senate permits. I am sure that it will, given the fact that the Australian Democrats supported us in a motion. When this report was tabled in the Senate a motion was moved condemning the Minister for his response. Sam Lipski went on to say:

With Priorities . . ., for example, the media have paid rather more attention to the scorn heaped on the committee and its chairman, Senator Terry Aulich, by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, John Dawkins-and Senator Aulich's duly recorded rejoinders-than to the national crisis that Priorities . . . highlights.

The focus was on the personalities rather than on the principles and the issues that we were raising in that document. Why did the Senate condemn the Minister? Why was it able to get a motion through condemning the Minister? Mind you, there was no response in the press. It is a fairly major issue when a Minister is condemned by the Senate. Minister Collins might laugh. He might think that the Senate does not count, and many of his colleagues do think that it does not count.

TALK.START.PARA: —It never seems to affect the Ministers in the House of Representatives. That is what I was laughing at.

—Hopefully the academic community will understand the importance of it; I am sure they will. Minister Dawkins in his response to the Committee said that the Committee was really wasting its time. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: ``(The report) is based on a few observations of a few unrepresentative and in some cases malcontents around the country,'' . . .

I think the Committee will be delighted to send this report out to all those malcontents. They will think: why on earth did we spend hours-and many of them spent hours-making extremely good submissions to have this sort of response from the Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —It was an intemperate response.
—Is the Minister saying that this Minister made an intemperate response?
—Minister Dawkins had made an intemperate response to the report. I agree with you.
—Why did the Minister not vote with us when we condemned him?
—Why didn't Senator Aulich?

—That is tremendous. It has been worth speaking for 20 minutes to hear the Minister say that. I hope the Australian Associated Press is listening. A Minister has said that Min- ister Dawkins made an intemperate response. I think that a Government Minister responsible for education should be more measured in what he says about a Senate committee.
—More temperate.

—I will remind him constantly about his condemnation of the Committee. He said that the report represented two years waste of time on the part of some senators who obviously had too much time on their hands. That is most probably a general reflection of what the House of Representatives thinks about what we do here. Its attitude is that we do not have anything to do-that we have no constituents and do not do any work. Let me remind honourable senators that we will be sitting for two or three weeks longer than the House of Representatives and spending from now until Christmas fixing up its sloppy legislation. But we have time on our hands!

SPEECH.PARA: Let me tell the Minister that if his report-and I want to read it in more detail before I condemn it out of hand, as he condemned our report out of hand; and I do not want to be intemperate-is as evasive as Senator Aulich seems to think it is, given the fact that Senator Aulich had a few more minutes to read it than I did, I think that Minister Baldwin's response is intemperate. It is appalling that a Minister would respond in a way that does not take our priorities for reform in higher education seriously. Maybe `intemperate' was not the right word to use; maybe he was just being offhand and did not take the report seriously.

This Committee is not the sort of committee that just lets things go. We have put down a report entitled Education for Active Citizenship. It is a report that has been acclaimed around the community. In fact, it has been said by some of the senior staff members of the Senate that it is one of the most important reports to be brought down in 20 years. There has been an enormous response. What we have decided to do, and what the Senate is enabling us to do, is continue to study that subject.

I am sure that we will not let priorities in higher education sit on the shelf and be a waste of time not only to us but also to all those people who made submissions and the staff members. That is not what we intend to do. This is a very cooper- ative committee. It has good chairmanship from a Chairman who is prepared to stand up and be counted and say what he thinks about various responses. I can assure the Minister that he has not heard the end of this and that the priorities for reform in higher education will continue and will have an effect, despite Minister Dawkins and Minister Baldwin.
Debate (on motion by Senator Bjelke-Petersen) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The matter of concern to me is a report in today's Sydney Morning Herald. This is not over any by-line, which in many ways makes the error more egregious. The article is headed `Opposition forces dole relaxation'. I think we are all aware of the frenzy that the media have managed to fabricate in recent days in suggesting that somehow the Opposition has gone soft on welfare. I want to record my very great displeasure at the way in which I have been, I believe, wilfully misrepresented by this report. What I made clear to the journalist in question, Peter Hartcher, in no uncertain terms, was that the Opposition believed that the proposal to introduce a liquid assets test was de- ficient in two respects. One of those was that it was arbitrary and blunt in its application and could just as well affect those it was intended to affect, being high income casual workers, as it could those that presumably it is not intended to hurt-people on low incomes, usually with a number of children and very modest levels of savings.

SPEECH.PARA: In the House of Representatives last night-as I indicated to the journalist-we moved an amendment to provide for the Secretary to have a discretion to exempt certain applicants from the four-week waiting period in the event that significant hardship was demonstrated. I think anyone, and certainly a journalist with the experience of Mr Hartcher, would be well aware that hardship is not easily established in relation to assets tests and in other areas of social welfare. Significant hardship is even harder to demonstrate. Therefore, that would be a very modest concession at best.

The worst aspect of the matter, and one to which I take great exception, is the total failure of this journalist to make reference to the other amendment that I indicated we would be moving and that is to tidy up the provision because, as it is worded at the moment, if a person has $5,000 or more on hand in cash, or readily realisable assets, at the date of making an application for unemployment or sickness benefits, that person has to wait for a four-week period. Whilst spouse's income is taken into account, there is nothing to stop that person giving the money away to anyone. That is just reducing this whole provision to nought. It is designed to save $23m in the current year and $33m in a full year. What we propose to do is tighten it up to help the Government save that money by saying that any disposal within a period of three months preceding the date of the application will be regarded as ineffective.

I submit to the Senate that that is a very significant tightening of a welfare measure and one that was totally and wilfully omitted from the report. I therefore take great exception to it, especially in view of the fact that the felony was compounded earlier in the week by Mr Hartcher's suggestion that some cloud cuckoo land proposal from the Centre for Independent Studies was identical to any suggestion made recently by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). I hope that we can look forward to less mischief-making and more accuracy in reporting from that journalist in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

As I understand it, the 1989-90 annual report of the Australia-China Council is not available to us at this time. I want to make a few comments about this very important advisory body to the Federal Government on matters relating to China. Not only does it look at a range of activities, including business contacts between the two countries, but also it looks at cultural matters. The most important thing I want to say is that the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade sees the Australia-China Council as a model for the establishment of a council to deal with matters relating to India.

We believe that the Australia-China Council should be a yardstick for the future development of a council with power to advise the Government on a whole range of matters-business, education, cultural and sporting matters-relating to India. One of the most important recommendations of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee was that there be such a council established; that it include members of Australian business, academics, members of Australian Government organisations to advise the Government on all matters relating to India; that it help boost Australian expertise on India; that it raise awareness in this country about that very important country and that it identify gaps in the relationship between Australia and India.

We say that because we take the view in our report that India is already an important Asian power of the same general order as China, which is of course the subject of this Australia-China Council report. But the Committee took the view that-and I see Senator Teague nodding-a lot of attention has been paid to China. There are institutions in the form of the Australia-China Council already in place to help develop and further that relationship.

The Committee took the view that it is high time that there be an Australia-India council to help foster relations between Australia and India but, most importantly, to help oversee the development in an Australian university of an Indian studies centre to be a repository of knowledge in this country on India. We hope that that centre can be established in the future. I know that members of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade are awaiting with interest the Government's response to our report on India. We hope and trust that there will be some interest in that response to the establishment of an Australia-India council along the lines of the council which currently exists to oversee contacts between Australia and China.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

DEBATE.TITLE: REHABILITATION OF FORMER NUCLEAR TEST SITES IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Two issues arise quite clearly out of this report by the technical assessment group. First, the Government has been very slow to act in this very important area of the protection of the Australian public from radiation resulting from the nuclear tests carried out in the 1950s and the 1960s. Secondly, it shows that we are dealing with very long term radiation risks indeed.

It is now some 30 years since the Maralinga tests. I first became aware of these through a former Royal Australian Air Force employee, one Alvin Hudson, whose job responsibility, in the late 1950s and in the early 1960s, was to bury plutonium on this site. In 1972 Mr Hudson attempted, with the then Minister, Vic Garland, to raise the issue of the radiation hazards of this area. It was simply pushed aside. No action was taken. This was after a so-called clean-up in 1967, which we now know was totally inadequate.

The matter was raised again by Mr Hudson with me in 1978 when, with John Gilbert of Channel 10, we travelled up to the Maralinga site and took quite a lot of film. In praise of Channel 10, it put on a series of programs over about four or five nights, each of about five minutes duration, highlighting the very important problem of plutonium wastes in this area. That led directly to the McClelland Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia between 1952 and 1963 and, of course, indirectly to the paper before us now.

Some honourable senators will recall that for many years Sir Ernest Titterton, the former head of the Atomic Weapons Test Safety Committee, attempted to pour cold water on and treat with disdain anybody who raised the issue of radiation risks associated with Maralinga. Indeed, I well recall him saying that of course there was no plutonium buried up there because plutonium was so valuable that, if it were there, people would go up and take it away. We know that he was proved quite wrong. Eventually the British Government came out and collected quite a large amount of plutonium which was buried quite close to the landing strip at Maralinga.

We also know from subsequent studies that some of the tests were carried out under quite adverse meteorological conditions. One test in particular resulted in fallout which came right down through South Australia and, indeed, even reached south of Adelaide, which itself was exposed to radiation. The way in which the Australian public has been dealt with by successive governments of both persuasions has been quite unsatisfactory.

Page 15 of the report outlines the costs of various options for clean-up. Page 16 says that a well-regulated working environment would result in one fatal cancer among the workers. It states that the clean-up would require some 500 workers over six years. This brings me to my second point. The writers of this report assume that an exposure of five millisieverts per year, which is the maximum allowable for those working in the nuclear industry, is an acceptable radiation exposure. With that level of exposure, the workers involved in the clean-up may suffer one cancer over six years working among those 500 workers.

It goes on to point out that the very small number of people in the Aboriginal community at Oak Valley may suffer one to two fatal cancers per 100 years as a result of the remaining radiation. As we are talking about plutonium radiation with a half-life of 24,000 years, we can see quite clearly that what this report recommends will result in in excess of 200 fatal cancers in that very small community over the lifetime of that radiation exposure.

I raise as a very important issue the fact that there is no reason why deaths in future generations should be discounted and regarded as any less significant than deaths which occur in the present generation. One hopes that the Government will press the United Kingdom Government to, and will itself, carry out a very adequate and final clean-up of this important area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I congratulate the Australian Tourist Commission on its annual report and the tremendous work it does in trying to promote Australia. This work includes working not only to increase the number of overseas visitors to Australia and to maximise the benefits to Australia from those tourists but also to monitor the environmental and social impact of tourism. This report covers a period of two very significant occurrences in Australia's tourist industry. One of these challenges was to be expected-that is, the decline in tourist arrivals after Australia's Bicentenary in 1988 and the tremendous tourist potential of the Brisbane Expo. The other was totally unexpected to the industry. That, of course, as anyone who was aware of what was happening in Australia last year would know, was the long running pilots dispute. In the report the Chairman states:
Australian tourism was hurt by the five-month shutdown of our aviation services. Companies which had expanded to meet demand suddenly lost their cash flow. Many were forced out of business.

The 1989 domestic aviation dispute will be recorded as a national disaster for tourism but, as the report notes on page 46, it was not the only event to damage Australia's reputation as a reliable destination. The second half of the year also saw the failure of major hotel groups and other tourism operators, several tragic coach accidents and a ballooning disaster in central Australia. These factors, coupled with increased and highly aggressive marketing by competing destinations and the opening of eastern Europe, mean that Australia must work harder than ever to hold and increase market share in our primary markets.

Australia finished 1989 with 2,080,000 short term visitor arrivals. This was, despite the problems I mentioned earlier, marginally down on the record 2.25 million visitors during 1988 when Expo 88 and other Bicentennial activities provided extra drawing power. Although the pilots dispute caused heartache in the industry, luckily for Australia, the report notes:
It also raised community perceptions about the size and importance of the tourism industry to unprecedented levels.

According to the Commission, indications are that we will surpass the visitor numbers of 1988 by the end of 1990 and go on to achieve 6.5 million arrivals by the turn of the century. That is quite a number.

I found in my local newspaper today an advertisement about the Lions International Convention to be held in Brisbane from 17 to 21 June 1991. This will certainly be a very large convention for Queensland and will bring up to 40,000 delegates and their families from 130 countries. According to the article, `This would inject at least $80 million into Queensland's economy'. I believe that most of the delegates will stay on the Gold Coast. It will be a very big function and will certainly be a great help to tourism not only in Queensland but in Australia as a whole. The report went on to say:
Growth has returned to pre-dispute levels out of Asia and is improving from Europe and New Zealand.

But, sadly, I note that the Commission, despite its optimistic hopes for next year, noted that tourist potential from North America, `remains soft, but forward bookings point to a rally in this market'. Perhaps it is because Paul Hogan has stopped doing his `shrimp on the barbie' television advertisements. As last year's report noted:
It is apparent that Australia's reputation as a reliable tourist destination had been damaged in many overseas markets, particularly Japan and the US . . . any chance of a turnaround has been dashed.

There can be no doubt that this was the result of Government policies and the disreputable part the Government played in prolonging the pilots dispute. The effects of the dispute cannot be underestimated. The Commission noted in the report that its:
. . . targets are ambitious but not unrealistic, given Australia's quality as a tourist destination and the strategies we have put in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Bjelke-Petersen, in reading the annual report of the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) I noted the effects of the airline dispute on tourism, but I want to rebut some of the comments and some of the conclusions that the honourable senator drew from that dispute. Because Expo was staged in 1988, it was to be expected that there would be some decline in tourism the following year. Therefore, the airline dispute had only a marginal impact on total tourism to this country.
—Some areas were affected worse than others.

—Certainly. As Senator Watson says, some areas were affected more than others, but it is absolutely incorrect to blame the downturn in the tourism industry purely on the airline dispute. There was no doubt that there was going to be a substantial influx of visitors in 1988. Senator Bjelke-Petersen has referred to the substantial number of hotel failures. I also make the point that these did not occur simply as a result of the airline dispute. There were also some very unwise investments in the hotel and hospitality industry in terms of the massive number of properties that came onto the market at the one time, for which occupancy levels were simply unable to be sustained to support borrowings. That was also a very important contributing factor.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the airline dispute, it was very pleasing to see that the ATC adopted a very positive approach. It went out into the international market and attempted to ensure that the problems were minimised. I would praise in this place the work of the ATC and, in particular, the work of the Chairman of the ATC, John Haddad. I know John Haddad personally. —On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following reports of the Auditor-General: Report No. 4 of 1990-91, Department of Employment, Education and Training; and Report No. 10 of 1990-91, Australian Bureau of Statistics, data collection for the consumer price index.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am extremely disappointed with the key findings of the risk management report into the fraud control plan operating within the Department of Employment, Education and Training. The key findings are:

SPEECH.PARA: 1 although the Department spent almost $8 billion in 1989-90, finalisation of its Fraud Control Plan, and the development of procedures for dealing with fraud, had been unduly slow.
2 comprehensive investigations and prosecution guidelines had yet to be completed, and
3 the department had failed to ensure that a strong and viable internal audit unit was maintained following its establishment in July 1987.

These comments are quite scandalous because they denote a strong criticism of the management and the management structure. It is becoming increasingly evident that far too many people in key positions have had inadequate management training. It further illustrates that there are in some sectors of the Public Service people who are incapable of following the Government's dictum of letting the managers manage and take full responsibility for their actions.

I remind the Senate that the onus for effective risk management rests squarely on the shoulders of senior management. Senior management cannot expect to devolve responsibility for decisions to line managers without providing adequate training in the management of risk, for without adequate training the danger is that risks will be taken and not managed. When this happens it is ultimately the public who suffer. Managers need to monitor the costs and benefits of risky decisions. On the other hand, senior managers must push to establish effective internal control sections to promote the receipt of quality feedback on the adequacy of internal controls in place within their organisations.

The initial assessment of risks in an organisation or program must be coordinated at a senior level in all Commonwealth agencies. This assessment cannot be made without input from program managers. Once the level of risk is identified, decisions need to be taken about the controls which should be established to contain the risk at a suitable level.

The report before the Senate today highlights many of the concerns I have had over the years as a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and, through that medium, have expressed. In fact, the PAC issued a discussion paper on internal audit in the Australian Public Service in February 1981. That was report No. 184, which was closely followed by a second report in November 1983. In 1981 to 1983 the Joint Committee of Public Accounts was of the opinion that the establishment of effective internal audit units had not been adequately advanced by many senior public sector managers. To this end, as part of its inquiry into the Australian Audit Office-again, report No. 296-the Committee recommended that the Auditor-General undertake an efficiency audit of internal audit in the Commonwealth sector, which should include a comprehensive survey of internal audit.

I have stated many times in this chamber that internal audits are only as good as the staff employed and far greater emphasis needs to be placed on the training of internal auditors and on promoting their image so that the quality of staff attracted to internal audit positions is enhanced. This training has to extend to education about the sophisticated techniques of planning adequate and meaningful audit coverage.

If Commonwealth agencies continue to allow such a low priority to adequate resourcing and training of internal auditors, something more fundamental has to be examined. Maybe we will have to go as far as looking at placing the necessity for proper internal audits on the statute books via legislation. As I mentioned, the Department of Employment, Education and Training spends almost $8 billion. It should be an utmost priority with this Government to ensure that internal audits be in place and the Department should have in place an adequate fraud control plan. I believe this report is quite scandalous in terms of the comments and observations of the Auditor-General. I ask that expeditious action be taken to remedy the matters raised in this report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

In recommending that the work proceed the Committee recognises the close bilateral relationship between Australia and Papua New Guinea. It also recognises the need for Australia to give high priority to the effective management of our relationship. This includes the protection of Australian interests there.

Due to the restriction in the Public Works Committee Act 1969 on meetings of the Public Works Committee outside Australia and its external Territories, the Committee was unable to inspect the proposed site or existing accommodation in Port Moresby. This is completely contrary to the normal practice of the Committee which has always regarded site inspections as an integral and extremely important part of its consideration of a project.

In this particular case, due to the absence of a site inspection, the Committee was hampered in its consideration of the project, particularly in relation to issues of security. The Committee believes that Section 12(1) of the Public Works Committee Act 1969 should be amended to remove the restriction on Public Works Committee meetings being held outside Australia. The Committee will be approaching the Minister for Administrative Services on this matter in the near future.
The second report I have tabled deals with the redevelopment of the Aeronautical Research Laboratory site at Fishermens Bend in Victoria.
The Committee has concluded that there is a need for the redevelopment of the ARL site at Fishermens Bend in Victoria.

ARL is part of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation and this proposal sought to redevelop the site it now occupies by refurbishing a number of buildings, demolishing others and providing additional external works, such as car parking and extended security services.
The project will cost $17.5 million in April 1990 prices.
From the Committee's perspective, this was an unusual project because of its length and complexity, and because of the issues it raised.

The Tasmanian Opposition and Government both forwarded detailed proposals that Aircraft Systems Division of ARL, together with the RAAF's School of Air Traffic Control and the Civil Aviation Authority's search and rescue training facilities, be relocated to Newnham at Launceston and, with existing institutions there, form national centres for simulation and aviation studies.

The Committee considered these proposals very carefully. Both the Tasmanian Government and Opposition gave evidence at each of the public hearings. The Committee inspected facilities at Newnham on 18 July 1990.
Having considered the evidence presented to it, the Committee believes that ARL will function more effectively and efficiently if Aircraft Systems Division remains at Fishermens Bend.

The Committee's reference from the Parliament dealt with the redevelopment of the ARL site at Fishermens Bend. Accordingly, as was made clear at the public hearing on 5 September, we were unable to comment on the merits or otherwise of the proposal to transfer the RAAF and CAA facilities to Newnham. The proponents of these proposals are, of course, free to advocate them to relevant Ministers and organisations.

This proposal raised some very important occupational health and safety issues. The Committee is satisfied that appropriate measures have been taken to deal with radioactive material and chemical contaminates found on the Fishermens Bend site.

The third report I tabled is for the provision of a new air traffic services centre for the Civil Aviation Authority in Brisbane. As part of the CAA's consolidation and rationalisation of facilities and functional elements in Queensland, a 14 hectare site has been purchased at the former Brisbane Airport. This site includes the former Australian Airlines terminal. The CAA proposes to rehabilitate this building to house new radar equipment being acquired.

The Committee concluded that the location of the new equipment in the refurbished terminal offers cost and operational advantages over other alternatives examined. These alternatives included extending the existing air traffic services centre which is not favoured because of the higher cost, its condition, location and the need for existing equipment to continue to operate during the construction of extensions. Another alternative examined was the relocation of the centre to a greenfields site.
This alternative would be relatively expensive, it would cause disruption, and would delay the commissioning of new equipment.

The Committee has recommended that the CAA undertake an assessment of energy demand for air conditioning during detailed design, with the aim of minimising electricity charges without compromising the operational effectiveness of the centre.

The cost of CAA operations is recovered from charges on the aviation industry. The Committee therefore sought details on how the proposal will be funded as the capital cost of the proposal will have an impact on the level of charges levied by the CAA.

The CAA advised the Committee that it is undertaking a major capital investment program involving nearly $500 million being spent over the next five years. During the first few years of its existence, the CAA has undertaken a number of initiatives designed to improve productivity and reduce charges.
The CAA advised the Committee that whilst the investment program is substantial, it is already producing productivity gains which will enable it to reduce charges to the aviation industry.
I commend these three reports to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I make the point that the process of having a document such as this tabled in the Parliament-a process which was set in train by a motion of my former colleague, Senator Macklin, in this place in November 1988-does appear to be having a desirable effect on the Government. I make the same complaint I made about an earlier document, and that is that this one does not contain dates on which the unproclaimed legislation to which it refers was actually passed. It makes making comments like this, when we have not had this document for very long, somewhat more difficult. Nevertheless, it is a process which does seem to be working quite well. In fact, the document is getting thinner and thinner each time we get it. In April 1989 it was a 25-page document; in December of that year it was 29 pages; in May this year we had one with 20 pages and this one only has 13. Unless the Government's explanations are getting much shorter, one can only say that less legislation is remaining unproclaimed.

That is important because the Government puts legislation before us in this place eventually-after we have been here for some weeks-and presses us to pass it, very often claiming enormous urgency. At the moment the Senate is looking at some 65 Bills which the Government is telling us it wants through before the end of this year, and another 12 which the Government would like to be given if it is possible. I do not know how any of that is possible in the Senate in the next four weeks.

The pressure on these issues has been quite extraordinary at times. For instance, when we have wished to negotiate amendments with the Government we have been told no, this legislation is too urgent, we cannot hold it up and mess around by having amendments. Then we have seen those same Bills unproclaimed for many months and, in some cases, many years.

It is of concern that sometimes legislation is unproclaimed for reasons which are somewhat disturbing. There can be a tendency to give way to bureaucratic influence. There are some examples where we are waiting for regulations to be put in place, and other work to be done at the bureaucratic level and that is holding up the proclamation of legislation. Many sections of this legislation are unproclaimed because they are going to be repealed. I really do not see why the Government cannot get on with that sort of tidying up and housekeeping if it really intends to repeal this legislation.

There is also an element in some of this legislation where it appears that the Government may be giving way to the States. In some instances, legislation is said not to have been proclaimed because the Government is awaiting cooperation and moves from the States. I would be concerned about that in some areas because it is important that the Federal Government accept its responsibility and pursue its responsibility as the national government of this country.

I give an example of one piece of legislation that is of concern, that is, the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Act 1989, proclamation of which, we are told, has been deferred to enable clarification of some administrative and policy issues that arose as a result of the intention to repeal the Hostels Act. We are told that it will be proclaimed in late 1991, but that area does seem to me to be an example of problems in the bureaucratic arrangements attached to that legislation. If we have to wait, after passing this legislation in 1989, until 1991 for those sections of the Act to be proclaimed, I think that that is an extraordinarily long time if it is just a question of putting in place surrounding bureaucratic structures.

Obviously I have to comment on the last piece of unproclaimed legislation in the list, that is, part IV, sections 12 to 18, of the Financial Corporations Act 1979. It is interesting that just today in this place a private member's Bill was introduced by my colleague Senator Spindler, the Financial Corporations (Prudential Standards) Amendment Bill 1990, which picks up part IV of the Financial Corporations Act 1979, which is that provision of the Act which would empower the Government to impose direct controls on non-banking financial institutions.

I shall have more to say about the Australian Democrats' views about the failure of successive governments since 1974 to proclaim that provision of the Financial Corporations Act. As a Victorian from a State where the collapse of financial institutions has created enormous economic and financial damage and personal damage to many ordinary Australians, I state that the significance of this piece of legislation appearing today on the same day as the Democrats are moving to effectively institute that piece of legislation is quite strong.

We believe that successive governments have been extremely lax in not proclaiming that piece of legislation and that much of the financial stress and distress that have been caused in our community, particularly recently, can be traced right back to the very fact that this piece of legislation has not been proclaimed since 1974 and to the failure by successive Federal governments to pick up their responsibility to depositors in non-bank financial institutions around this country. They have walked away from their responsibility. The most recent of those to do that is the current Treasurer, Mr Keating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: -I wish also to speak on the paper on unproclaimed legislation to which Senator Powell has been speaking. As she said, it was very much the initiative of Senator Macklin and, on our side, of Senator Puplick, both of whom took a keen interest in the issue of unproclaimed legislation. They seem to be continuing their activities together, and I am sure that we look forward to their very serious book on the process of Parliament. Also, many of us will be very interested to see the novel that they are producing, but that is an aside. I am sure that we shall see some of ourselves in that book.
—Under a different name.

—Yes, under a different name. As Senator Powell was saying, we have seen the amount of unproclaimed legislation decrease since this sort of document has been an activity of the Senate. Let me give another example. When I was speaking earlier on priorities for reform in higher education and the Minister's response to that matter, I talked about the Minister's attitude to the Senate and how he had said that the senators on the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training had more than enough time on their hands, implying that we, as senators, really did not do very much. I remind honourable senators that, when they move around talking about the role of the Senate, they should be talking about the function of this place as a House of review.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Powell said, often legislation is pushed through the House of Representatives, a perfect example of that being the Family Law Act at the end of 1987. That piece of legislation was pushed through the House of Representatives and there was an attempt to push it through the Senate, but it was delayed. There were 4 7/8 days of activity in this place to ensure that that legislation, with which all of us agreed-the Democrats, the Government and the Opposition-was amended. In fact, Minister Tate praised Senator Durack for his contribution to the chamber at that time.

That is the sort of review and attention to detail that we see in this place. More and more, this Government has a total disregard for the Parliament and the parliamentary process. We saw legislation this week of which the shadow Minister did not even have a copy. That legislation was to be introduced the next day and it had not been printed. With that sort of shoddy handling of Government business, it is no wonder that we see legislation unproclaimed: it has not been properly thought through.

Fortunately, we have in the Senate people who take an interest in this area, both in the Opposition and in the Democrats, and I believe that this has drawn the attention of Ministers to this important area. As we have seen, in some cases where legislation has not been proclaimed, there may have been some quite serious effects.

As Senator Powell said, there are a number of pieces of legislation on this list in respect of which it is simply stated that there is a need for it to be repealed. I can hardly understand why such legislation is still there and why the responsible Ministers do not get on with it. I hope that Minister Bolkus, who is not actually sitting at his desk, will remind Ministers of their responsibility to look at this report and to do everything in their power to have the legislation either proclaimed or repealed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill, and move:
