DEBATE.TITLE: DARWIN TO ADELAIDE SOLAR CAR RACE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that:
(i) the car leading the Darwin to Adelaide solar car race is equipped with solar cells researched and made in Sydney at the University of New South Wales by Professor Martin Green,
(ii) as of the morning of 13 November 1990 this car was 150 km ahead of its nearest rival which was made in Japan,
(iii) this Federal Government has progressively reduced its funding of renewable energy research,

(iv) the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had the gall to suggest that Australia needs to become a clever country when it clearly has leading-edge science and technology appropriate to the urgent needs of tomorrow's greenhouse world, and
(v) this research and technology is being starved of funds as a direct consequence of the decisions of this Government; and
(b) calls on the Hawke Government to reverse, as a matter of priority, its damaging approach to funding research in the area of renewable energy.

I remind the Senate, in beginning debate on the motion, that we will be bringing this to a vote at the end. Secondly, although the motion had its genesis in a great deal of enthusiasm over the absolutely magnificent performance of the so-called Swiss car powered by Australian designed solar cells, this led me to reflect upon the absolutely atrocious way in which this Government has dealt with this leading edge technology. I direct the Senate's attention particularly to subparagraphs (iv) and (v) and paragraph (b) of the motion, which state:

(iv) the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had the gall to suggest that Australia needs to become a clever country when it clearly has leading-edge science and technology appropriate to the urgent needs of tomorrow's greenhouse world, and
(v) this research and technology is being starved of funds as a direct consequence of the decisions of this Government; and
(b) calls on the Hawke Government to reverse, as a matter of priority, its damaging approach to funding research in the area of renewable energy.

Although I will draw on the solar car as an example, I will direct my remarks particularly to those paragraphs because that is the important crux of this motion. This motion speaks of the need for real vision, real courage and real leadership in facing the challenges of the future. It speaks of the failure of the Hawke Government to meet those challenges, or even to recognise that they exist. I must say that the Opposition has contributed very substantially to this failure and has given every indication that in this respect it would be worse than the present Government.

The critical importance of changing our patterns of energy use in a greenhouse world has not been comprehended by most members in this chamber. Sustainable energy technologies, renewable energy sources and energy efficient products are crucial to the future viability of both our nation and our planet. The Government's energy vision was spelt out in one of the most depressing documents ever tabled in this chamber-the Energy 2000 paper. The Energy 2000 paper looked forward to a world which consumed Australian fossil fuels and uranium at an accelerated rate. Metaphorically speaking, it rubbed its hands in glee at the thought of the impact on our balance of trade of that increase in sales. It was as though the environmental concerns could be disregarded and resource depletion was simply not a problem.

The Government's and the Opposition's technological vision is bound up in outdated science fiction images of the twenty-first century in which we all lead high material consumption lifestyles, dominated and cushioned by a bewildering array of high technology services and gleaming devices. Information technology has been singled out for attention of a particularly gee whiz variety. This is evident from the telecommunications debate, the partnerships for development program and the proposed multifunction polis, on which I have spoken and questioned Senator Button at some length on a number of occasions.

However, ecologically sustainable development does not depend nearly as much on further advances in information systems as it does on sustainable energy technologies. The obsession-I stress `obsession'-with telecommunications has more to do with facilitating the speculative movement of capital at the speed of light than with productive activity to secure our economic, social and environmental future.

The findings of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) have far-reaching implications for the vision and policies that we should be pursuing. I stress that: this is the imperative that we must meet. The critical finding is that in order to stabilise the concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere-I stress `stabilise', not reduce back to what they were before the start of the industrial era, but merely to stabilise-the global rate at which carbon dioxide is emitted must be cut by over 60 per cent. If this does not happen, carbon dioxide levels are destined to rise until fossil fuels are entirely depleted. The resultant climate change would probably render the globe absolutely uninhabitable.

The IPCC concluded that the global annual average emissions of carbon must fall from 1.45 tonnes per person to about 0.35 tonnes to stabilise-I stress that word-atmospheric concentrations. But Australia is now one of the most energy wasteful nations on earth, being somewhere between second and fifth in the world in terms of our profligate use of fossil fuel. We will, therefore, have to reduce our energy consumption to a much greater extent than most other nations. Australians now emit four and a half tonnes of carbon per person per year. To reduce this to the global average of 0.35 tonnes represents a cut not of 60 per cent, not of 80 per cent, but of 92 per cent.

The task before us is to reduce our emissions by this very large amount while assisting Third World countries to energy sustainability without their following our environmentally destructive path and repeating our mistakes. This puts the Government's highly qualified 20 per cent cuts in greenhouse gas emissions by 2005 in proper prospective. Twenty per cent is all the Government is offering-and 20 per cent with very severe qualifications even on that amount. We have much further to go.

I read in yesterday's Australian newspaper that, rather than accept the inevitability of the environmental imperatives that I have just outlined, Senator Button is leading several of his colleagues to exclude major developments for environmental assessment. I see Senator Button as one of the most dangerous people, along with the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in this Parliament. This Government is leading this country in totally the wrong direction.

A landmark study of global energy policy by Jose Goldemberg and others has concluded that some progress in the direction required could be made quite readily given present technology by stringent energy efficient programs and increased use of renewable sources. This would allow energy consumption in industrialised countries to fall to 3.2 kilowatts per person, with no loss of service-in other words, a substantial reduction in energy consumption per person, with no loss whatsoever in the end services to which that energy is put, while Third World consumption would rise to 1.3 kilowatts. For Australians, this would mean a cut of 50 per cent-a substantial move in the right direction.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I was making the point that it was possible to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions very significantly while allowing Third World consumption to rise somewhat and at the same time meet the end use services without any significant increase in cost. I said that we could do this with a 50 per cent cut in energy. While that is nowhere near the 92 per cent I indicated earlier that was necessary in the ultimate situation, nonetheless it was a much more substantial start than the Government's 20 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear to the Australian Democrats, but obviously not to either the Government or the Opposition, that the development of a sustainable energy base is the single greatest challenge which we face both as a nation and as global citizens. In its rhetoric, the Federal Government is starting to acknowledge that huge savings in energy consumption and money are possible by energy conservation and the use of energy efficiency technologies. I will show later in this speech that those words, however, have not been met by very much action.

The Government, the Opposition and Australian business also appear to be convinced that renewable energy sources have almost no role to play. Government funding of renewable energy sources has fallen 88 per cent in real terms in the 12 years since 1978. Funding supplied by the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council (NERDDC) for renewable sources in 1978-79 was $4.66m in 1978 dollars. In 1989-90 this had fallen to $1.32m. This decline is particularly scandalous in view of the establishment in December 1987 of a renewable energy research trust account funded from oil tax revenue in response to Democrat pressure in the Senate which we applied at that time.
In a letter to Senator Janine Haines, the then Leader of the Australian Democrats, the then Minister for Resources, Peter Morris said:
. . . the Government is willing to commit an additional-
I stress the word `additional'-
$5m over five years for . . . renewable energy and energy conservation and efficiency.

That commitment has not been met. Estimated expenditure from the special trust account in 1990-91-that is the current Budget year-is $483,000, less than half of the $1m promised by Mr Morris in the recent past. Just before the extra funding was agreed to in 1987 the Government announced grants of $2.1m for NERDDC funding for renewable energy. The 1989-90 figure was $1.2m; in other words, roughly half.

Some of the States have shown a similarly short-sighted approach. In 1987 the activities of the Solar Energy Research Institute of Western Australia was greatly reduced while the Solar Energy Research Centre of the University of Queensland was totally disbanded. Federal officials are wont to claim that there are simply not enough worthy projects to justify greater funding. However, our research-that is, the research of the Democrats-has shown that numerous projects of world class have not been funded and researchers are leaving the field. It is remarkable that world class researchers such as Dr David Mills of the University of Sydney have made great advances while constantly having to fight for funding. Just as importantly, there has been no strategic use of the purchasing power of the Government to take new technologies out of the laboratory and into production.

Here I return to the first couple of items of the motion which refer to the solar car race currently progressing between Darwin and Adelaide. The Solar Challenge car race illustrates very well this short-sightedness. The Swiss entry, The Spirit of Biel, which earlier today had increased its lead-from the time the motion was moved two days ago-to 250 kilometres, is using high efficiency solar cells designed by a University of New South Wales team headed by Professor Martin Green. While some Federal money did go towards that research, the arrays of cells were actually manufactured in Germany by Telefunken.

There are several points I would like to make about that. The most efficient cells developed by Professor Martin Green in his laboratory have achieved a 24 per cent efficiency. These are the last generation of cells which achieve only 17 per cent efficiency. So there has been almost a 50 per cent further increase in the efficiency of the solar cells and yet these cells have been put into an array not in Australia, not using Australian labour and not using Australian money for support, but by Telefunken in Germany.

We need to appreciate the extraordinary technological advance which these cells indicate. In 1987 the Solar Challenge was won by General Motors-Holden's Ltd Sunraycer-most people will remember that beetle shaped car-using gallium-arsenide cells worth $1.5m. The Swiss car is using silicon cells achieving the same efficiency and costing $20,000. It has reached Alice Springs in exactly the same time as the Sunraycer did in 1987. That represents a 75-fold increase in the dollar efficiency in just three years. As race organiser Hans Tholstrup says, `If that's not one hell of an advance for technology and humanity, I don't know what is'. Even so, the best is yet to come.

As I pointed out, the cell array on the Swiss car has an overall efficiency of only 17 per cent. Professor Green's goal is to reach 30 per cent efficiency, which is very close to the maximum theoretically achievable efficiency, and to mass produce thin film cells at around the cost of their glass substrate.

By comparison, in my own personal purchases of computer equipment-I remind the Senate that computing is one area that is normally regarded as rapidly developing-I reckon that there has been about a 20-fold improvement in the dollar power available in computing in the last 10 years. I am comparing a computer I bought in 1980 with one that I bought this year. Compared with that technology we have a 75-fold increase in the dollar efficiency in solar cells developed right here in Australia at the University of New South Wales.

As spectacular as this progress in computing is, it looks absolutely insignificant compared with the technology development in photovoltaic cells in Australia. The Federal Government has missed an extraordinary opportunity to develop an Australian technology of environmental and commercial value. This is very symptomatic of the malaise identified in a recent speech by computer industrialist, Lionel Singer, in which he pointed out that North American, Japanese and European governments stimulate a high technology industry by encouraging individuals to create solutions to a problem that needs to be fixed. If there is one problem that needs to be fixed in this world, it is the problem of greenhouse. Mr Singer contrasted the approach overseas-that is, the European, Japanese and North American approach-to stimulating technology with that of the Australian Government's techno-cultural cringe. He said:
Not much thought is paid to bolting down true Australian based technology.

While he was referring there to information technology, the criticism applies even more to renewable energy. Switzerland, I would remind the Senate, is busy building what will be Europe's biggest solar power station, with a peak rating of half a megawatt. That is not very large by world standards, but it is interesting that the Swiss are doing it in a country that has much less sunshine than Australia.

Switzerland has registered a 100 per cent increase in the use of solar power with units of over 100 kilowatts being installed to power whole streets and businesses while feeding power into the grid. Swiss authorities acknowledge that solar power is more expensive than some other forms, but they have made a strategic decision to invest in solar technologies because they understand-but the Australian Government does not, evidently-that their energy future demands it. I point out that just the other day a Swiss expert said that the best solar generated electricity is now available at only twice the cost of nuclear generated electricity.

Given what I have said earlier about the possibility of doubling our efficiency without any increase in the end use costs-that is, the costs of the services which the electricity is finally used for, and given also that there has been a 75-fold increase in the cost efficiency of solar cells developed in this country in only three years, one can see that we are very close to the break-even point in which we could have a substantial solar generation of electricity.

There are a number of renewable sources that are viable right now which could make a large dent in our energy consumption. For example, solar water heaters for domestic use could eliminate most of the fossil fuel energy used for this purpose-for heating water. That is responsible for about 6 per cent of our CO2 emissions. Wind energy is economic in many locations. Passive solar building designs are cost effective and again I refer to Dr David Mills and his solar steam generator. What we are seeking from government is support not just for the glitzy high-tech but for what is appropriate technology to get the job done. Dr David Mills's steam generating evacuated tube technology has proven its ability by providing steam for Sydney's Campbelltown Hospital. This could offset a large proportion of our industrial use of fossil fuels.

The barriers preventing these sources from entering the market in significant quantities are non-technical in nature. They are political and they lie very much with the Government. To take just one example: if I buy electricity from the grid, I pay for my share of the generating plant over a long period. The cost of the generating equipment which my purchase of electricity makes necessary is amortised perhaps over as many as 25 years. On the other hand, if I buy an energy efficient light globe or a solar water heater, I have to pay the total capital costs up-front. The equivalent financing arrangements used by central electricity generation utilities would remove this market distortion and immediately make economically viable a large array of technologies that we already have available to us.

To take another example, in Australia it would be illegal to connect private, small solar generators to the electricity grid, as is happening in Switzerland. To remove these barriers means reorienting our existing electricity utilities to focus on selling efficiency and renewable sources-that is what Amory Lovins calls `negawatts' rather than megawatts-which would offset the need for large, expensive and environmentally damaging supply sources and have long construction lead times requiring risky long-range demand predictions. I would point out, as I did in a question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, the other day, that there is a crisis with our electricity utilities which is inhibiting such reform.
Michael Gill, writing in the Australian Financial Review of 24 September, summed up the problem well when he pointed out:
Electrical utilities have run up a $32 billion debt.
I repeat that this is a debt of $32,000m-
Over-optimistic demand projections have left them with excess capacity. Energy prices have been subsidised in attempts to stimulate demand, and energy efficiency measures largely ignored.
The utilities stand in the way of real change because of their economic predicament and the outdated assumptions on which they operate.

The Queensland Electricity Commission (QEC) has begun to build a 600 megawatt hydro-power scheme at Tully-Millstream which is likely to submerge 3,700 hectares of tropical forests, 1,400 hectares of which is listed as World Heritage, with the remainder on the National Estate. Tully-Millstream-if it is built-will cost $550m. On past indications, 25 per cent of this will be spent overseas for the heavy generating equipment. Yet the QEC admits to debts of between $4.1 billion and $6.7 billion, depending on which of its reports one reads. This debt is growing at a rate of 15 per cent per year-well above inflation. The QEC is convinced that the demand will be there in 1996 when the station is supposed to start operating. But this is the same QEC which in 1982 overpredicted 1988 demand by 1,000 megawatts-an error of about 30 per cent and nearly twice the output of the Tully-Millstream scheme.

The Government and the Opposition have expended enormous energy debating the alleged need for telecommunications micro-reform. Yet even the Opposition has conceded that Telecom Australia basically works. It provides a reasonable service and pays its way. Indeed it makes a profit. By contrast, the electricity utilities are not providing a reasonable service and are not paying their way. They have run up $32 billion of foreign debt. Their operations dwarf those of Telecom. Capital investment in the electricity utilities totals $50 billion-approximately four times that of Telecom.

Energy sector reform should be at the top of the Government's list. Yet the recent Special Premiers Conference could do no more than discuss possible extensions to the interstate network and other ways of improving interstate arrangements. When on Tuesday I asked Senator Button to comment on Federal control of electricity supply, he said he would obtain a response. This reply, only two days ago, indicates clearly that Senator Button and the Hawke Government have not even considered this important matter. So on the one hand the Government has intruded into the operations of Telecom, which is efficient and profitable, but on the other it has failed to address electricity generation which is wasteful and has caused a debt of $32 billion.

What clearer indication, even on the Government's own exclusively dollar-based criteria, could one find that the Government is simply looking in the wrong direction? When one adds the problem of greenhouse, of course, one sees that quite clearly the Government is headed in the wrong direction.

I simply point out that by directing government expenditure in appropriate ways to help support these burgeoning technologies-in which we are not behind; we are right at the very forefront-we would move this technology to a point where it would become extremely valuable to Australia and the rest of the world. Indeed, if one looks around one finds that the Federal Government is well aware that its spending power can be exercised strategically. Senator Button has said:

. . . one fundamental element of a policy environment conducive to the development of a robust manufacturing sector is to ensure that the maximum benefits are obtained from the Government's considerable purchasing power.
He was, of course, referring to the purchase of submarines, frigates and other military equipment.

This strategic exercise in purchasing power through the military Budget is a shocking misdirection of national resources at a time when global environmental disaster is looming and the stimulation of global development should be our first priority. If we do not act now, future generations will curse our shortsightedness; if we do act, we have every reason to be optimistic that, for the first time since the dawn of the industrial age, human kind will live well and within its ecological means.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on behalf of the Opposition on this motion by Senator Coulter, I feel I should point out that the leading car referred to in the motion is a Swiss entrant called the Spirit of Biel, the solar cells for which were designed by the team headed by Professor Green at the University of New South Wales. As I understand it, however, they were not built in Sydney; they were built by the German Aerospace Co. Whether Senator Coulter's information or mine is accurate, I cannot be sure. One interesting piece of information that I obtained is that it performs 10 per cent better here than in Switzerland, due to the amount of sun that we enjoy. I also understand that the leading Australian entry was in sixth place at Alice Springs yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: The program that is referred to at the University of New South Wales gets its funding from a variety of sources-including private companies, the Australian Research Council, the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council (NERDDC), and the Department of Energy in the United States-and has recently been made a centre of excellence by the Federal Government. To put the program on the footing that it would like, the centre needs to be successful in an application which is currently under way for a Federal Government cooperative centre. I hope that Senator Coulter's motion and our support for it might go some way to helping the centre to achieve the funding it seeks on an important matter, certainly one that is well suited to Australia.

The results of research projects supported by the Government, according to the Minister for Resources, Alan Griffiths, `demonstrate Australia's place as a world leader in solar energy research'. Mr Griffiths, in his press release of 8 November from which I have just quoted, drew attention to the research into solar cells at the University of New South Wales. The interesting thing is that governments, in the way they do, have tended to enjoy taking the credit when something is successful. From watching politics over a number of years, I know that governments do enjoy sharing the limelight with successors in other fields. Perhaps one of the features of the energy debate has been that governments have tended to come and go, depending on the fashion in the energy world. Of course, that also has something to do with the price of oil. Currently, with oil prices rising, alternative energy sources have become of much greater interest to all of us, including the Government.

The trouble is that we have not had established a sustained and consistent research effort over time. The angle of criticism which I would have is that this is something which governments cannot turn on and off like a tap. It is something which must be sustained and, for the country's sake, alternative energy research should not be subject to the whim of fashion.

It seems that we have a comparative and natural advantage in the availability of sunlight. Many people would say that that is an underutilised advantage. The journal of the Australian and New Zealand Solar Energy Society, Solar Progress, has claimed that Commonwealth spending on renewable energy resource related research has collapsed over the decade. According to the journal, the spending in the area of renewable resources dropped by 88 per cent over the last 12 years. If that is correct, it would tend to suggest that we are spending on renewable energy research only about one-eighth of what we spent in 1978, at the time of funding of NERDDC. If those figures are correct, it would appear that the Government seems to be evacuating the area of renewable energy research. The Government has been prepared to draw attention to itself by advertising the breakthroughs in these research efforts and those that it continues to support, but it has not been continuing the effort on a sustained level.

I do not think that the Government has appreciated the long term timeframes involved in research. There has been a history of pulling the pin on research programs before they have been able to work up to a suitable level of activity. The research community needs consistency in the application of policy and certainty as to its direction. That is absent under this Government. In that sense, we should be directing attention to some of the organisational issues in support for solar energy research.

The theme of greater cooperation between the Commonwealth and the States is very much in fashion, and energy research and research into renewable energy are areas which could be properly addressed in that framework. There are national issues, but a coordinated and cooperative approach with coherent objectives across all States could well provide an important boost for such areas as solar energy. We must not forget that there has been a real problem with the entry of people into science and only today an article appearing in the Australian newspaper talked about the ageing of the scientific community and the sexism, if you like, of the scientific community. There is clearly a need for more women to go into scientific research. We have an underprovision of people generally to fill the jobs which have been advertised for physics graduates.

I noticed that last year there were 810 job advertisements for physics graduates in the Australian newspaper but that the nation as a whole produced only 360 graduates and Ph.D students in physics. There was quite a drift away from tertiary studies in maths, science, technology and engineering between 1977 and 1987. Of course, we tend to see those that we do produce go overseas. The salaries in the public sector in Australia have consistently been lower than those being offered overseas. In the private sector there has not necessarily been the concentration on research as part of industry that is desirable if we are to become the clever country.

I know that we are limited in time tonight and I do not wish to labour the point. We in the Opposition believe that the Government's priorities have not been satisfactory when it comes to funding research in the area of renewable energy. We think this is very largely a matter of priorities within its approach to science and the habit it has had of jumping onto bandwagons and then getting off when something more attractive comes along, which is not conducive to the long term and valuable research that this country needs. It means that our scientists and our engineers are inclined to look to greener fields, both for better salaries and for more consistent program management. This brain drain will not stop unless the Government is prepared to take a fresh look at how people are funded for projects and how controlled our universities are by the central government in the projects which they can undertake and in the money which goes to these centres. I urge the Government to look at national priorities when it comes to renewable energy research and to reverse the direction which, I agree, has been a damaging one in this field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Coulter's motion deserves a great deal more seriousness than it has been offered so far, either through the attention offered to it by Government speakers or the depth of consideration that other honourable senators have been able to muster for it. I know that Senator Coulter, in his usual modest way, would not have drawn the chamber's attention to his own press release, which he put out in an attempt to show support for the people who have designed and manufactured and then led a race from Darwin to Alice Springs with their solar powered car.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter led his press release with the heading `Well done Australia'. It is that sort of support which I thought that a government interested in the future of Australia would be able to offer the designers of the particular solar panels which are used on this vehicle. It is the design on which they need to be congratulated. It is the design of something which is immensely more efficient than the previous victor in this race. That point seems to have escaped other commentators and honourable senators who have considered this motion. It is a fact that it is within Australia's capacity to lead the world in the design of high-tech modern technology applications not only in the design of solar panels but also in many other fields of renewable energy research. Senator Coulter has spent many sessions in this place trying to point out that we really do not need to be suffering this cringe of looking towards another international source for leadership in this area.

We are talking about solar power. Before I go any further, the point should be made that even the term suffers a little. It is considered a soft issue, an issue which does not seem to be very macho or very attractive to the hard core of politics. When this matter is considered properly, we should be aware that everything on this earth is solar powered. Even the dirtiest of the coal, even the greatest grunting diesel engine, derives its original energy source from the sun. We should be paying much more attention to the correct use of our solar derived energy sources.

To harness our energy from the sun in a manner which is as direct as possible is only commonsense to me. All the other sources are several steps away from the initial energy which was the input to create the fuel which we use. One of the solar created energy sources we are exploiting is coal or, in fact, the entire petroleum resource. We recognise that this resource is finite. To be prepared for the day when that resource is exhausted, we should be conducting research tests and evaluations now. This would assist us in the capacity to substitute truly renewable fuels for the finite petroleums. This is all conventional wisdom; we are all well aware of it. It is really difficult to understand why there is no evidence at all that this Government has accepted that wisdom. It should accept it and then go on with enthusiastic support for research into renewable energy applications. But we do not get that enthusiastic support; we get begrudging acceptance of this motion, not even tacit attention paid to Senator Coulter's speech, which was as enlightened as any other that one could hear throughout the world on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the universe? He did it after the sun went down.

—Whatever the pathetic protestations from the Government side, the fact is that I had to make a comment such as that to engender some sort of attentiveness from the government benches. Australia has within it the capacity to show examples to the world.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very interesting that earlier this afternoon I attended one of the meetings of the parliamentary United Nations Children's Fund group, where we were told, of all things, about solar powered child weighing scales that would be provided, through UNICEF, to the world. This is a wonderful project. Through this project our technology is on display to the world. It will benefit the world. It is frustrating that not more of these sorts of projects are being developed and allowed to be brought to fruition, to actual production.

Australia is particularly well placed in this regard. We have our own domestic market, which has immediate application to many products which incorporate a self-contained energy collection and conversion process. Our isolated communities provide ideal proving grounds for such leading technologies. These leading technologies are such things as solar powered public telephones, and solar powered beacons and navigational aids, et cetera. People who live in isolated areas understand and appreciate these things more, because they are able to be demonstrated. Quite often, the proving ground which is our outback is the place where Australian ingenuity can lead to great advances for people in Third World countries.

We are at the forefront of this technology. Our particular geography has forced us to take that position. Our harnessing of renewable energy has become part of our very heritage through our establishment and development of windmills all over the country. I subscribe to a magazine called Soft Technology. In that magazine it was reported that a backyard researcher and talented engineer has been able to improve the efficiency of our traditional windmill, which harnesses renewable energy. He was able to improve the traditional design by replacing the steel blades with aluminium ones. I am sure that even Government members would understand the basic engineering principle of centrifugal forces being lower with reduced weight and the fact that therefore the blades could be increased in size. For a given piece of equipment the efficiency could thus be improved. Such ingenuity has been the hallmark of Australian pioneers. We can and should be taking advantage of this by exploiting such developments and taking such work internationally to the stage where they become marketable products.

Again, it is because of the lack of understanding and lack of appreciation of just what we are capable of in this country that so often such developments do not occur-they die before they are brought to fruition-and are lost because our ingenuity cannot be fully developed. This is where government initiative and support is necessary and would be welcomed.

The other area where government support is required and where it would be beneficial is the renewable energy which could be derived from ethanol used as motor fuel. Despite being bombarded with facts and examples that demonstrate that ethanol is a viable, effective fuel, despite having an Australian trial conducted by Queensland canegrowers demonstrating the suitability of ethanol as a fuel, and despite the only too obvious threats to the supply of existing petroleum-based motor fuels, this Government is unable to see beyond the entrenched industrial position.

This Government is unable to see the huge advantages which would accrue to the Australian economy and the Australian society in general if we were to provide government support for the establishment of an ethanol industry for motor fuel. I remind the Government that the support that is being asked for does not necessarily mean cash grants, subsidies or infrastructure development. All it means is enlightened, progressive purchasing policies, especially in fuels; leadership, especially in the Government's use of energy; and leadership in the Government's conservation of energy. With regard to this, I think it was ironic-of course it greatly amused the journalists-that it took an invasion of bogong moths to encourage the administration of this building to switch off unnecessary lighting. The saving of energy was seen as incidental.

I will not speak for too long, but it bears repeating that there are well established methods by which the Government can not only reduce energy consumption throughout the entire nation but also encourage investigation into alternative energy and renewable energy sources. These methods have been mentioned many times over the decades but they bear repeating briefly. The basic suggestion of a taxation reduction being available for the purposes of home insulation is one method which has been adopted previously and I cannot see any justification for denying it in the future. There needs to be Government research and then consumer guidance in all manner of ways so that consumers can be encouraged to reduce their consumption of energy. I might say, in passing, that Tasmania's Hydro Electric Commission has finally realised the wisdom of offering tariff rates which favour householders who wish to harness the energy of the sun to heat their water. For years, the accountants of that organisation pursued a policy which positively discouraged people from installing solar water heaters. The ridiculousness of that was finally realised and the new enlightened policy is an example which could and should be followed throughout Australia.

This Commonwealth Government could assume a leading role in committing funds for research. As Senator Newman quite rightly suggested, funds could be committed, not as a matter of fashion but as a matter of a long term commitment, which I am sure would pay a dividend. The dividend to be derived from this is not necessarily one which is to do with cash savings; it is a dividend which is to do with the infrastructure which the whole country can benefit from. The dividend in this instance is simply a matter of pride. It is with quite sincere pride that Senator Coulter is able to congratulate the designers of these particular solar cells. While we readily invest money, time and effort in seeking national pride from other endeavours, whether they be cultural, sporting or otherwise, the sorts of national efforts which bring pride in other areas could also be directed towards our research into renewable energy. It is with great pride that I endorse Senator Coulter's press release which says, `Well done Australia'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the time pressures on us tonight I will be as brief as I can in responding to the Financial Corporations (Prudential Standards) Amendment Bill 1990 that has been introduced by the Australian Democrats. The purpose of this Bill, as outlined by Senator Spindler when introducing it, is to establish a proper national framework for the regulation of the non-bank financial system in Australia. In essence, what the Bill does is bring into law part IV of the Financial Corporations Act 1974 which was one of the Acts of the Whitlam Government. Part IV of the Act has never been proclaimed.

SPEECH.PARA: I make it clear at the start of my remarks that the coalition, like the Democrats, believes that something must be done to improve the supervision of non-bank financial institutions (NBFI) in Australia. Regrettably, the Government seems to be all over the place on this matter at the moment. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said that it is unnecessary to have a more national or integrated approach to prudential supervision. In his view, apparently the present system of prudential supervision is adequate. On the other hand, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said-and he said it in July in response to remarks made by the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, to whom I will turn in a moment-that in fact an integrated national system of prudential supervision of non-bank financial institutions was necessary and desirable. I hope that the Government will get its act together on this before too long because it is a matter of considerable importance.

I also point out to the Senate that it is a matter on which the coalition has set the agenda. The Leader of the Opposition has made repeated statements in recent months calling for action. I am pleased to see that as a result of the pressure that has been brought to bear on it the Government has now put this issue on its agenda as well through the Special Premiers Conference which was held last month. In July Dr Hewson said that, in his view, there was a need for a more uniform integrated national approach to prudential supervision. At that time he said:

The Prime Minister should instruct the Treasurer to establish a committee of inquiry into a national system of prudential supervision. The committee of inquiry should consist of representatives of the Reserve Bank, the States and relevant industry experts.
He went on to say:
It-
that is the inquiry-

must be asked to report as quickly as possible on the adequacy of existing prudential standards and quality of supervision as well as on measures which may be necessary to improve the degree of protection afforded to depositors in financial institutions in Australia including the adequacy of existing information available to depositors.

There is no doubt at all about the coalition's attitude to this matter. We believe that it is necessary to have a much better approach to prudential supervision of non-bank financial institutions than exists at the moment. We believe that there is a need for a more uniform integrated national approach to the matter.

Having said that, there are of course various ways in which that can be achieved. We believe that the degree of inadequacy of the prudential supervision can be tackled in various ways and I will return to that matter in a moment. However, the coalition will not be supporting the Bill introduced by Senator Spindler. There are several reasons for this, some of which are of a technical nature. We believe there are some technical faults and difficulties with the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It can be amended.

—We would be happy, if in due course those changes were made, to look at that to see whether it is possible to do that without undermining the thrust of the Bill. There are other reasons as well why we will not support the Bill at this time. The primary reason is that the whole issue is currently under review following the Special Premiers Conference held earlier this month. The nature of that review follows very closely the type of inquiry called for several months ago by the Opposition, through Dr Hewson. The communique released from the Premiers Conference said in relation to the question of the regulation of non-bank financial institutions:

SPEECH.PARA: Leaders and representatives agreed upon the need for reform of current State legislation and administration of non-bank financial institutions (NBFIs) in the context of the stability of the financial system as a whole.
That is a very important statement. The communique went on to say:

The Governments of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories have instructed a working group of Officers of all Governments to prepare a report by 31 March 1991 on specific proposals for a system of State-based prudential supervision with national co-ordination of high uniform standards and practices and suitable industry-funded liquidity support mechanisms.
As part of this process, the working group should consult widely with the Reserve Bank, industry organisations and other interested parties.

Given that, and given the reporting date for that high level working party-namely, 31 March 1991-the coalition believes that it would not be prudent to pre-empt the outcome of that review, which will involve a much closer and more thoroughgoing examination of all the issues that I am sure even the Democrats would agree is available to them or indeed to the coalition.

We believe that the approach adopted at the Special Premiers Conference is a sensible way to begin tackling what is a complex and very difficult issue. In light of the all-government agreement to consider the matter, the timing of this Democrat Bill, I must say, is unusual, and I will be interested to hear Senator Powell's comments following my speech as to why the Bill is being introduced at this time. I would have thought it would have been much more practical in a timing sense to have deferred consideration of this Bill until such time as we see what the experts produce in the work they will be doing between now and 31 March next year, and possibly going beyond that.

The coalition does not have a closed mind about either the degree or the best way to achieve a more uniform integrated national approach to prudential supervision. The coalition has made various statements on that matter. In an interview on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio as far back as 20 July in relation to his call for a more integrated uniform national system, Dr Hewson said:

I'd also make clear that I'm not advocating increased control. Supervision doesn't necessarily mean control. It means a standardisation of supervisory practices, selecting data, and of course, importantly, understanding who's got the responsibility.
He went on to agree with the interviewer, John Shovelan:
. . . that there needs to be a common system between the States, not necessarily administered by the Federal Government-

nor, necessarily, he went on to agree with the interviewer, with responsibility vested with the Reserve Bank. As I understand it, that seems to be a view broadly shared at this stage by the Government and certainly by the Prime Minister who has said similar things to that. We need serious and considered views from all interested parties on the array of topics involved.

The coalition, as I have intimated, does not want to put its views finally on the table until all the facts and analyses are available. This was a prime reason for the coalition's earlier call for an inquiry. What we need are the facts. In connection with that, it is also important to look in the course of this inquiry-and I presume the expert working party will do this-at the actual degree of supervision that may be desirable.

My attention has been drawn to a speech given in Melbourne today by Mr Des Moore from the Institute of Public Affairs (IPA), in which he pointed out what I think are some very pertinent matters in relation to the degree of increase in prudential regulation and supervision that is desirable. The IPA's view, just to quote from Mr Moore's press release, is that:

The enormous increase in `prudential' regulation and supervision of financial markets that is now occurring is largely based on false premises and the rush to reregulate is being focussed in each individual area without any overall assessment of the costs and benefits.
He went on to say in that speech that:

. . . the main cause of the over-lending and over borrowing that occurred during the 1990s was not a lack of prudential regulation but the Government's policy of accommodating inflation through monetary policy and the Accord. This had encouraged over-borrowing to purchase assets whose prices had seemingly been `guaranteed' to rise.
Mr Moore went on to say that:

. . . the moves to increase prudential supervision and regulation were in serious danger not only of failing to recognise the real limits to these processes, but also of providing de facto guarantees to depositors, thereby creating moral hazard and contravening a vital principle of efficient regulation. ``Primary responsibility for the safety of depositors must be, and be seen to be, with the financial institutions themselves, not with governments or their Central Banks''.

Those are very important comments. Without necessarily agreeing or disagreeing with them, they highlight the sort of considerations that need to be brought into account and considered in any full analysis of this matter. With the Democrats' Bill to date, that degree of analysis and examination is just not possible. The timing of this Bill may therefore have more to do with, as I understand it, the Democrats' opposition to deregulation of the financial sector than to anything else.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has something to do with the timing of this Bill.

—Right. The coalition, on the other hand, is, and remains, committed to deregulation supported by an effective supervisory framework. It is essential to realise that a properly deregulated financial market will always require supervision. It is incumbent on the Government to ensure that the proper supervisory framework is put in place. That is why the coalition has been so keen to set the agenda on this issue. The coalition has also taken careful note of the statement made by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Bernie Fraser, in May when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: While we believe that financial deregulation, on balance, has been good for the economy, there is no doubt that prudential supervision will have to be developed further. The rules will have to be adjusted as we learn more about the game.

That is precisely the view of the coalition. The rules do need to be changed in a way which gives due consideration to the links between the supervisory mechanisms that may ultimately be adopted and the overall question of deregulation of the financial sector. It is important not to lose sight of the reason for prudential controls within the deregulated system. To quote Mr Fraser again:

We do not even now have a fully deregulated system and we never will-the public will rightly expect governments to impose some restraints to ensure that the basic rules of the game are adhered to and that individual freedoms do not lead to undesirable social consequences . . . [that] is the basic rationale for prudential supervision of the banking system.

It is also important to remember that responsibilities relate both to those who manage and to those who supervise financial institutions. The fact remains, however, that ultimately individual institutions must take responsibility for their own integrity. That is the point Mr Moore made in his speech to the IPA today.

In looking at effective supervision, many of the issues which will need to be addressed were outlined in a paper prepared for the Special Premiers Conference by the Queensland Government, entitled Committee of Inquiry into Non-Bank Financial Institutions and Related Financial Processes in the State of Queensland. I understand that that paper was very influential in the heads of government reaching the agreed position that they did at the Conference. That paper includes a number of interesting recommendations. While it is too early for the coalition to decide on its position on those recommendations, it does suggest, I think, that the Democrats may not have looked fully at all the issues before coming to their conclusions; and I commend to the Democrats, in their further consideration of this matter, the Queensland paper.

The Democrats do not appear to have considered the possibility of maintaining a State based system. While there are advantages to national consistency, this can be achieved through mechanisms which would allow a continued State based system. A national approach would provide automatic uniformity between the States, economies of scale in supervision, and acknowledgment of the similarities of many NBFIs. However, the history and unique nature of some regional institutions must also be recognised. That may best be achieved under a State based system, with some form of national coordination.

A State based system would also appear to be preferable from the standpoint that non-bank financial institutions are established and administered under State legislation, so a Commonwealth supervisory role could be somewhat contradictory. Consistent with the intent of this Bill, however, a State based system could involve the adoption of a Reserve Bank style of prudential supervision without the Commonwealth being responsible for the entire supervisory role. In that respect I note that Dr Hewson has also said that it need not be the Reserve Bank which plays the oversighting supervising role, as I pointed out earlier.

I am not, on behalf of the coalition, necessarily advocating continuation of a State based system, but I do think that the relative merits of such a system deserve a closer and more detailed examination than the hurried presentation of this Bill has allowed. There may be particular reasons for it, but this Bill was introduced into this Parliament only 11 hours or less ago. Obviously it has not had the opportunity to be as carefully examined as we would like.

I wonder, too, whether the Democrats have fully thought out the implications of increasing the Reserve Bank's role to the extent that this Bill suggests. In May of this year the Governor himself said:

There is always a risk in adopting a higher profile in even general ``surveillance'' of building societies that we may raise false expectations about what we are prepared to do to support an intermediary in difficulties.

It is the spin-off effects of any action in this area which also bear careful consideration. The fabric of our financial system is based primarily around confidence and possible contagion effects. It is these psychological factors which make reactions to changes in the financial sector especially difficult to predict, and make caution and well-considered conclusions essential. The Opposition recognised as much when the Financial Corporations Act, on part IV of which this Bill is heavily based, was first introduced in 1974. At that time the late Hon. Phillip Lynch said:

The views of both a former Governor of the Australian Reserve Bank and the present Governor clearly support the Opposition's position that the powers contained in the Bill before the House have the capacity to be counterproductive if used without regard for their economic consequences.

The other major issue which must be carefully considered involves just how the supervision of institutions can, and should, contribute to solving problems which have led to the concern evident in this action by the Democrats and our call for an inquiry, namely, closures and collapses of financial institutions, particularly in Victoria. It is clear from the Reserve Bank bulletin of 1987-July 1987, I think-that regulation in areas covered by part IV of the Financial Corporations Act do already apply, albeit to varying degrees within the States and the Territories. It is, therefore, the precise nature and extent of the regulation enumerated in part IV, rather than the subject areas themselves, which is the critical element.

In this respect it would be helpful for the Opposition to be fully briefed on exactly what information the Commonwealth Government already receives about the financial system, exactly who receives it and when. The recent collapse of, particularly, the Pyramid Building Society is a case in point. Despite repeated attempts to ascertain exactly what happened, who knew what and how much should have been known, given the current supervisory arrangements, we still have no answers of substance. It is difficult to correct a problem when one cannot even be sure of the situation which applied when it happened.

The question of how best to address the supervisory improvements, which, I think we would all agree, must be considered, is a very difficult one. While the Democrats have rightly recognised that a problem exists-and we agree totally with them on that-we will wait for the outcome of the current review of the matter before deciding on the best action to take. De- regulation has put all of the authorities involved with the financial sector on a very steep learning curve. It is now imperative that we do not jump too soon to conclusions which may not best meet the diverse objectives which must be met in this new environment.

I am not sure what is going to happen to this Bill, but I hope that the Democrats might consider deferring it until such time as the work that is going on and that has now been set in train by the Special Premiers Conference has come to fruition and we have had a proper analysis of all the issues and considerations involved. Only in that way will we then be able to be confident that we are taking the best solutions to meet those problems which we commonly agree exist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Short for his contribution to the debate on the Financial Corporations (Prudential Standards) Amendment Bill 1990, and for his constructive approach and his request that time be given for consideration. Indeed, it is the intention of the Australian Democrats that this debate tonight should not close consideration of this Bill which, as Senator Short has said, was introduced earlier today by my colleague Senator Spindler, the treasury and finance spokesperson for the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short questioned the timing of this Bill and has also made a claim on behalf of the Opposition that the Opposition has led the way on the whole question of the oversight of financial institutions and, in terms of this legislation, non-bank financial institutions. I challenge that claim and do so in the context of answering his query about the timing of this legislation. For many years the Democrats have been the only political party in this country opposing the rampant deregulation in the financial system and in other areas. It ought not to be a surprise to Senator Short or anyone else that, within the first six weeks of the sitting of this Parliament, the Australian Democrats are bringing in an initial piece of reregulating legislation.

In fact, within days of the collapse of the Pyramid Building Society in Victoria we called for the proclamation of part IV of the Financial Corporations Act, which, as Senator Short has said, is largely the basis for Senator Spindler's Bill. In that respect, as well, we have led the way. As I said, this Senate has not been sitting for six weeks yet, and during that time energy and effort have gone into the drafting of this piece of legislation, and the timing is determined by the fact that this legislation has now been made ready for introduction into this place. That is the reason for the timing. It is rather interesting that earlier today, when this chamber received a report to the Senate of a list of unproclaimed legislation, in that report was the note of the lack of proclamation of part IV of the Financial Corporations Act. So the timing is, I would suggest, quite fortuitous.

The Bill proposes to establish a national prudential supervision system for deposit-taking non-bank financial institutions-that is, building societies and credit unions. Senator Short quoted his parliamentary leader, Dr Hewson, in challenging the right of the Reserve Bank to be responsible in this area. It is within the charter of the Reserve Bank of Australia to be responsible for the Australian financial system. The non-bank financial institutions are part of that system, and the fact that under Treasurer Keating the Reserve Bank has confined itself to banking institutions does not make either Senator Short or Dr Hewson right when they say that the Reserve Bank has no capacity to act in this area.

Before considering the Bill in detail, I would like first to consider the main attributes of non-bank financial institutions. Many people may think, `Why not just join a bank? Why join a building society or credit union?'. The reason is that the non-bank financial institutions sector offers a vast array of choice, and innovation is often linked to a particular region. One example of this innovation is the proposal that is currently before the Victorian Government concerning the recent purchase of the former First Mortgage Permanent Building Society. A Perth based women's organisation has purchased that society and is applying to establish Australia's first specialist women's building society. Parking places for prams and creches will be provided and there may be special provisions applying to loan repayments during pregnancy and maternity leave. Can honourable senators imagine any of our banks providing such services? The Australian Democrats totally support such community-minded initiatives, particularly those which take account of the special needs of women in our community.

The Bill proposes to activate the dormant provisions of part IV of the Financial Corporations Act 1974. These provisions provide the mechanism for the national regulation of the non-bank financial institutions. Currently there is a variety of State based regulatory systems, to which I shall come later in the speech. In doing so I will respond to some of Senator Short's other comments. The Federal Government, the Democrats believe, should accept its responsibilities, and the Reserve Bank is the appropriate mechanism by which that should happen. It has the statutory duty to maintain the health of the Australian financial system, as I have said. It cannot do this without being involved in direct prudential supervision. We have seen that, and many Australian investors are suffering from the fact that at the moment that is not happening.

Under the current system the Reserve Bank operates through the banks when it provides liquidity support. Such a system is clearly unacceptable. Since the banks are in competition with the deposit-taking non-bank financial institutions, there is obviously a potential conflict of interest in these types of arrangements. It is a classic example of putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank. Why will the Government not show some leadership in this area? Surely people's savings are more important than political considerations. The ideological deregulationist position taken by the Government is supported by the Opposition. Treasurer Keating, by rejecting this kind of approach is clearly trying to distance himself from any sense of responsibility which he should be accepting for the disaster of the Pyramid Building Society.

The paper to which Senator Short referred prepared by the Queensland Treasury for the recent Special Premiers Conference has suggested what we consider to be an unwieldy State-based structure, which is quite ridiculous in terms of a conference which was supposed to address problems of duplication. But when one looks at the paper it is clear that this is recognised as a second best option. Paragraph 3 of the paper states:

While the Reserve Bank has some responsibility under its charter for the whole financial system, the Federal Government has indicated clearly that it is not prepared to legislate in this area, provide any liquidity support or assume responsibility for the various non-bank financial institutions.

We consider that a disgraceful situation. This is why this Senate, which represents the States, should send a message to the Government that the Pontius Pilate attitude is both inefficient and unacceptable. I urge honourable senators to contact their respective State governments to seek their views.
Furthermore, the New South Wales Deputy Registrar, Mr Uri Windt, recently spoke at the seminar on managing non-bank financial institutions in crisis. In that speech he stated:

The first and most fundamental fact to be established is whether the regulation of non-bank financial institutions is to remain a State Government responsibility or come under Federal jurisdiction. If the Federal Government was to assume this responsibility the outcome is probably straightforward in the sense that there exists machinery for corporate and prudential supervision which could be adjusted to take on this role.

Moreover, I believe that a number of States would desire such an outcome. So you can expect none of the drama that accompanied the introduction of the Corporations Act. The fact is that the Federal Government has resisted the temptation of assuming this responsibility. All the informal and semi-formal feedback has indicated a distinct lack of interest in enacting legislation or any similar step that would presume Federal responsibility (or liability) in the area. At best, it is my impression that the Federal Government's interest is in ensuring that a State-owned system is in place, capable of meeting the regulatory challenge of non-bank financial institutions. So let us assume that the outcome will indeed be a State-based system.

What a way to design a financial system! That is comment on Senator Short's remarks as to why we do not sit around and do nothing while this whole system is investigated, looked at and turned over for many more months while many more people remain in financial danger, as the Government washes its hands of its responsibilities.

This Bill seeks to commence the process of the full national regulation of non-bank financial institutions. It proposes to update all financial penalties for offences under the Financial Corporations Act by 500 per cent to bring their real value up to the level of 1974-the point at which the relevant part of the Act was not, I remind the Senate, proclaimed. Monetary penalties must be kept at an adequate level to act as an effective deterrent.

The Bill also proposes to extend the scope of the Financial Corporations Act to friendly societies for the first time. It is only proposed to bring these societies under the registration and statistical provisions at this stage. Indeed, the Government is understood to be examining the possibility of bringing friendly societies under the supervision of the office of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC). As such it is recognised that the ISC may well be the appropriate supervisory body and no action is taken in this Bill, except as I have just mentioned.

A new part IV(A) is introduced into the principal Act by this Bill. Bank style prudential standards are contained within this new part. It will apply initially to building societies and credit unions. A prime assets ratio is introduced for these institutions. There is power to set various levels for differing categories of distributions. However, the same rules must apply to each member of a category. Where the institution does not satisfy the prime assets ratio it is generally not allowed to grant any loans.

A further prudential control is the setting of minimum capital adequacy standards. This will ensure that the particular institutions maintain secure structures with adequate capital bases. There are also provisions concerning large exposures. These must be notified to the Reserve Bank and the bank may intervene to protect the interests of the deposit holders. The measures are designed to ensure that institutions do not put too many eggs in one basket.

The Bill also proposes that the supervisory functions of the Reserve Bank will be paid for by an administrative levy on all non-bank financial institutions. This will be paid into a special fund and can be used only for this specific purpose.

In addition, industry specific liquidity support funds are to be created for both credit unions and building societies. All institutions will have to make deposits into these funds. Interest will be payable at a rate below the market rate-rather like the non-callable deposits which banks are obliged to make with the Reserve Bank. These moneys are then available to provide liquidity support where necessary. Deposits are repayable on exiting the relevant industry.

To create a more secure regime for depositors, a separate reserve fund will be established for both credit unions and building societies. Basically the fund is to secure deposits in these institutions. A levy may be imposed on building societies or credit unions which will be paid into the fund. The reserve funds will invest the moneys deposited and the total assets of the reserve funds will be available to provide assistance to depositors where an institution has to be liquidated-and there are many Victorians who wish that these sorts of provisions had already been in place.

It will not be compulsory to contribute to the reserve fund. Since the reserve fund arrangement is basically an insurance arrangement for deposits, there will be no levy available where an appropriate deposit insurance has been obtained by the institution. These measures will not commence until six months after the royal assent of this Bill to enable the appropriate consultation with the States concerning existing liquidity fund arrangements.

Views within the industry, as one would expect, vary. However, the general trend is towards support of national regulation. For example, the General Manager of the Australian Federation of Credit Unions, Mr Graham Loughlin, is reported in the Australian Financial Review of 1 November 1990 of welcoming the opportunity:
to achieve high uniform standards, practices and prudential supervision Australia-wide.

Indeed, senior business representatives have privately supported this approach. Our approach in this Bill-in contrast to the State-based mishmash which we were asked to consider seriously and which we believe is inappropriate-is preferred, we believe, by building societies, and senior business representatives have also privately supported the approach.

This Bill does not seek to create a complete national regulatory structure. We think that such a massive job should be achieved gradually. The most important move at this stage is to a national prudential supervisory system with a full national regulatory system, the natural further step not too far into the future. The non-bank financial industry provides a perfect microcosm of the absurd structure which pervades so much of Australian life. Senator Short laid emphasis on the State-based approach that has been put forward by the Queensland submission to the Premiers Conference.
I referred earlier to some statements by Mr Windt on that matter and I commend further comments from him to Senator Short and to others. He says:

In some States the regulator is a Registrar administering a piece of legislation for each of the various types of entity. In others there is an Omnibus Act covering every form of incorporation. In other States the role of the Registrar has been subsumed in the functions of Corporate Affairs Commissions and there is no longer a distinct role of a Registrar.
Nor is there consistency in the set of entities regulated by Registrars . . .
To add to the confusion, the process of Ministerial responsibility is not homogeneous either . . .
To complete the picture it should be said that the relevant Ministers responsible for cooperative type organisations had never met to consider the matters of common concern until October 1990.
A final quote:
Nevertheless, the point remains, if you were to set out and design a regulatory framework this would not be considered the most perfect system.

My own State of Victoria, as I have already mentioned, has had some enormous problems in recent times in the area of non-bank financial institutions. The tragic collapse of the Pyramid Building Society following the stupendous problems with the merchant bank Tricontinental Ltd show clearly that effective prudential supervision is essential to safeguard depositors.

Financial deregulation has been a disaster. Slowly more and more people are coming to realise this. How can we hope to increase savings which will reduce the current account problems facing Australia under the present climate? People need proper incentives to save. Firstly, they must have security. This Bill addresses the problem of depositor security by enacting proper prudential controls similar to those applying to banks to help restore the confidence that has taken such a battering recently.

The second incentive that people need to encourage them to save is that they must get a reasonable return because all of us want a reasonable return on our savings. Inflation and taxation together work to eliminate much of the interest earned in financial institutions. Just as people need a reasonable wage to work hard, investors need a reasonable return on investment to save hard.

In our alternative Budget put down in August before the Treasurer's Budget, we proposed a tax rebate on the first $1,000 of interest earned. This rebate is set at the marginal tax rate which applies to a person on average weekly earnings. Thus to low and middle income earners up to $1,000 interest will be tax free under Australian proposals. However, those on higher incomes will have to pay a small amount of tax on their interest.

People have seen an extraordinary binge since the 1980s. A small element of our society went on a huge spending spree and they have left the bill to the rest of the community. We now have a stupendous foreign debt which is still growing inexorably. Even though we have the terrible evidence from our own performance in the United States, Britain and the Nordic countries that financial deregulation smashes the savings ratio, the deregulation fervour that grips the old political parties here in this place has not died but appears to be actually increasing.

This is despite the fact that the Government has had to engineer a recession to attempt to contain the current account monster it has created. As usual, those on the bottom of the social ladder will bear the cost by being thrown out of work. To add insult to injury, Opposition members say that if they were in government they would cut off unemployment benefits after nine months. So much for their commitment to society. We have to realise that policies like that will cause poverty, crime and violence in our society.

Some people say, `Well, so, if the Skases and the Bonds lose all their money or the banks' money, I have not lost anything'. If only that were true! The banks have a huge portfolio of so-called non-performing loans. Estimates vary, but the accepted estimate is about $10 billion. The banks always complain about supposed government inefficiency. Yet in response to this $10 billion of non-performing loans disaster they say, `We have been on a learning curve'. I think that I heard Senator Short refer to the learning curve. When will they learn that financial deregulation is in nobody's interests. Since the banks are earning no interest on these non-performing loans, the amount charged to all their other customers is increased. That is in the general level of interest rate increases, or the interest rates do not decrease at the rate that they otherwise would.

The banks increase their margin on loans to customers who pay for the often reckless lending which the banks themselves undertook. So, as usual, in the end it is the ordinary person who picks up the tab. Indeed, some ominous signs of the second wave of crashes are already coming through. As unemployment rises, which is occurring quite dramatically at the moment, we will see an increasing number of private bankruptcies. As people lose their incomes they will become un- able to pay their mortgages and their credit card debts. This will place further strain on families and increase poverty. Yet the Government and the Opposition want to accelerate this process.

The Government has before this Parliament a Bill to commence the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. Even Sir Robert Menzies and Malcolm Fraser would not have countenanced such legislation. The crash of Tricontinental was a direct result of deregulation. This has cost the people of Victoria their State Bank, an unprecedented result except for the New South Wales State Saving Bank disaster during the Depression.

The Government also wants to deregulate the domestic and international telecommunications market. Why? It is so that it can give to the private sector the fastest growing industry in the world. This Bill is proposing an historic national solution to a national problem. I urge all honourable senators to think of their constituents' interests, of the depositors, when they decide which way they will vote on this legislation. We need something positive to be done. Of course, the majority of building societies operating are in a sound, stable position, supplying good services. But those depositors who are unfortunate enough to be involved with an institution where that is not happening do need the right and proper protection which it is the responsibility of the Federal Government, through the Reserve Bank of Australia, to supply. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Foreman) adjourned.
