SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Further Amendment Bills 1990 and the Wool Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, in the same way as did Senator John Panizza, I must declare an interest in the debate because I am a woolgrower and I also had a previous interest in the industry in that I was a shearer for 17-odd years. I understand both sides of the equation. It is very important that we remember in terms of the wool industry that many people in the community who do not involve themselves in growing wool rely on the industry. That is something that must not be lost on us in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been emphasised by many speakers here tonight, the wool industry is in a serious situation. Many would believe that the industry is facing its darkest hour. I want to make it quite clear that, unless the industry acts decisively and quickly, there is worse to come. History shows that the wool industry is the most important industry in the history of this country. It is our greatest export earner and one of our greatest employers of people. It is worth noting that between 1979-80 and 1988-89-I will not quote all the figures-wool produced from $1.2 billion to $4.6 billion in export income earnings each year.

I wish to put on record the current situation of the wool industry. At this very moment we have 4.251 million bales in the stockpile. The total cost of that stockpile is $3.7 billion. The debt of the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) in terms of that is slightly more than $2 billion, the rest being grower equity in the fund from levies.

Let us see what has happened in the industry. In June 1989 we had 200,000 bales in the stockpile. In June 1990 we had 3.1 million bales in the stockpile. There have been many signals to the industry and the Government in terms of what was happening. If I have a criticism-and I believe it is a valid one-of the wool industry, the Wool Council of Australia, the Wool Corporation and the Government, it is that they have been tardy and slow in reacting to the situation. If we look a little further down the track, and I think it is important that we do, we find that it is estimated that by June 1991 there will be between 5.3 million and 5.7 million bales in the stockpile. By this time next year, if nothing is done-and by that I mean selling or slaughter-to reduce supply to put it in line with demand, that stockpile will be between six million and 6.5 million bales.

The position is totally unsustainable and it cannot go on. The stockpile has become an albatross which unless brought under control will destroy the industry in two ways: firstly, by distortion of market prices into the future and, secondly, in that the tax required to maintain it will send producers broke. We are currently producing close to six million bales per annum. Our average sales over the past 10 years are slightly more than 4m bales. In other words, we are producing two million bales per annum more than we have been able to sell traditionally. I emphasise the point that production must equate with demand.

In looking at the solutions and the magnitude of the stockpile, one must be cognisant of stockpiles since 1970. In 1974-75 we had an upper level of 1.6 million bales in the stockpile. In 1983-84 we had 1.2 million bales in the stockpile. The situation the industry faces today is much more serious in terms of the effect of the stockpile and the cost of it than it ever was then. In fact, it is minute when we compare the figures. The current situation cannot go on. It will destroy the Corporation; it will destroy the industry; but, most importantly, it will destroy producers and the associated jobs that are part of the wool industry.

The Bills before us provide for an increase in the wool tax to a maximum of 30 per cent and surcharge provisions to a maximum of 20 per cent, giving the AWC power to tax to 50 per cent. In addition, the AWC will have the power to implement a disposal scheme with a target of 20 million sheep to be disposed of in a humane way.

There are two other matters, one which deals with the flood victims and the other with carpet wools. The coalition supports each of these two provisions. As I understand it, the provisions for quotas and the Corporation's management plan will start in July 1991.

I will deal with each of these provisions one at a time. First, the 30 per cent tax. We support that provision but I make the point that if, prior to 1 July last year, the 25 per cent wool tax, which was the industry's choice at the time, had been put in place, we would not be debating this Bill tonight. The other important aspect is that, had it been done then, growers would have been treated equitably instead of some paying 18 per cent for part of the season and others paying 25 per cent.

I now deal with the surcharge. The coalition does not support this. I feel very strongly about it. It is very irresponsible of the Government and the Australian Democrats to agree with the Wool Corporation about that level. No institutional bureaucracy should ever be given the power to tax to 50 per cent of gross income. If this were applied to any other sector in the economy the Government would have strikes everywhere on its hands. It is akin to giving a kid a bucket of ice cream and telling that child to eat only half of it. It is as simple as that. If the Wool Corporation gets its act into gear, 30 per cent will do the job. If it does not, the reserve price will collapse.

The disposal scheme is totally inadequate. It will do little to overcome the supply demand. I do not know why people want to mince words when talking about the disposal scheme or the slaughter scheme because they are one and the same thing. The first option is for the industry to sell more wool. I will deal with that later. The second best option is a commercial slaughter scheme. In looking at that, the purchase of two million bales by November next year would cost $2 billion, that is, $1.65 billion for the purchase of the wool and just over $300m for storage, handling and other costs. To effectively address our oversupply, a commercial slaughter scheme would cost between $400m and $500m. As unpalatable, abhorrent and undesirable as it is, the economics are clear. The other point about this is the impact of overstocking. One way or another over time those sheep will go. It will either be through a controlled, effective, humane process, through environmental pressures or through drought. History has proven that many times.

My next point is quotas. Quotas will fail. They have never succeeded in any industry that I am aware of. They certainly did not succeed in the wheat industry. It is impossible to provide equity. It is unfair to producers who have not increased production. At a meeting I was at the other day a lady clearly stated her position when she said, `We have not altered our wool production for 20 years. Why should we be penalised?'.

Senator Panizza talked about the States and production. It is impossible to ensure equity between States. There are so many variables which exist from year to year and from season to season within the States. Why should a producer whose wool that is selling be put on a quota? It is the most illogical suggestion I have heard in a long time. As I said before, quotas will fail. The other problem with quotas-that seems to be missing in this debate-is that they will provide a private stockpile. This country will have two stockpiles-one with the Corporation and another in the sheds of farmers. One must recognise the fact that we cannot stop a sheep growing wool. We can stop putting a paddock into crop or doing some other things. We can chop a tree down. But we cannot stop living sheep walking around the paddocks, fields or wherever it might be, from growing wool.

From day one of these proposals-I refer to the 50 per cent tax and related suggestions-we, on this side of the chamber, said that we had to be satisfied with the business plan; that we did not believe that quotas would work; that we had to sell more wool; that we had to reduce sheep numbers; and that we had to have a commercial disposal scheme. Once again I will say that quotas will not work. We can support only 30 per cent. This is the Wool Corporation's last chance to get it right.

The other point is what I term `ignorance in the bush'. I do not blame the farmers who live out there; I blame the Corporation, the Wool Council in particular and, to a lesser extent, the Government. If it was fitting for Mr Kerin to write to all growers last May, it was fitting for him to carry out the same exercise last month about the state of the industry. I emphasise that the real responsibility for this lies with the Wool Council. I will say a little bit more about that in a moment.

The next point is selling. We need a little bit of lateral thinking and imagination. We need some initiatives in credit sales; export insurance and what can be done in that area; barter trade; and what the industry itself can do in industry investment. I point out to the Senate that for every two years that a bale of wool sits in a stockpile it costs $300 in interest rates, storage, handling and all other costs. The industry has lost that money forever. The banks get it, the warehouses get it or somebody else gets it.

It seems logical to me-I put this to the representatives from the Wool Council and the Wool Corporation-that the industry should be investing that $300 in the pipeline and coming to some arrangement with the trade to get that money working. I put a lot of emphasis on that. The Corporation has been very backward with initiative and lateral thinking when addressing an issue that has been around for some time.

I also mention diversified or new uses for wool. I make reference to the speech made in the other place by Graeme Campbell, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. I take this opportunity to congratulate him, first, for recognising what Dr Hewson said at the conference held in Tasmania the other day and, secondly, for pointing out that when he was in France just a year or two ago the wallpaper was made of wool. I am not sure whether it is called `wall wool' or `wool wall' or what. It is interesting to note that that was an initiative and something that should be pursued.

Another point I make is something that was pointed out to me at a grower meeting I was at last week. I guess everybody has heard of pink batts or ceiling insulation. What are called `wool batts' are now being sold in Perth. I had never heard of them until the other day. I have never seen them advertised but they are commercially priced to compete with the pink batts advertised on television or in newspapers. It is time that some initiative was taken in what can be done with wool. It would be good if wool products could compete with other products. Also, these wool batts are a much better product. They are fire proof, they keep a place cooler and they save energy.

My next point on initiative-and this is where I will be somewhat critical of the Government because I gave it an opportunity-is that on 24 August 1990, just after the problem in Iraq started, I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I suggested to him that we set up a business task force separate from our corporations and what have you of businessmen, get around the world and find out what niche markets and opportunities were available to us. In that letter I referred, if I remember correctly, particularly to wheat, wool, sheep meats, et cetera.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could do it for anything.

—Yes, for anything. I wrote to the Prime Minister on that matter. I also sent copies of that letter to Minister Kerin, Minister Blewett and Minister Evans. It gives me much sadness to point out to the Government senators who are sitting here that not one has bothered even to reply to or acknowledge that particular letter. I find it very disappointing that, when one tries to put forward a constructive suggestion at a time when there is much difficulty in rural Australia, the Ministers cannot even bother to acknowledge it.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to refer to some other points concerning processing and the development of industry locally. Once upon a time we did have some processing capacity in this country, but unfortunately our taxation policy and our industrial policy do not provide an incentive for these things. These are the areas we have to look at. We have to look at the introduction of proper enterprise agreements where there is reward for effort. We have to look at the impact that things such as the capital gains tax have on investment in these types of industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with you, but I am saying that the Wool Corporation was opposed to that for a very long time.

—We will not have a debate on the Wool Corporation tonight. I have said enough about it; I am now concentrating on what the Government can do. I have sought permission from Senator Button to incorporate this document in Hansard. It refers to AWC purchases and the exchange rate. Monetary policy, high interest rates and the high dollar have hurt this industry very badly, as they have others. This chart demonstrates quite clearly how the purchases of the AWC have ebbed and flowed as our exchange rate has gone up and down. When one looks at the graph-which will be there for all to see-it is quite remarkable to see what an impact the value of the dollar has had on the industry. I seek leave to incorporate this chart in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The chart read as follows-
[THE CHART IS NOT INCLUDED IN THE DATABASE; SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 4356]

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The other point I wish to make about interest rates concerns the impact that they have had on the Corporation and its holding of stocks. That has been very significant.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the Wool Council. I think it is time for us to say quite clearly to the Wool Council: `It is time to lift the game. It is time to inform growers what is going on'. I will give honourable senators an example of what I mean. I attended a meeting at Calingiri last week. A grower at that meeting, quite legitimately, asked what levels of taxes would be required during this coming year for different corporate purchases-how much would it cost to purchase one million bales, two million bales, et cetera? There were three representatives from the Wool Council in attendance and not one of them could answer the question. I think that is an indictment of those people and of the Wool Council.

For the Senate's information, I would like to cite some figures relating to this matter. If the wool trade bought four million bales during the current selling season and the AWC bought two million, the tax required would be about 33 per cent. If the trade were to buy three million bales and the Corporation were to buy three million bales, the tax required would be about 42 per cent. That situation is just not sustainable and that is why we have adopted the position that we have on the matters I have talked about.

The next matter I would like to address in relation to the wool industry concerns the operations of the International Wool Secretariat (IWS). I also seek to have incorporated in Hansard a chart which shows Australia's figures and those of other contributing countries.
Leave granted.
The chart read as follows-
[THE CHART IS NOT INCLUDED IN THE DATABASE; SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 4357]

TALK.START.PARA: —We can see from the chart that Australia's contribution is 72 per cent, and the point I particularly want to make is that the non-exporting countries who grow wool and who benefit from much of the work done by the IWS contribute nothing to the work of the International Wool Secretariat. When I look at the wool production levels of these countries, particularly China, Russia and Europe, which are very large producers of wool, I find it incredible to see that some of them benefit from much of the work that is done by the International Wool Secretariat. It is time that our negotiators-and it might be required at Government level-became really involved in this matter and made sure that the beneficiaries of this organisation, not just the wool exporting countries, make a contribution to it. In fact, those particular countries ride on our back.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now address the situation regarding carpet wools. I would particularly like to mention Senator Bell's comments on this matter. I respectfully inform Senator Bell that our carpet wool producers are piggybacking on the New Zealand reserve price scheme. I think it is absolutely pointless and inaccurate to suggest that, because the reserve price and the levy are not being applied to carpet wools in this country, producers have sustained their position in the market. It is quite clear, in view of our production levels and the situation that exists in New Zealand, that producers are piggybacking there. In fact, it is no different from what all the other wool exporting counties are doing to Australia. Those countries are piggybacking off our reserve price scheme.

In summary, our first priority is to get out there and sell the wool. I believe there has been a lack of initiative at Government and Corporation level when it comes to investigating what can be done-looking at opportunities, looking at niche markets and really getting wool into the pipeline. As I have outlined in my speech, there are many opportunities for us to maximise our performance. The pain must be minimised. It is important that growers be informed clearly of the state of the industry.

In terms of the situation in which we now find ourselves and the challenge that faces us in the form of this legislation, the time has come to put blame behind us and give all of the support we can to getting on with the job. The Wool Corporation needs support; the industry needs support; and those people who can get out there and do something need support. If we do not give that support, we will find that six, seven or eight months down the track we will be back in this chamber debating the wool industry again, but we will not be debating whether the levy will be 30 per cent, 50 per cent or 25 per cent; we will be debating whether we have a corporation, because I do not believe that the situation can be sustained. I appeal to the Government and the Corporation.

I believe it is irresponsible in the absolute extreme to give an open cheque book to an institution, whether it be the Corporation or any other institution, to the extent of 50 per cent of gross income. The Corporation's figures show that in its 1991-92 scenario it is looking at using about 35 per cent of that 50 per cent. I cannot, in all honesty, justify handing that sort of financial power to an institution which is essentially run by bureaucrats.

In closing, I cannot emphasise strongly enough how serious the situation is in the wool industry. I believe it is on the verge of a collapse of a magnitude that we have never seen before. I believe that, unless everybody pushes very hard in the right directions and stirs up those people who have the responsibility of marketing and selling our wool and those people who have the responsibility of putting the slaughter scheme in place, the reserve price scheme will collapse and we will see the industry suffer an enormous amount of pain for many years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly enjoyed Senator Crane's speech. He had a lot of content and obviously he is a man who knows his subject. The Senate tonight is debating the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Further Amendment Bills and the Wool Legislation Amendment Bill which will increase the rate of tax from 25 per cent to 30 per cent, place a surcharge of a maximum of 20 per cent if required, adjust the carpet wool industry, allow payments to be made from the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) fund to fund a scheme for the disposal of sheep and allow payments to woolgrowers who could not get their wool to market because of the extensive floods in Queensland and New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

DEBATE.TITLE: WOOL TAX (Nos 1 to 5) FURTHER AMENDMENT BILLS 1990WOOL LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL l990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The wool industry is in a very serious and difficult situation. That has not been brought about by one factor but by a number of factors which have compounded on each other and accelerated the massive problems of the wool industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry could have copped one or two knocks and ridden through with just a few minor movements, but that did not happen. It has been king hit by a number of things which have happened to it. The Chinese have withdrawn from the wool market because of international problems. They have not been able to sell their wool products on world markets. That has resulted in the loss of 80 million kilograms of wool sales. Russia's move into a free market economy took money from the centrally controlled economy; that decision removed Russia from the market and resulted in the loss of another 90 million kilograms in 1987-88 and a massive 130 million kilograms in 1988-89.

The collapse of the live sheep trade in the Middle East had a large effect on the overall problems. For instance, in 1983 Australia was selling 7 million sheep a year in that market. That is a total of 35 million kilograms of wool coming on the market each year. Given that those sheep had a producing life of a further four years, their sale to the Middle East would have taken 140 million kilograms of wool from the present market and would have caused a reduction in the AWC's stockpile.

We have had excellent seasons since 1984, resulting in the breeding up of our flock by 40 million sheep. Australia's increased production is equivalent to the total in South Africa, New Zealand and South America. As a result of the bountiful seasons, the average kilogram cut from a sheep has added a further 100 million kilograms to production and consequently to the stockpile. These things have resulted in supply overrunning sales with a consequent build-up in stocks of 4 million bales in the AWC's warehouses, rising at the rate of 80,000 bales a week.
We can add to that the wrong decision by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin)-and if he were honest he would say it was the wrong decision--

TALK.START.PARA: —Now you are getting back on track. You were floundering with those figures.

—I am quite on course. In May this year the Minister dropped the floor price for wool from 870c a kilogram to 700c a kilogram. That sent shock waves throughout the industry. Every sector of the industry-from growers to manufacturers to processors-felt the shock. The lowering of the wool price to 700c was done regardless of warning. All sections of the industry, including importers and manufacturers, wanted stability in the market. Everyone wanted stability in the market, except Mr Kerin, and I think Mr Kerin will rue the day he made that decision. It will haunt him until the day he dies.
—Don't be silly. You know nothing about it.

—I know a lot more about it than Senator Button does. If Senator Button wants to make a contribution, I would be interested to listen to it. After that decision was taken by the Minister, buyers stood out of the market and waited for the next reduction they believed would come. They were living only from hand to mouth, not placing decent orders. Now all the industry's worst fears have come true. The market has lost confidence in the floor. It is critical that we retain confidence in the floor and that confidence in the floor be held at 700c.

SPEECH.PARA: All these factors have come together and they have resulted in an extremely difficult situation for the wool industry. We all know that primary industry is cyclical but no one would have expected all these problems to hit over a five-year period, adding millions of kilograms of wool to the AWC stockpile. There is confusion, hardship and hurt out in the bush. The industry has to come to terms with its problems and work through them in a calm and rational manner. It is no good looking for scapegoats. That will not help the industry one little bit. If we do not get it right, it will not only be the woolgrowers who suffer; the repercussions will be felt right across Australia. In small country towns, regional cities and the largest capital cities people will feel the effects of the downturn in this industry. I believe-and I think Senator Button would agree-that this is one of the most serious problems facing this Parliament. Certainly it is one of the most serious problems I have faced in the eight years I have been a member of Parliament.

In the 1987-88 selling season Australia sold 784 million kilograms of wool; in 1988-89 the market met 840 million kilograms; in 1989-90 we dropped to 600 million kilograms and at present we are selling around 400 million kilograms a year, which is about half what we were doing in the 1988-89 season. It is in the national interest that we get wool flowing on to the market again. In 1988 the industry earned $6 billion for Australia in export sales. Directly and indirectly, it employs 650,000 people. On top of that, it has given great prosperity to Australia. It is the biggest industry in Australia and its marketing and research have been successful. It has been the flagship of Australia.

We did it right in 1983 when the International Wool Secretariat promoted cool wool. The world wanted our product and we were all very proud then of the Australian Wool Corporation. The world wanted our product so much that it drove demand ahead of supply. It was promoted in fashions and became the most sought after fibre for men's and women's garments. For the last 17 years sales have been increasing in both kilogram terms and value terms. We must ensure that this industry survives and we must give a strong commitment to the floor price. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is on record as saying the floor price will never be lower than it is now. The Government has agreed to back the floor price until the end of the 1992 selling season.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be broke before then.
—I believe Senator Panizza was in the wool industry in 1973, as was Senator Crane. I suppose they were no different from the Queensland farmers, who were receiving 24c a kilogram for their product.
—I got 18c.
—That must be some sort of record. Twenty four cents is the lowest figure I have heard but 18c is even worse. It would be a recipe for disaster if we ever went down that track again.

SPEECH.PARA: If the floor price was to go I do not know how we would stop pies and cartels being formed, because that is exactly what happened in the 1960s and the 1970s. Buying cartels and pies drove the price down to a point where farmers were at a subsistence level. The great wool industry was driven to its knees, returning the farmers a pittance for their sweat and toil. Supply had only to outreach demand slightly and down the market would go. If demand got ahead of supply, wool would take off. Neither the grower, the processor nor the manufacturer could know or plan for the future. It was chaos in the market.

In the late 1960s and early 1970s the interest rates were fairly minimal by today's standards. In those days farmers could just sit down, tighten their spending and pull in the belt a few notches, but today they cannot do that. The interest rate clock is running at around 20 per cent, and they cannot just sit out these disasters as they were able to do in the 1960s or 1970s. In those days-in the late 1960s and early 1970s-Australia escaped the worst of the wool recession because of the compensating mineral developments that poured millions of dollars into the economy, much of which went into the rural towns of Australia. We do not have that luxury in 1990. The economy is on a precipice now. Industry-and this industry in particular-has to remain viable for Australia's sake.

In the early 1970s the Australian Wool Corporation was set up. It had a rocky start and went close to running out of money in its very early years. It just got in. I would like to pay tribute to the former Leader of the National Party of Australia, Doug Anthony, who stuck to the industry then through thick and thin.

TALK.START.PARA: —Agreed.

—I thank Senator Panizza. After a very shaky start it fired, giving the wool industry a strong base to work from. It played a role in Australia's prosperity. More importantly, it took the roller-coaster effect out of the industry. It allowed the growing, the processing and the manufacturing sectors to plan, grow and develop with some certainty. It allowed the processors to know exactly what their base cost was. It put some certainty into the market and the result was that the industry was able to carve out a niche for quality and premium products. It allowed the International Wool Secretariat to promote the hallmark, the logo for the industry, as the best. When people bought a garment bearing the wool logo they knew that they were buying a top product. The promotion cost millions of dollars, but it got results.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last 17 years the wool industry has been monumentally successful. During the April crisis we had wool exporters in all sections of the industry beating a path to the door of this Parliament, begging on behalf of their customers to maintain the floor price as they saw it to be necessary and absolutely essential. That was not to be the case. The floor price went from 870c to 700c and Mr Kerin copped plenty when he went overseas.

I emphasise that in 1973 the Australian wool industry was returning the grower from around 18c-as Senator Crane tells me-to 24c a kilo. Farmers were actually putting grass in the tyres of their cars because they could not afford any alternative. After the AWC was formed the floor price moved, over a 17-year period, up to 870c. Depending on who one listens to, this may have been a wrong setting. It may have encouraged over-production, but I say that the setting of 870c was not what sent the wool industry into the decline that it is facing at the moment.

In April this year the AWC was buying 20 per cent of the offering and traded the remaining 80 per cent on to the market. After the decision was made to reduce the floor, the trade was purchasing 20 per cent and the Wool Corporation was buying 80 per cent. Today the Corporation bought 70 per cent of the offering. I believe that it is essential that the floor price be held at all costs. The ramifications of not holding the floor are too horrendous even to contemplate.

The industry has to set supply in line with demand. In a lot of areas that is already happening. The industry will make its own decisions on how this is done. We are seeing some variations now. Some of the farmers are using British rams to produce meat sheep for sale in the lamb trade. There are a number of farmers not joining their young ewes this year. The industry plan is to remove 15 to 20 million sheep. That will take away from the market a further 50 million kilograms. The industry, the farmers and the graziers are accepting what has to happen on the supply side. They will make the decisions that are necessary by force of economic rationalism.

The industry and the Government have to look at further ways to get the wool out of the warehouses and onto the market. I believe that at the end of this week-possibly tomorrow-the Chairman of the AWC, Mr Beggs, will accompany the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy on a sales visit around the world to sell wool. I wish Mr Kerin and Mr Beggs the best of luck on their selling trip. I hope they come back with full order books. The industry will address the supply side, but the Government and the Australian Wool Council must try new, innovative ideas and methods to get the wool out of the warehouses and onto the floor of the factories. I hope that Mr Kerin has some sort of sweetener in his sample bag so he can encourage the industry in terms of extending lines of credit and get the pipeline moving again. The Australian wool industry needs some big sales to create a circuit-breaker.

The AWC recommendations are based on the maximum of 750 million kilograms of wool going onto the market in the 1991-92 selling season; a tax of a maximum of 40 per cent in the 1992-93 season; and a culling program of around 20 million sheep. That is nasty medicine for any industry to swallow. The Wool Council will have to get out there and explain its action plan to the growers in all States of Australia.

The Wool Corporation's predictions are that unless that course of action is followed Australian stocks will rise to 6.4 million bales by 1991-92 and the debt will rise to over $3 billion and will have to be sustained by a wool tax of up to 40 per cent. That would spell disaster and the end of the floor price scheme as we know it now. The Wool Corporation's plan to bring in quotas will have to be carefully explained, as it seems to have very little support amongst the woolgrowers. Tonight the Senate will pass the necessary legislation to allow this plan to be implemented, and some hard decisions will have to be made.

Last week the Australian Wool Council and the Australian Wool Corporation launched their plan in Hobart. Tonight it is being debated in the Senate. I do not believe the growers have had enough time to understand what the ramifications of the plan mean to them at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: — The House of Representatives certainly did not have time to consider it.

—They are trying to work it out and, as Senator Panizza knows, anyone who has tried to get on the phone to any woolgrower in the last couple of nights knows that they have been ringing each other to try to find out how the plan will affect them, what it will do to their budget and how they will approach the bank manager. All these problems are going around and around out in the bush as if they were in a washing machine. I acknowledge the need to get the legislation in place at the earliest possible time so that the market and the growers will know just where they are in the next two years.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the plan, and the coalition will support the Bill ultimately, because I do not believe that the industry has any alternative other than to remove the floor and, as I said before, that is completely unacceptable. I can imagine what would happen with $3 billion worth of wool in stock and no floor price. We could go back to face exactly the situation that Senator Crane and Senator Panizza faced in 1970 with wool prices down very low.

At present the Corporation is buying approximately 60 per cent of the offering. Today it bought 70 per cent. But once this legislation comes down, hopefully the market will gain some confidence. It seems to me that it is imperative that the Corporation buy less than 35 per cent of the wool if the plan is to succeed. At present the Corporation is buying around 60 per cent. That will have to be reduced by half in the next six months to a net buy-in of around 35 per cent by the Corporation. Well, I wish it the best and I hope that it succeeds.

Quotas are raising great concerns. I have had a lot of questions directed at me about this, and I believe that this is the most unacceptable part of the plan. Many farmers remember the wheat quotas. They were before my time, but they are still causing a bad hangover in the bush. It seems to me that such quotas were universally unacceptable.

I was assured by Mr Beggs that there would be an appeal system set up to handle any inconsistencies regarding properties that have been in drought areas in the last 12 months, or any other contingencies. One share farmer asked me whether the quota, if it is brought in, would belong to him or to his share farmer because they both own the sheep in partnership. We will need the wisdom of Solomon to sort out these sorts of contingencies, but that was just one question that was thrown up to me. Farmers do not seem to have great faith in appeal boards. One farmer told me that he had never won an appeal in his life.

The business plan includes provision for a low cost slaughter program returning the grower between 90c to 180c. I do not know whether this will compensate them for the losses or cover the cost of slaughter. It would be very easy to criticise the Australian Wool Corporation plan. It will be very hard for producers to come to terms with the problem. But I do not think that criticism will get the wool industry anywhere. It is time to get behind the plan and to give it a go. It is time for all the Monday morning quarterbacks to retire from the field and let the wool industry-the growers, the exporters and manufacturers-play the game. It is time for everyone to work together to see that this great industry survives and continues to give prosperity to all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the legislation that is before the Senate tonight is the Government's attempt to put forward its plan to set the wool industry on a stable course. First, let us look at what the problem is and then at how the Government proposes to fix it. There is no argument that there has been an enormous oversupply of wool in Australia, with an equally dramatic drop in demand. The oversupply has occurred for many reasons, but the two main reasons, I believe, are a succession of good seasons and secondly, the high wool prices of the past few years.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the reasons for the present lack of demand, we find that because of the political situation in Europe, which we all applaud, the economic upheaval is so great that the Eastern bloc countries, particularly the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) are unable to enter the market through the lack of hard currency. Indeed, the USSR still owes Australia for some of its last year's sales. Again, China has had similar problems, although the political situation is in reverse. Demand in western Europe is there, but it has had a couple of unusually mild winters and, because of our uncertainty and its present stockpile, it is staying out of the market-and who would blame it? Its stocks were markedly devalued when the Government lowered the floor price of wool from 870c a kilo at which they had bought their stocks to 700c. So the Europeans are sitting on the sidelines waiting to see whether we intend to lower the price further. Of course, the Gulf crisis has added further to the uncertainties.

The only ray of light in the whole situation is Japan where wool stocks are running out and the Japanese will soon be forced to enter the auction because they will not let their woollen mills close. However, they too are waiting to see which way we will jump before they start buying. The message that the debate here in this Parliament is giving is that the floor price remain. To enforce this message the farmers are paying an additional levy to maintain that price. Having looked at the lack of demand, let us look at the over-supply. As I have said, we have had a succession of good seasons in many parts of Australia since the dreadful drought of 1982-83. Some States have had better seasons than others. The wool price has boomed and many farmers decided to run a few sheep for the first time in their lives, and those farms that could run sheep increased the numbers of their flocks over previous years.

I will quote the percentage increase State by State of greasy wool production for the years 1984-85 to the estimated 1990-1991 season. I have chosen 1984-85 because that was the year that represented the average number of sheep-168.2m run over the past 10 years. New South Wales had an increase of 48 per cent; Victoria, 34 per cent; Queensland, 23 per cent; Western Australia, 28 per cent; South Australia, 15 per cent; Tasmania, 12 per cent; and Australia on average 34 per cent. So we have a 34 per cent over-production of wool, which represents about 47 million more sheep than our average. Therefore, it is pretty obvious to everyone that we have to do something about our over-production.

This group of Bills proposes several strategies but really fiddles around the edges. It proposes that the farmers should pay a levy that will enable the Wool Corporation to first continue the 700c floor price scheme; next, pay for a slaughter scheme; next, exempt some carpet wool growers from the levy; and finally provide assistance to those farmers affected by the recent disastrous floods in northern and central New South Wales.

I would like to deal just with the first two problems. As we are all aware, until July this year, farmers were paying an 8 per cent levy on their wool to maintain the 870c floor price. It then went up to 18 per cent; from 8 to 18 per cent. In October this year it rose again to 25 per cent; and, of course, by this time the floor price had dropped to 700c. The woolgrowers, according to this legislation, are now asked to increase their levy to 30 per cent, with a 20 per cent surcharge: a total of a possible 50 per cent tax on the wool they will produce.

The facts are that the floor price has dropped by just on 20 per cent and that the levy they are being asked to pay has gone from 8 per cent to a possible 50 per cent. The surcharge of 20 per cent, we have been told, will be repaid eventually. Not only that, but the Wool Corporation is now talking about a quota. I would like to know how this can be done in a just and equitable fashion. At least the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, now acknowledges that there is an enormous oversupply. He has suggested that about $100m of this new levy be spent on a slaughter scheme to cull 20 million sheep, less than half the number, as I have already pointed out, that need to be culled. If my figure were agreed to, that would bring us back to the 168 million, which is our average.

The Corporation says that the rest can be culled by a quota scheme, a scheme that covers the wool clip of farmers from November last year to November this year. How can this quota scheme be implemented with any justice? I return to the figures that I cited a few minutes ago of the State by State increases: New South Wales increased its production by 48 per cent; Victoria, 34 per cent; Queensland, 23 per cent; Western Australia, 28 per cent; South Australia, 15 per cent; and Tasmania, only 12 per cent. Why in the heck should Tasmania and South Australia pay the price for the greed of New South Wales and Victoria?

We are told that there will be an appeal mechanism that will allow for drought conditions and other such tragedies to be taken into consideration, but not State by State overproduction. How is it suggested that we cope with those farmers who shore their sheep early to claim the 870c while the Government vacillated, through bullying and threats, et cetera, before it forced the floor price down to 700c? Those farmers, by shearing early, added to their clip; and that is what the quota would be taken on. Because the quota will cover all lines of wool, the farmers will not be able to put up for auction all their best fleeces. So we will find that some of the finest, cleanest and highest priced wool in Australia, coming from my State, will be affected by the quotas. Why vote for this legislation if one agrees with that? We will find that some of the finest wool-wool that is in great demand and wool that Australia needs for its current account figures-will not be sold because of the quota scheme. Quotas just cannot work with any justice. Because it will be unjust, the farmers will store their own wool and we will end up with two stockpiles.

The only answer we can come up with is that our oversupply must be cut by a commercial slaughter levy. No-one wants to do this. There is no-one amongst those who have seen the slaughter of the sheep that has already occurred who has not suffered tremendous heartache, but there is simply no other answer. There is talk about additional marketing and about the long term needs-and there must be more effort in this regard-but something has got to be done right now while farmers are still shearing. It is when the sheep are sold off shears that farmers can be best enticed to sell their sheep at commercial rates. They have to be picked up at point of sale so that we do not have other farmers buying sheep at 20c a head and putting them on pastures that normally would be used for other less commercially viable products such as wheat.

Finally, can I make it just perfectly clear to those senators in this chamber who do not understand the industry just what is happening in the bush. In 1989-90, the average woolgrower in Australia, producing 21-micron wool with an average yield, received $20.47 for the wool from each sheep after he had paid all the direct costs associated with running the sheep-shearing them, selling the wool and paying the levy. Because the reserve price has been dropped to 700c a kilo and the levy increased to 25 per cent, the return to the woolgrower has gone from $20.47 per head to $11.71-a reduction of 42.8 per cent in just one year.

The Government now suggests that a 30 per cent levy with a 20 per cent surcharge should occur. If this does happen, the net return per sheep on the average will be reduced to $6.14, which equals a reduction in income of 70 per cent. That is before interest rates and wages are even considered. The Opposition will not go along with the surcharge. No-one can survive on a 70 per cent reduction in his income.

We will vote for an increase in the levy to 30 per cent, but not for the surcharge. An increase in the levy will mean a 48.2 per cent reduction in the income of the farmer, but we cannot go to a 70 per cent reduction. Let me assure those Labor senators opposite that there would not be one Australian Council of Trade Unions affiliated trade union member in Australia who would tolerate anything like the type of treatment the Government is attempting to hand out tonight.

The Government was all very quick, if we remember, in handing out money to subsidise Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd because it may have lost a few employees in the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). What was the figure again? I am sure that Senator Walsh can tell us. About $30m-odd was given to Kodak, which has now made a tremendous profit.

TALK.START.PARA: —What electorate was it in? You don't know.

—It was on the border of Wills. Now we have found that Kodak has made a tremendous profit, and the Government is here saying that it does not matter about the farmers. Well, the farmers are already paying their own levies-not being handed grants-but the Government is saying that it will add another 20 per cent surcharge. The reduction in income would end up being 70 per cent if that surcharge were used in full. We are being told that that reduction would not occur because the Wool Corporation and the Government tell us that they would not use that surcharge.

SPEECH.PARA: I heard Senator Crane say tonight that it is like giving a bucket of ice-cream to a child and saying, `Eat only half, don't eat the lot'. How true. Once the 50 per cent tax was able to be charged, does the Government mean to say that it would not be used? If the Government is serious that it would not be used, then for heaven's sake it should not impose it. That is how the Opposition feels and that is how we will be voting. We will vote for an increase in the levy to 30 per cent which, as I have already said, means a reduction of 48 per cent in the farmers' income, but we will not go that extra 20 per cent, which would mean a 70 per cent reduction. No-one can survive such a reduction, and the Opposition will not go along with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wool Tax (No. 1 to 5) Further Amendment Bills and the Wool Legislation Amendment Bill, which are before the Senate this evening, are vital to Australia as they relate to the survival of the wool industry as we know it at present. After all the excellent speeches given by coalition senators this evening, the Government must be convinced that the 20 per cent surcharge proposed by it is not necessary and should be omitted from the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has ridden on the sheep's back for years. Wool is Australia's greatest earner of export dollars. Ninety-nine per cent of Australian wool is Australian owned and 97 per cent of wool is exported-or at least it used to be. It is a bit hard to get it exported at the moment as it is all stored up waiting for sale.

Wool has always helped Australia pay its way. Yet today in Australia wool has become so expendable that we daily read of farmers who have to shoot their flocks because it is not even profitable to ship these worthless animals to markets. As one newspaper headline said, `$1.80 will buy one beer or 18 sheep'.

The wool industry faces a very difficult time. Production is dramatically ahead of demand and so naturally we are witnessing an ever-increasing stockpile problem. With that are rapidly increasing taxes to finance the purchase and storage of those stockpiles. How dreadful that this once great industry has been reduced to such circumstances. I ask honourable senators: How can we have had such a profitable and efficient industry so quickly destroyed in a few years? Just why are Australian woolgrowers in the current situation?

Back in the autumn session we debated in this chamber the Government's legislation to drop the wool floor price. The Government may have thought it was helping the industry by its action of dropping the floor price, but I say to honourable senators that all it did was help to damage the industry. The marketing scheme had been great for the wool industry and for Australia. Our sometimes first, and sometimes second, largest export earner, the wool industry, had developed and made an enormous contribution to our export earnings.

European and Japanese wool buying interests disliked the success of our wool marketing scheme. They were not able to manipulate the market, and they have not benefited from the periodic collapse in price that was familiar prior to 1970 when the scheme was put into place. For 20 years the Australian wool industry benefited from unprecedented price stability. Yet the Government decided to intervene purely because it was unhappy that money was not going quickly enough into Treasury coffers to cover the enormous balance of payments this Government had created.

As I told the Senate earlier this year, nowhere had it been demonstrated-as distinct from asserted-that were the offer price for Australian wool to be lowered there would be any kind of direct and significant demand response. Further, and more importantly, it had not been shown that any such response would ensure that gross income to the industry would increase or even be maintained. Our current growing wool stockpiles are testament to that.

As I told the Senate, this interference could ruin the reserve price scheme and ravage future orderly wool marketing. We have to realise that the speculation about the floor price has done market damage that may not be recoverable. The slightest doubt and lack of resolution will only give the buyers encouragement to continue their resistance to the floor price.

Today Mr Kerin and, sadly, woolgrowers are having to adapt to some of those consequences. It is not that wool has been surpassed as a fine material. Woolgrowers are not facing a situation where a synthetic fibre has been developed that can replicate the desirable and superior characteristics of wool-not at any price, let alone a comparable one. Confirmation of this is the fact that sales and exports data for the eight months to 28 February 1990 show that several traditional large and important wool buying countries with sophisticated and high technology processing industries have substantially increased their wool imports compared with the same period last year: West Germany by 49 per cent; Italy by 9 per cent; the Netherlands by 377 per cent; the United Kingdom by 9 per cent; and Taiwan by 19 per cent. But what has happened is that, where countries have purchased significantly less wool, it has been agreed in most cases to be due to a shortage of foreign exchange currency, as in the Soviet Union, China and Poland.
As the Australian Wool Corporation said in its annual report, which was tabled in the Senate only last week:

Demand . . . fell sharply, partly in response to high market prices in 1988 but also as major export markets in China, Russia and eastern Europe almost collapsed because of totally unpredictable economic and political changes.

The conclusion, therefore, must be that today we are dealing with normal economic market forces of supply, demand and price. Raw wool price has little effect on demand for wool. It did not in the late 1960s and early 1970s before the reserve price scheme began when prices fluctuated wildly. The academic economists' approach to the current wool industry battle was flawed badly. Today we have to take some action to correct those bad decisions made by the Government when it reduced the floor price of wool.

As I said, the Government thought that it would be able to get those millions of bales of wool in Australia to the markets if it reduced the price. Where are those bales? They are stored in sheds throughout Australia. It is to correct this problem that we are debating these Bills this evening.

To finance those growing stockpiles the growers pay a levy. Until 1 July that levy was about 8 per cent, then it rose to 18 per cent, and in October it moved to 25 per cent. According to industry projections, it could be 40 per cent from July next year. At the beginning of the 1980-90 wool selling season, 200,000 bales were in the stockpile. At the conclusion of the selling season in June of this year, 3.1 million bales were in that stockpile. The projection for this year is that there will be between 5.3 and 5.7 million bales by the end of the wool selling season in June next year. If the increase continues at the same rate, obviously it will be between 7 million and 8 million bales at the end of the next selling season. Marketing alone will not get the industry out of its problems, as the Australian Wool Corporation has finally acknowledged. Production must be dramatically reduced and quickly.

The 20 million flock reduction, together with quotas and the 20 per cent surcharge from 1 July, will not bring supply into line with demand fast enough. Therefore, as has been indicated by earlier speakers, the coalition will be unable to fully support all aspects of this legislation. A major slaughter scheme is the only realistic method of bringing supply down in the short time available to the industry, although this does not come into the legislation that we are discussing this evening.

Time is the essential aspect of what we are talking about. This industry does not have the luxury of time in dealing with its problems, and to date this urgency has been missing from the measures imposed. Neither will quotas be a solution to the industry's problems. They have never worked and I believe they will not work in the wool industry. Despite what I can only call the flawed actions of the Government earlier this year to reduce the floor price, I agree with the decision of the Government to maintain the current 700c a kilogram floor price. This legislation aims to keep that 700c floor price, and I agree that this is very necessary. Without a firm floor price, the market will disappear. But I remind honourable senators that the Government should never have tampered with the floor price in the first place.

I acknowledge the need to increase the wool tax to 30 per cent for the market support fund and to pay for the flock reduction scheme. What I am critical of is the continuing failure of this Government and the Minister, Mr Kerin, together with the industry, to inform woolgrowers, fully and adequately, of the seriousness of the situation they were facing and are still facing. That includes the 30 per cent oversupply problem.

Many growers today do not yet realise that the 25 per cent wool tax they are paying already will never be returned to them. It will be eaten up in interest and storage payments. To add another 20 per cent surcharge to this would destroy too many growers; in other words, an eventual tax of 50 per cent. What a slug to have your income halved. Honourable senators would not be very happy if someone said they were to lose 50 per cent of their income-just as I do not believe that the average woolgrower wants a scheme where 50 per cent of the wool cheque is taken up in tax as well as sales quotas.

I also support the provision in the legislation for growers disadvantaged by recent flooding. This provision is to allow growers who were not able to deliver wool for sale before 30 June, because of the floods, to receive the higher floor price and the lower wool tax. I ask honourable senators: Is there any way that wool farmers can get at least some small amount of money for their sheep which could help them to meet costs? The Government must investigate and, if necessary, give some assistance to cut red tape, or other bureaucratic hindrances, to use and sell this commodity.

Honourable senators from my own State of Queensland would have read of the plan by a Brisbane Catholic priest, Father John McKeon, to use some of those worthless flocks for the hungry and needy. That is a commendable use for what would otherwise be a destroyed commodity. But growers, of course, would not receive any payment for those sheep. In today's Australian it was reported that Queensland welfare and meat industry representatives agreed to a scheme where sheep slaughtered by farmers because of the wool industry collapse would be distributed to the needy. That is certainly better than shooting them and just burying them. It is giving some people the chance to have some good food.

However, I also ask that the Government help the industry out of the hole into which it has been pushed. That means not only looking at reduction in production, and an aggressive marketing scheme, but also searching out markets which we would never have contemplated in the past. I believe an instance of this could be the Philippines businessman who approached my husband's company in Brisbane advising that millions of sheep could be taken to the Philippines-live sheep and, indeed, slaughtered sheep. But we have to realise that the Philippines is a Third World country and has no foreign exchange. Of course, that would be a matter of bartering: fast patrol boats, rubber gloves and carpet underlay.

It would not hurt the Government to support a proposal such as this with finance. Farmers would get a bit back for the sheep that were going to be slaughtered and buried. It would be a good thing for a Third World country such as that to get a bit of help when one considers how much money the Government gives away to other countries. The Minister should help to by-pass some of these problems by at least selling some of our product overseas. I also ask that the Government look at some ways of addressing the ever decreasing income and the financial burdens that those in the wool industry are expected to carry.

Only yesterday I asked Senator Cook, as the Minister representing Mr Kerin in the Senate, whether the Government would, as a measure of relief to growers, be prepared to reduce the prescribed minimum value for sheep from the current value of $4 per head to the 1984 figure of $1 per head.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is for natural increase, isn't it?

—That is right. All the Minister could say was that he would make available to me a statement by Mr Kerin on the wool industry. He either did not seem to be aware of the situation where one is taxed for money one does not even earn or, as this Government has shown all too often, he does not care because woolgrowers do not reside in Sydney or Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to remind honourable senators of something which I find I often have to express in this chamber, and that is we should be ever vigilant that we do not allow ideology on economic issues and crass politics to misplace the needs of people. This is what is happening in many industries today and it is at the expense of many important sections of our community. Today it is the economic survival of Australia's wool industry.
Finally, I would urge all honourable senators to support the amendment that is to be moved by the Opposition, namely, that the 20 per cent surcharge proposed by the Government be opposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Presumably we all know that we are debating a wool package which, among other things, increases the maximum wool tax from 20c to 30c. It includes an overriding 20 per cent surcharge and it provides support for growers disadvantaged by recent flooding. This will allow growers who are unable to deliver their wool before 30 June to receive a higher floor price. It also exempts carpet wool and provides the ability to use money from the market support fund for the sheep disposal scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: The wool industry is in a state of crisis. That is an expression often used in the rural industry. Perhaps it is because of the droughts, the floods and the pestilence that seem to be visited upon Australia every so often. But we really are in a dreadful state-the wool industry in particular. I suspect that the minimum price is at risk of collapsing. I do not know whether it is going to be with us next year or not. In the event that it is not, I wonder what price farmers will receive for their wool.

International demand is weak and I would think it is likely to remain weak for some time yet. Of course, this is due to two things: the price we have been demanding for our wool and the fact that a number of our traditional markets now have very serious economic problems. For instance, in the year 1988-89, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics purchased 18 per cent of our wool. Last year it purchased only 9 per cent. There is great hope that, with the changes in eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, there is going to be a new dynamic market. My own view is that the economy in the Soviet Union is a great deal worse than has been judged. I would think it is not going to be in a position to increase its demand for Australian wool in the near future. Sales to China fell by 56 per cent between 1988-89 and 1989-90.

I would not have thought that in the medium term we could be optimistic that there would be an improvement in China's demand. It has very real domestic problems. One of the tragedies is that the Wool Corporation perceived China's wool purchases as the norm rather than aberrations. It was inevitable when we could see what was happening to China's economy, when it broke away from the rigours of a centralised system and dallied for a time with a deregulated, decentralised system-with the provinces having much autonomy-there was a temptation for each province in an uncoordinated way to distort the economy. There was an enormous inflow of capital, a number of factories started up and inflation grew very rapidly and China had to do something about that. That has been exacerbated by recent events which were caused in part by the cut off of international funds.

The European Community sales have fallen by 12 per cent over the last financial year. I would have thought that there was not a great deal of optimism to be had that it will increase its level of demand. With prices being distorted the way they are, the European Community has moved away from wool and has found substitutes. In the last 12 months demand fell by 30 per cent in Japan. While there are different views about the state of the Japanese economy, I would have thought that it is still fragile and it is unlikely that its demand will pick up. We need only to have the Gulf crisis continue to overlay that problem, and that will cause oil prices to remain high or go higher, stimulating inflation and slowing down world demand.

The inevitable has happened as a result of Australia's price. Current production is approximately six million bales. Sales are averaging 3.8 million bales. I understand that this year we will be lucky to sell three million bales. Production in Australia has increased by 20 per cent over the last three years. By the end of this year the Australian Wool Corporation will have five million bales in stock and next year, all being equal with no changes, there will be about six million to 6.5 million bales with the Wool Corporation presently having a debt of $2 billion and likely to be $3 billion by the middle of next year.

This is a classic case of the reserve price being distorted and in turn the price signals being distorted. The price signals became so camouflaged that the reserve price bore no relationship to the real price. What started as a floor price ended up as a minimum price and as the prices went up in the short term, the minimum price dashed up after it. Had we used more efficient ways, from the outset we could have sorted out the peaks and troughs or smoothed out incomes. As we all know, we had an income equalisation deposit scheme which this Government saw fit to abolish. That would have been a much more efficient way of smoothing out the incomes of farmers.

One of the major proposals in this legislation is to introduce a slaughter scheme. The initial scheme is to take about 15 million to 20 million sheep out of the flock. That will cost about $100m. Based on that calculation, it is intended to take out about 50 million kilograms of wool. To me that projection seems far too low. On my calculations if we return to average sales of 750 million kilograms, we need to be reducing production by about 250 million and that would require reducing the flock numbers by between 40 million and 50 million sheep. To do that we would be looking at a figure of about $400m.

While we can get the crackers, the old sheep and the rubbish out, we can get the first five million out pretty cheaply but after that prices are bound to go up for a number of reasons, not the least of which being that farmers, ever the optimists, will imagine that as they reduce the numbers, the demand will increase, and the price will go back up and they will be tempted to hold on to their flocks, imagining that everybody else is selling his. As they come to their quality flock, they will tend to store it. That is why quotas will not work; one ends up with two stockpiles-the official stockpile and the on-farm stockpile.

I believe that a 50 per cent levy will destroy many woolgrowers. It will cause massive bankruptcies, drive down land values and drastically reduce the equity of many farmers and their properties. That will make the banks all the more nervous as they inevitably have more foreclosures.

One of the tragedies of this situation is that it is almost unique. We have a situation of dramatically falling wool prices and dramatically falling wheat prices. What has caused part of the problem is the exchange rate. That has, of course, sapped demand. In the bad old days when we were in this situation with a fixed currency, we could just devalue and get rid of stock without having to reduce prices. But, of course, we cannot do that now.

The other twin evil is the high interest rate, which is very much caused by the high exchange rate. That is destroying the value of the stockpile. It has undermined the capacity of the rural sector to weather out this storm. If we look at net farm cash income, we see it will fall by 32 per cent this year. Net farm production is expected to climb by 57 per cent, which gives some idea of the state of the rural sector.

I do not believe that this legislation deals with the fundamental problem. It plays around the edges in terms of removing the numbers out of the flock that are necessary. We have a flock of 175 million, have not we?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 185 million.
—We think that if we take 20 million out, we will dramatically change the price. Of course we will not, and that will shortly be shown.

SPEECH.PARA: I did promise to be brief and I will be. I just conclude on one not terribly fundamental matter to the issue. I notice that Senator Bjelke-Petersen referred to a program in Queensland where sheep are being provided to voluntary organisations. One of the great difficulties with that is that it costs about $14 a head to put the sheep through the abattoirs. It is a cost. I notice there is a program in Western Australia where sheep are put through the gaol abattoirs, and to some extent that has worked. About 500 sheep or so have been used, so it is not easy.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Queensland people gave their services and it did not cost a thing.
—I think that has also happened in Western Australia with Father Brian Morris, who is doing exactly the same thing. I support the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —At this late hour I will not take long to respond to the debate. Apart from everything else, the debate has been substantially rehearsed in the House of Representatives and there has been a substantial amount of public discussion about this here and elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody will jump for joy and glee about any of the measures that are required to deal with the wool industry in the circumstances in which we find it now. In many ways it has been desirable that most people have refrained from cheap shots and simplistic attempts at solutions. I do not agree with a number of the things that have been said but the days in which people thought that all these problems were somehow internally generated I thought were totally behind us. It is not quite the case, but they do seem to be substantially behind us, and I value that.

There are some matters to respond to. But at 20 minutes to 12 I do not want to start debating with people their views about macro-economic policies and its possible interrelationship, even though I think they are wrong. Just to make it clear, in case anybody is under any misapprehension, the surcharge is not a government initiative; the idea did not originate from the Government-it originated from industry. The Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) and the Wool Council want it. That does not mean that we have to do it.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that at 20 to 12 some people find listening harder than talking; several others find thinking harder than both. The AWC business plan indicates that tax levels of 30 per cent are required to maintain the Corporation's financial viability and growers' equity in the stockpile. This indicates that those measures are required to maintain the scheme. If the Opposition wants the scheme, then it has to continue to support what it takes to maintain it. The Opposition cannot have its cake and eat it too in these matters as it does in other economic matters which it is trying to deal with. It is a bit like saying, `We'll reduce the total of government expenditure by several billion but we won't support any particular measures to reduce it'. It is a response of equal intellectual rigour and logic.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also necessary to make it clear, just in case anybody has the misfortune to hear or read the debate and be misled, that neither the Australian Government nor the ubiquitous and very powerful Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, controls the world economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —They call him the phantom; he's never there.

—There are certain vacant spaces over there around which noises are echoing. I do wish they would stop at this rather late hour. Neither controls the world economy. That is, in effect, what is affecting the sale rate. Everybody who is serious about it knows that over recent years there has been in the United States of America an economic policy that has led to and compounded the twin deficit debacle with which that nation is confronted.

SPEECH.PARA: Probably the rest of the world, except the National Party of Australia, has noticed that there is a Gulf crisis and that that is having some impact on the international economy. The economic circumstances in Japan have led to a change in its demand for wool. Certainly, dramatic changes in eastern Europe and in the Soviet Union have had a substantial impact which no-one could deny and the consequences of which have been profound on demand for wool.

The problems with the United Kingdom economy under the policies advocated by the Opposition in the hope that they would be introduced here have led to double digit inflation and double digit unemployment in that country, as the Opposition's policies did the last time it tried them here in Australia. That has of course had adverse consequences on demand for wool. There is no doubt that these factors dramatically affect consumer confidence. That drives the apparel wool market and it drives the demand for Australian wool.

Some interesting things were said about carpet wool, which has become one of the phrases of the moment. Because the fundamental problem is too difficult, people focus on a significant but not central matter. I do not mean to reduce the significance of that important part of the industry but, if we could solve that single-handedly, we would still have a rather significant wool industry problem. Everybody wants to talk about that. I am not saying that it is insignificant, but it is important that the Australian Government is represented through the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Dr Blewett), who is in New Zealand at the moment dealing with some significant arguments with that country about issues of subsidy of carpet wool and the consequences of the import of that wool to Australia. That is a significant part of the subsidiary problem that needs to be addressed.

Given the enthusiasm of the Opposition for this debate, I could, with the enthusiasm of my colleagues, go on at some greater length, but I am happy to say that it is important that this Bill be carried, and be carried promptly, so I urge its support to the chamber.
Amendment negatived.
Original question agreed to.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: WOOL TAX (Nos 1 TO 5) FURTHER AMENDMENT BILLS 1990
The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, before I move to the amendment I have circulated, I have a question of you, as Chairman, with regard to the formality of the Bills we have before us. You will notice that before the listing of the short title in the preamble to the Bill it is stated, `The Parliament of Australia enacts'. This is the first occasion on which Bills coming before this Senate have used those words. In effect, they create a new formula which I believe needs explanation and creates a precedent. Previously the words that appeared on all Bills that came before the House were:

SPEECH.PARA: BE IT ENACTED by the Queen, and the Senate and the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, as follows:

The Bill then proceeds. This change has been made, very obviously, without any consultation with the Parliament. It is not a matter for government pursuit or government decision. I look to you, sir, for an explanation as to why this change has been made, who has made it, and why there has been no consultation, as there should have been as a matter of very proper form, with both this Senate and, of course, the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot answer the second and third questions. I am not quite sure that I can answer the first question, but I will give it a go. I understand that the Constitution refers to the Parliament as consisting of the Queen, the Senate and the House of Representatives, so the Parliament, under that definition, would mean the same as the words which Senator Tambling mentioned as being in previous Bills. I cannot provide any further information. It might be an appropriate course of action for Senator Tambling to ask the Minister, but at this stage I would say that the Bills are in order.

—Mr Chairman, I am not disputing the order of the Bills. The main thrust of my argument was the decision to change the form without consultation with the Parliament-either the Senate or the House of Representatives-on an important matter that obviously has consequences of both precedent and authority of the Parliament. As you request, Mr Deputy President, I certainly redirect that question to the Minister and ask him whether he is able to answer any of the questions that I posed initially to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a fascinating issue in which to get involved. I have heard a lot of accusations in the two or three years that I have been in the Senate about things being done without consultation with the Parliament, but it is the first time that I have heard it alleged about something that has already been passed by the House of Representatives and is now being debated in this chamber. It is what one would call a secret manoeuvre-only 224 members of Parliament have seen it!

SPEECH.PARA: I am not quite sure what Senator Tambling's point is. This is what is called the world's worst kept secret-everybody has been given a copy. It is being expressed differently and the honourable senator is entitled to have a passionate view about the way it is being expressed and to debate it in the second reading stage or now, if he can find some formula here. But I do not understand the problem. The honourable senator says that this is being done without consultation. I regard it as a fairly routine and mundane matter. The honourable senator is entitled to have a view about it, but I cannot see how he can think that it is being done in any secret manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In continuing to raise the issue, I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that it was raised in the House of Representatives on 7 November by Mr Peacock with Mr Beazley. I believe that on that occasion a very unsatisfactory answer was given and recorded and, again, no explanation was given as to why a very important form and process of the Parliament has, in effect, been changed and thwarted by the Government without consultation with the Parliament. I think it is appropriate that we record our reservations and our notation that as part of the Labor Party's republican thrust it is choosing to implement Government policies in an area that is more properly the domain of the Parliament. I seek leave to move a motion.
