AUSTRALIAN CITIZENSHIP AMENDMENT BILL 1990

Mr President, the main purpose of this Bill is to remove an inequity based on gender which has existed in the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 (the Act) since its commencement on 26 January 1949. The Bill also seeks to correct three minor administrative difficulties with the operation of the Act.

Honourable senators will be aware that prior to 26 January 1949, people born or naturalised in Australia were British subjects and that the Act introduced the status of Australian citizen on that date.

The Transitional Provisions of that Act automatically conferred Australian citizenship status on 26 January 1949 upon British subjects if they were born outside Australia and New Guinea and their fathers were born in Australia or New Guinea and acquired Australian citizenship on 26 January 1949, and they had entered Australia and been allowed to stay permanently. The Act provided that those persons who had not previously entered Australia became Australian citizens automatically when they did so, providing their entry was for permanent residence.

Following amendments to the Act on 6 May 1966, such persons were also required to be British subjects upon entry to Australia if they entered on or after that date. The Transitional Provisions were repealed on 1 May 1987.

Although this provision enabled a child to acquire Australian citizenship by descent through the father, there was no similar provision for Australian citizenship to be acquired by descent through an Australian mother.

This Bill will enable a person born outside Australia and New Guinea before 26 January 1949 to apply for and acquire Australian citizenship by descent through registration where the person's mother became a citizen on 26 January 1949 providing certain requirements are met. To ensure the provision corresponds with the provision to acquire Australian citizenship through a father, only a person whose mother was born in Australia or New Guinea, or who had been naturalised in Australia before 26 January 1949 will be eligible. The person also must have been present in Australia at some time before 1 May 1987, and apply for registration on an approved form.
There will be no application fee and upon registration being approved, evidence of citizenship will be issued free of the usual charge.
The Bill will also allow the children of these applicants to be included in the registration. No age limit will apply to these persons.
This provision is based on descent. The concession will therefore be limited to the natural issue of the parent from whom the benefit derives.
Unlike the paternal concession, however, the proposed provision will not be limited to British subjects, the definition for which was repealed from the Act in 1987 to remove discrimination.
A five year limit will apply to the lodgement of applications under this provision.

While the number of people covered by this provision is thought to be small, absence of it has nonetheless caused considerable and justifiable concern to those affected and it is clearly a discriminatory matter which needs to be rectified.
I will now move to discuss the minor administrative difficulties that the Bill seeks to remedy.

The Act currently requires a person who applies for registration of citizenship by descent to be registered within 18 years after the person's birth. The Bill will ensure that where an application for the registration of citizenship by descent is lodged before the person's eighteenth birthday but actual registration has not been effected prior to that date, then the person will not be denied citizenship because of administrative delay.

The Bill will amend section lOB of the Act to provide that registration of citizenship by descent may be effected where an application is lodged at a place of registration-usually an office of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs or an Australian mission overseas, no later than an eligible person's eighteenth birthday. This amendment will be retrospective to rectify cases where administrative oversight has resulted in unlawful registration after the eighteenth birthday of persons who applied prior to that time and who have satisfied all other requirements.

The Bill also amends section 13 of the Act to ensure that a child who has been included in a responsible parents application, but whose name has been unintentionally omitted from the certificate of citizenship, and who is over 16 years of age, can nevertheless acquire citizenship by amendment of the responsible parent's certificate of citizenship.
Section 13 currently requires that the child has to be under 16 at the time the certificate of citizenship was amended.
This amendment will overcome doubts associated with Departmental practice of remedying this situation by amending the responsible parent's certificate pursuant to section 47 of the Act.

The final matter addressed by the Bill relates to the definition of an application for the purposes of the Act. To ensure that all applications lodged under the Act can be properly identified and the appropriate application fees are paid, the Bill provides that an application is not made unless it is on an approved form, accompanied by the prescribed fee and is received at an office of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs or an official representative of the Australian Government overseas designated for such a purpose. This provision is consistent with similar provisions in the recently amended Migration Act 1958.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
NORTHERN PRAWN FISHERY VOLUNTARY ADJUSTMENT SCHEME LOAN GUARANTEE AMENDMENT BILL 1990

In 1989 the Government undertook a major review of the management of Commonwealth fisheries. This review culminated in my release of a policy statement titled `New Directions for Commonwealth Fisheries Management in the 1990s'. The policy statement placed particular emphasis on the need to ensure that:
Fisheries resources are not overexploited and that any exploitation is at a level which can be sustained while maintaining the surrounding environment
Commercial fishing operations are economically efficient, using the most appropriate technology to achieve the greatest net returns

Fishermen make an appropriate payment to the community for the right to exploit a public resource for private gain, provided that new profits are generated and that the industry has the capacity to make such a payment.
The policy statement also emphasised that the administration of Commonwealth fisheries should be established on the most efficient and effective basis.

Taken together these management objectives emphasise the importance of maximising economic efficiency, but are always constrained to protect the resources. These objectives are entirely consistent with the Government's policy of ecologically sustainable development.

The policy statement identified the existence of substantial excess fishing capacity as the main factor inhibiting the attainment of these management objectives. In order to address this problem the Government gave a commitment that it would assist the fishing industry to reduce overcapacity, as long as it was convinced that this would help the fishery concerned to become more profitable.
The statement also indicated that this assistance would be provided on a fishery by fishery basis.

The northern prawn fishery is the most valuable fishery managed by the Commonwealth. For the past few years operators in the northern prawn fishery have experienced financial difficulty. This has been largely caused by considerable excess capacity in the fishing fleet and a sharp reduction in world prawn prices due to competition from farm grown prawns mainly originating from South East Asian countries. A poor Australian banana prawn catch this year has aggravated this situation.

There is general agreement by industry that there needs to be significant reduction in fishing effort to restore the fishery to profitability. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has estimated that if the capacity of the fleet was halved the profitability of the fishery would increase significantly from the current negative levels of about $40m to positive levels about $20m per year or more.

Furthermore the possibility of too much fishing effort damaging the prawn stocks is always a concern. At present the prawn stock does not appear to be in danger, but this could change relatively quickly. Only five years ago CSIRO scientists were most concerned about this and the Government with industry support implemented gear restrictions, extended seasonal closures and bans on daylight trawling to protect the stocks.

For these reasons it was decided it was appropriate for it to be the first fishery to be restructured. A joint government/industry task force was established and together with the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Committee a restructuring package was developed. Throughout the process the industry was widely consulted and there were a number of meetings with fishermen at the principal ports.

The assistance package which the Government has agreed to will build upon the Voluntary Adjustment Scheme (VAS) that was introduced in late 1985. The original scheme did succeed in reducing capacity but became increasingly expensive and was too slow in achieving the necessary level of restructuring.
The new package is also based on providing incentives to industry to restructure through a buy-back program, but there are important differences from the old approach.

The first difference is that there is a fixed target size for the fishery of 50,000 fishing units to be achieved by the beginning of the 1993 fishing season. Experience has demonstrated that for restructuring schemes to be successful a fixed target is essential. Although the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics projections indicate that the most efficient level of exploitation would be achieved with a fleet size of less than 40,000 units, the management advisory committee for the northern prawn fishery and the Government have agreed to a target of 50,000 units. If the target is not met a pro rata compulsory surrender with special provision for single boat operators will be implemented to bring the number of units down to 50,000.

Another major difference is that the voluntary buy-back part of the scheme will only operate for a short, sharp, three month period at the beginning of 1991. There will be a fixed price for fishing units and a compensation payment which will be paid when fishermen take their boats out of the fishery (referred to as a redundancy payment).

To fund the buy-back the Government will provide a guarantee for a commercial loan of up to $40.9m, to be repaid over 10 years. The Government will also provide a grant of $5m over three years from the National Fisheries Adjustment Program to assist the industry to repay the loan in the initial years while the increased profits in the fishery are building up. This Bill will amend the existing act to reflect the new loan guarantee. The loan repayments will be funded by a levy which will be collected twice yearly from the northern prawn fishermen. The Fisheries Levy (Northern Prawn Fishery) Regulations will be amended to make these collections.
Amendments will also be made to the northern prawn fishery management plan to allow the whole package to be put in place.

The Government has made no secret of the fact that it expects industry to share some of the new profits which result from this restructuring with the wider community. However. the Government will ensure that any community return charges which it requires industry to pay do not destroy incentives. The Government's view is that where genuine new profits are made arising from the exploitation of a community resource for private gain the industry will share a portion of those profits with the wider community.

I would emphasise that the Government realises it is important to take account of all costs when calculating these profits to avoid creating a cost burden for the industry. The community return legislation which will give effect to this policy is an integral part of this package and will be introduced in the autumn sittings.

While fishermen will not welcome the requirement to pay a community return it is fair to say that they recognise that the fishery will be considerably more profitable after the restructuring even allowing for the new payment of a community return.

Members of the northern prawn fishing industry have been most helpful in the provision of advice during the development of this restructuring scheme and have supported the totality of the restructuring package outlined above. Many of their suggestions are embodied in these arrangements. An industry/government committee has been established to ensure a continuing high degree of consultation. With their assistance and co-operation I expect a smooth transition for this structural adjustment initiative.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

This Bill is an omnibus measure proposing a series of amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901, in addition to a consequential repeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.
The main proposals contained in the Bill relate to:

i) amendments to the Customs Act 1901 to provide the legislative framework for the introduction of an electronic entry and cargo reporting system for exports (EXIT), and the consequential repeal of the Export Return Scheme (Clauses 15 to 23);

ii) the repeal of Sections 64 and 74 of the Customs Act 1901 and the introduction of new sections to provide for the advance reporting of ships and aircraft and their cargo and crew, including the electronic reporting of such information (Clause 10), and the corresponding tightening of customs control over the unshipment of imported goods, especially where no cargo report in respect of such goods has been provided, or where such report is not provided sufficiently in advance (Clause 12); and

iii) the saving of the prohibited imports status of dangerous goods under Item 18 of the Second Schedule of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, which was declared invalid by the Full Federal Court in the recent Owen v Turner and Jones case (Clause 49).
I will now refer briefly to each of those proposals:
i) Introduction of EXIT and Repeal of the Export Return Scheme

The public and private sectors have for some time been pursuing the considerable cost savings available through the use of electronic technology to improve the flow of cargo documentation and information.

The Australian Customs Service is playing a crucial role in this reform through its development of a number of electronic initiatives. Exports integration or``EXIT'' is one of these initiatives, and is one of the largest Electronic Data Interchange initiatives undertaken in Australia to date.

The reports and clearances which the EXIT system allows to be computerised provide the basis for Customs control over Australia's exports. It is also the main source of data for the export component of the periodic balance of payments assessments. Prior to EXIT it was the Export Return Scheme which provided the principal reporting mechanism for export trade statistics.

Administration of the Export Return Scheme over the past 12 years has shown the Scheme to be an unsatisfactory arrangement which does not meet Australia's basic control and statistical requirements. Firstly, Customs control over high risk exports is undermined, as most exports are not reported to Customs until after cargo has left the country.
Secondly, over the past few years inadequacies have become apparent in the statistical information provided through the Scheme.
It is for these reasons that the Government has proposed the repeal of the Export Return Scheme and the introduction of the EXIT system for electronically reporting exports prior to shipment.

Given the economic significance of Australia's balance of payment figures, it is considered that export trade statistics should be collected on a similar basis to imports. In other words, they should be recorded on computer prior to Customs clearance.

Despite the introduction of an electronic option under the EXIT system, exporters will not be forced to become direct participants in the new regime. Exporters may either join EXIT directly, engage the services of a registered EXIT user (a freight forwarder, Customs agent, etc.) or utilise the traditional paper based preshipment export entry scheme. To facilitate the latter process, exporters will be permitted to lodge paper entries by facsimile.
Close to 1,000 exporters have voluntarily joined the EXIT system since trials began and as a result in July 1990, over 65% of our export trade was reported electronically.

The Australian Customs Service and the pioneering members of industry who have participated in the development of EXIT have tackled an ambitious program aimed at taking export reporting into the 21st century. Clauses 15 to 23 of the Bill seek to provide an appropriate legislative basis for the continued operation of the EXIT system. Those clauses are explained in greater detail in the Explanatory Memorandum of the Bill.

As a result of the proposed new export reporting regime for the Customs Act 1901, consequential amendments are necessary to the Excise Act 1901. This will provide uniformity in the treatment of all exported goods, whether excisable or otherwise, and is effected by the proposed amendments contained in Part 3 to the Bill.
ii) Repeal of Sections 64 and 74 and the introduction of new sections

Clauses 10 and 12 of this Bill propose the repeal of Sections 64 and 74 of the Customs Act 1901 and the introduction of new sections to provide for the advance reporting of ships and aircraft and their cargo and crew. Clause 10 also proposes an electronic reporting option for this information in line with other initiatives of the Customs Service, and amendments to the Customs Act to provide for paperless reports and entries. This will expedite the clearance of inward cargo, and benefit the importing community and Australian consumers generally.

The Government considers that the requirements for advance reporting of cargo will also tighten customs control over the unshipment of imported goods and aid in targeting risk cargo to protect the Australian community against the illegal importation of narcotics and other prohibited imports.
iii) Item 18 Amendments

The purpose of the amendments contained in Clause 49 of the Bill is to validate past seizures of dangerous goods, which had been seized on the basis that they were prohibited imports pursuant to Item 18 of the Second Schedule of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations.
Item 18 was introduced into the Regulations on 14 December 1956, and prohibited the importation of:
``Goods which, in the opinion of the Minister, are of a dangerous character and a menace to the community''.

Since 1956 Item 18 has been used to prevent the circulation into the general community of dangerous goods such as machine guns; land mines; flame throwers; flick knives; toys contaminated with dangerous levels of lead, heavy metals or other poisons; unsafe children's toys which do not meet Australian Safety Standards and many other dangerous goods.

The Federal Court of Australia has recently found that Item 18 is invalid. The basis of its decision is that Item 18 is an unauthorised delegation of the Governor-General's power in Section 50 of the Customs Act 1901 to prohibit the importation of goods.
The result is that goods previously understood to be prohibited imports under Item 18, and therefore able to be seized by Customs, are in fact not prohibited imports at all.

The Government has already addressed the future control of dangerous goods by repealing Item 18 and inserting new Items into the Regulations to prohibit the importation of most former Item 18 goods. This was effected by Statutory Rule No. 324 of 11 October 1990, less than 1 month after the Full Federal Court's decision.
The present amendment in this Bill is intended to address the status of pre 11 October 1990 action under the Item 18 prohibition.

This Senate has long been careful when faced with provisions which are retrospective in effect and operate to remove citizens rights, and properly so. In this circumstance, however, the Government is of the view that the amendment is both justified and necessary. The alternative would be the possibility that Customs could be required to release into the general community the bombs, guns, unsafe toys, flick knives etc., that had been seized, in good faith in the belief that Item 18 was valid.

Both the necessity of this provision, and the suggested commencement date for it, have been the subject of advice from the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department, a copy of which was provided as a matter of courtesy to the Opposition spokesperson for Small Business, Housing and Customs, the Member for Forrest.
iv) other amendments

In addition to the amendments already outlined, the Bill also proposes three further amendments which deal with the control of narcotic goods, and the consequences of their illegal importation. The need for these amendments arises from matters identified by the Courts and the Office of the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions. These amendments, which are contained in Clauses 26, 27, 30, 35, 36 and 38 of the Bill, are explained in detail in the Explanatory Memorandum.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present its accompanying Explanatory Memorandum.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (PLANNING AND LAND MANAGEMENT)
AMENDMENT BILL 1990

Mr President, the purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988 by extending from one year to two years the period within which the National Capital Plan is to cover the Territory.
Subsections 57(1) and 57(2) of the Planning and Land Management Act provide that:

(1) When the Governor-General is satisfied that the National Capital Plan sufficiently covers the Territory, the Governor-General shall, by Proclamation, declare that the transition period ends on a day specified in the Proclamation.
(2) The day specified shall not be later than one year after Self-Government Day.

The drafting of the National Capital Plan was completed in February 1990 following a process of public consultation. However the approvals processes which include consultation with the ACT Executive on the Plan, its approval by the Minister and consideration by the Parliament could not be completed largely because of the intervention of the federal election and the application of the convention that Ministers do not take policy decisions which may commit an incoming Government.
My Department received advice from the Attorney-General's Department which indicated in part that.

Although the Planning and Land Management Act shows a Parliamentary expectation that the National Capital Plan will sufficiently cover the Territory within one year after Self-Government Day (ie by 10 May 1990), the Act does not impose on anybody any duty in this regard;

If the National Capital Plan was not in effect until after 10 May 1990, the Governor-General could declare the end of the `transition period', under s.57 (1) of the Act, to be later than 10 May 1990, notwithstanding s.57 (2) of the Act;
The `transition period' would not automatically come to an end on 10 May 1990.

However it is possible that a court may decide that this is not the case, and the transition period has ended. Such a judgement would mean that the Australian Capital Territory has no valid planning system.

In order to remove any possible doubt as to the status of decisions taken in the period since the expiration of the one year period set out in the Act, that is since 10 May 1990, this Bill seeks to provide a period of two years rather than the existing one year period.
The draft National Capital Plan has been recently submitted to the Hon David Simmons, MP for approval and is now under consideration.
I present the explanatory memorandum for this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that at the end of a long sitting day there is often a reluctance for people to speak on the adjournment and that there is even greater reluctance to listen to people speak on the adjournment, but this is a matter, I believe, of some significance. I wish to take this opportunity to raise an article recently published in this month's edition of the Readers Digest entitled `Australia's Asians-are they getting a fair go?'. The article in question canvasses, if it is correct, a significant degree of racial discrimination against Australia's Asian community, a matter that I believe all honourable senators in this chamber would view very dimly.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take the opportunity to cite one particular case. It concerns two young school students who have recently migrated to Australia. The portion of the article reads as follows:

On their first day at a Melbourne school after arriving from Taiwan, Julius Yang, 13, and his 15-year-old sister, Li Ting, sat eating their lunch in the playground. Suddenly a stone whizzed past Li Ting's head. She looked up to see a group of seven teenagers, preparing to hurl another rock. `You chinks!' one of them yelled. `Get back where you come from!' Another stone cracked against the bench before the teenagers ran off laughing, leaving Li Ting in tears.

This country has had in the past a very shameful history of racism, a history that embarrasses, I believe, everybody who sits in this chamber this evening. It is a history of racism that I was hoping this country had left behind it. I certainly know that growing up in Queensland, anyway, is a lot easier for many Asian children than it was 20 years and I hope that in 20 years' time it may be easier still. Yet this particular survey by Readers Digest, a survey of Asian people in Sydney and Melbourne, found that 57 per cent of Asian people under of the age of 30 had experienced racial discrimination and 59 per cent of all male respondents in the survey had experienced racial discrimination.

The consequences of this are very clear. We must attempt to be one country, a united country, not divided by bigotry, racism or prejudice. I note the comments of Mr Will Bailey, the chief executive officer of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, who said, when interviewed by the Readers Digest:
To allow bigotry to alienate our export base would be economic lunacy.

I believe this really goes to the core of the whole issue. I am very aware of the fact that in times when there is an economic downturn racism always historically rises in this country; it rears its sinister ugly head again amongst the ill-informed, bigoted people who exist in the very cesspit of Australian society.

In an increasingly international world, a world in which we must fit into South East Asia, these bigots and racists run a very real risk of alienating this country from our trading partners. I believe that it is the same racism that is endemic in those who oppose foreign investment in this country for no other reason than that the company in question might happen to be Japanese, Taiwanese, Korean or whatever. I was hoping that, in the 20 years since I can first remember growing up in this country, Australia would have changed. If this survey is correct, Australia has changed for the worse. I hope that the results of this survey are some sort of statistical anomaly. I hope that it is some quirk of the people surveyed in Sydney and Melbourne and that it is not found elsewhere in this country.

We must look to the future-to the future of one Australia, one people. The Asian population of this country, the Asian community, has played and will continue to play a very significant and proud role in this nation's future. The Asian community is already under-represented in Parliament. I think that will change over time, and it will be a change for the better.

Many Asian immigrants to this country are very hardworking, as are most immigrants, and they embrace this country wholeheartedly as their own. That is why they have come here. They do not see themselves first and foremost as Chinese or Vietnamese or Asian; they see themselves as Australians. They look only for acceptance in a country that they have accepted as their home. I hope that all honourable senators will support me in condemning the bigots and racists in our society and will agree that we must work for a unified Australia which will be for the better interests of all of us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator O'Chee in the statement he has just made. I believe that there is no place in this nation for people who prey on Asian citizens in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: However, my main reason for taking part in this debate tonight arises from the fact that I saw when walking past the newsstand a headline in the Australian Financial Review. The headline has been running in most of the press, and I believe that tonight is an appropriate time to put down the story that is running in the press because it is untrue.

The headline to which I refer is: `Hewson's credibility hit by party revolt'. I was in the party room when that decision was taken. I can say without any doubt that Dr Hewson listened carefully to the arguments put forward by his parliamentary colleagues-not only in the National Party but also in the Liberal Party-who saw what the Government was trying to do on family allowances and how they would affect people, particularly those in the bush, and made the decision to accept the view of the party room. That is not being `rolled'; it is quite wrong even to suggest that.

In this building we are all representatives, whether we have a seat in the other place or are members of this Senate. We represent a constituency. We are the voice of the people in this Parliament and, as everyone in the Senate will agree, most of the action does not take place on the floor of Parliament, but in the party room. It is wrong to suggest that Dr Hewson was rolled at all. I would like to go on record as saying that, when a leader listens to his troops and then reacts to their wishes, that is not being rolled; it is just representation working in the party room.

It is unlike the Labor Party which factionalises its representation. Its members do deals before they go into their party room and lock those deals in place. Honourable senators opposite would probably never understand what true representation is all about. But I would say that the party room decision was made and it was accepted by the Leader of the Opposition. There was no way that anyone could ever suggest that he was rolled. It is quite wrong for the press to run that line. I hope that the members of the Press Gallery will take notice of what has gone down on the record tonight, move across to some accurate reporting and not depend on some beat-up that they got hold of somewhere.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 12.27 a.m., Friday, until Monday, 26 November 1990 at 2p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 22 May 1990:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A total of 216 ABC employees are based in rural and regional areas.
(2) The 216 staff in rural and regional areas comprise Regional Program Managers, Broadcast Officers (Radio), Broadcast Production Officers, Rural Reporters and Journalists.
All of these people are involved in gathering news and information for broadcasts on Regional Radio. However, 66 of these staff are News Journalists specifically involved in gathering news.

There were three temporary employees who competed unsuccessfully for the positions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 1 June 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: How many, and what are the names of all foreign nationals who gained approval to come to Australia as pilots for Ansett and Australian Airlines in 1989; additionally, what were: (a) the dates of their original applications; (b) the dates of approval; and (c) the dates of entry into Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Pilots sponsored by Ansett and Australian Airlines in 1989 entered Australia either as specialists under temporary residence policy or as employer nominees under migration policy.

Specialists entering for periods of up to 12 months may apply directly to any Australian office overseas and an assessment is usually made without reference to an Australian office of my Department. In my Department's records, specialist temporary resident visas are not necessarily classified by occupational category and consequently it is not possible to provide accurately the information requested by the honourable senator in relation to these visas. My Department has identified 271 pilots sponsored by Ansett and Australian Airlines who applied for visas, were approved, and entered the country as temporary residents for stays varying from less than one week up to 12 months. All these applications were received and approved and the pilots entered Australia in the second half of 1989.

According to Departmental records 62 applications were received in 1989 (1 in October 1989, 40 in November 1989 and 21 in December 1989) from pilots sponsored by Ansett and Australian Airlines under the Employer Nomination Scheme. Visas were issued to 40 of those applicants in 1989 all of whom travelled to and entered Australia. (The number of visas issued in 1989 given in this answer corrects an earlier answer given by the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Ray, in answer to a question from Senator MacGibbon-PQ 1481. More accurate information is now to hand from overseas posts concerning applications received from and visas issued to pilots).

The honourable senator also asked for the names of the pilots who gained approval to come to Australia. I believe to provide this information would be a breach of the basic right of the individuals involved to information privacy. I am therefore not prepared to answer that part of the honourable senator's question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 9 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the drug Berotec, which is used in the treatment of asthma, been dropped from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme; if so, why has it been dropped and what alternatives are available for asthma sufferers or other people dependent on Berotec.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes-the drug fenoterol hydrobromide (Berotec is the brand name) was deleted from the Schedule of Pharmaceutical Benefits on 1 August 1990.

The reason for deletion, on the advice of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, was due to doubts about the safety of the drug for which suitable alternatives are available on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). (Reports have indicated an increase in mortality with the use of fenoterol in patients with severe asthma).

There are a considerable number of drugs available on the PBS used in the treatment of asthma. The most closely related alternative drugs to fenoterol are salbutamol (and salbutamol sulphate) and terbutaline sulphate.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Primary Industries and Energy: Grants to Australian Council of Trade Unions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 11 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What grants has the Minister's department issued to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) during 1990-91.
(2) What grants, if any, does the Minister's department anticipate issuing to the ACTU during the remainder of 1990-91.
(3) What grants were paid by the Minister's department to the ACTU from the period April 1983 to June 1990, inclusive.

(4) For (1), (2) and (3) above, what were the details of the amount of each grant made, or anticipated to be made; the purpose for each of the grants made, or expected to be made; and the date that each of the grants were made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) One grant has been made to the ACTU during 1990-91.

(2) No further grants are proposed to the ACTU during the remainder of 1990-91; however, one grant is proposed to an affiliated union of the ACTU, the United Mineworkers' Federation of Australia (formerly Australasian Coal and Shale Employees' Federation or Miners' Federation)
(3) One grant was made in 1989-90 to the affiliated union, the United Mineworkers' Federation of Australia.

(4) a. 1990-91 (to date); $35,000; to assist involvement to the organisations in the East Gippsland Forest Agreement review of feasible and prudent alternatives to logging national estate forests in East Gippsland;
b. (1989-90) $40,000, 1990-91 (proposed) $40,000; mine safety. The grant is to assist the funding of District Check Inspectors in the western district of NSW and TAS.
